I HAVE often been asked to prepare an autobiography, but my objections to the task have ever been many and various. To one urgent appeal I sent this sonnet of refusai, which explains itself You bid me write the story of my life, And draw what secrets in my memory dwell From the dried fountains of her failing well, With commonpiaces mi~t of peaoe and strife, And such émail faots, with good or evil rife, As happen to us ail have no tale Of thrilling force or enterprise to tell,-Nothing the blood to.Rre, the ohoek to pale My life is in my books thé rooord there, Atruthfulphotograph.isaIlIohoMe To give the world of self, nor will excuse Mine own or others' failures glad to spare From blâme of mine, or praise, both friends and foes, LeaviagunwrittonwhatCtodonlyknows. In fact 1 fdwaya rejocted thé proposai wamed by récent volumes of pestilenfial réminiscences and,would none of it not only 'om its apparent vainglory as to the inevitable extenuation of one's own faults and failures in life, and the equally certain amplification of self-registered virtues and successes, but even still more from the misuhief it might occasion from a petty record of commonplace troubles and trials, due to the changes and chances of this mortal life, to the casual mention or omission of friends or foes, to the influence of circumstances and surroundings, and to other reve-lations~-whether pleasant or the reverse-of matters merely personal, and therefore more of a private than a public character. Indeed, so disquieted was I at the possible prospect of any one getting hold of a' mass of manuscript in old days diligently compiled by my~elf from year to year in several small diaries, that I have long ago ruthlessiy made a holocaust of the heap of such written self-mèmo-ries, fearing their posthumous publication and in this connection let me now add my express protest against the printing hereafter of any of my innumerable private letters to friends, or other MSS., unless they are'strictiy and merely of a literary nature. Biography, where honest and trne, is no doubt one of the most fascinating and instructive phases of litera-ture but it requires a higher Intelligence than. any however intimate friend of a man to do it fairly and fully so many matters of character and circumstance must ever be to him unknown, and therefore will be by him unrecorded. And even as to autobiography, who, short of the Omniscient Himself, can take into just account thé potency of outward surroundings, and still more of inborn hereditary influences, over both mind and body! thé biaa to good or evil, and thé possession or otherwise of gifts and talents,. due very-much under Providence to one's ancient ancestors and one's modern teaohers ? We are each of us morally and bodily the psychical and physical composite of a thousand generations. Albeit every individual pos-sesses as his birthright afreewill to turn either to thé right or to the left, and is liable to a due responsibility for his words and actions, still the Just Judge alone can and must make allowance for the innate inclinings of heredity and the outward influences of circumstance, and He only can hold the balance between the guilt and innocence, the merit or demerit, of His créature. So far as my own~will goes, 1 leave my inner spiritual biography to the Recording Angel, choosing only to give some recollections and memories of my outer literary life. For spiritual self-analysis in matters of religion and affection 1 desire to be as silent as 1 can be but in such a book as this absolute taciturnity on such subjects is practically impossible. For the matter,. then, of autobiography, 1 decline its higher and its deeper aspects as also Iwish not to obtrude on the public eye mere domesticities and priva-oies of life, But inainly lest others less acquainted 'with. thé petty incidents of my career should hereafter take up the task, 1 accede with all anl ness and humility to what seems to me like a present oall to duty, having little time to spare at seventy-six, so near the end of my tether,-and protesting, as 1 well may against the charge bf seinsh egotism in a book neces-sarilyspotted on every page with the insignificant letter I and while~ of course on human-nature-principles, wiUing enough to exhi.bit myself at the best, promising also -not to hide the second best, or worse than that whereloan perceive it.. That shrëwd old philosopher, Benjamin Franklin, thus excuses his own self-imposed task of autobiography, and 1 cannot do better than quote and adopt his wise and just remarks In thus employing myself, 1 shall yield to thé in-clination so natural to old men, of talking of themselves and their own actions, and I shaJl indulge it without being tiresome to those who, from respect to my a~e, might conceive themselves obliged to listen to me, since they will always be ee to read me or not. And I may as well confess it, as the denial would be believed by nobody 1 shall, perhaps, not a little gratify my own vanity. Indeed, I never heard or saw the introduotory words, Without vanity 1 may say,' c., but some vain. thing immediately followed. Most people dislikovanity in others, whatever share they may have of it them-selves but 1 give it fair quarter wherever 1 meet with it, being persuaded that it is often productive of good to the possessor, and to others who are within his sphère of action and there re, in many cases, it would not be altogether absurd if a man were to thank God for his vanity among the other comforts of life. And now 1 speak of thanking God, 1 désire, with ail hunulity, to acknowledge that 1 attributë the happi-nesa of my past life to Bis divine providence, which led me to the means 1 used, and gave the success. My belief of this induces me to hope, though I must not ~fesM~e, that the same gbodness will still be exeroised towards me in continuing that happiness or enabling me to bear a fatal reverse, which î may expérience as others have done the oomplexion of my future fortune being known. to Him only in whose power it is to. bless us, even in our afHictions. Thus speaketh the honest wisdom of Benjamin Franklin. I do not see that a better plan can be chosen for carry-ing out the title of this book than the one 1 have adopted, namely, tracing from the earliest years to old age the author's literary life-work, illustrated by accounts of, and spécimens from, his various books and writings, especially those which are absolutely oùt of print, or. haply have never been published. No doubt, in auch excerpts, exhibited at their best, the critical accusations of un irness, self-seeking, and so foith, will be'made, and may be met by the true considération that some-thing of this sort is inevitable in autobiography. How-ever, for the matter of vanity, ail 1 know of myself is the tact that praise, if consciously undeserved, only de-presses me instead of elating that a noted characteristie of mine through life bas been to hide away in the rosr rather than rush to the front, unless, indeed, forced for-wald by duty, when I can be bold enough, if need be and that one defect in me ail know to be a dislike to any assumption of dignity-surely a eling the opposite to self-conceit whilst, if I am not true, simple, and sin-cere, 1 am worse than I hope 1 am, and all my friends are deceived in their kind judgment of me. But let this book speak for itself 1 trust it is honest, charitable, and rationally religious. If 1 have and I show it tcrough aJl my writings a s of every denomination, that feeling I take to be due to some ancient heredity ingrained, or, ~nore truly, inburnt into my nature from sundry pre-Lutheran ooNfessors and martyrs of old, from whom I claim to be deacended, and by whose spirit 1 am imbued. Not but that.I profess myself broad, and wide, and liberal enough for ail manner of allowances to others, and so far as any narrow pre-judices may be imagined of my idiosyncrasy, 1 must allow myself to be changeable and uncertain-though hitherto having steered through life a fairly straight course-and that sometimes 1 can even doubt as to my politics, whether they should be defined Whig or Tory as to my religion, whether it is most truly chargeable by the epithet high or low as to my likings, whether 1 best prefer solitude or society as to literature, whether gaieties or gravities please me most. In fact, 1 recognise good in everything, though sometimes hidden by evil, right by intention, at least in sundry doctrines and opinions otherwise to my judgment wrong, and 1 am wifling to believe the kindliest of my opponents who appear to be honest and'eamest. This is a very ir creed for a citizen, of the world, whose motto is Terence's famous avowal, Homo sum, humani nihil a me alienum puto. CHAPTER II. INFANOY AND SOHOOLDAYS. IN a short and simple way, then, and without any desire ostentatiously to chronicle small béer, as lago sneers it, I suppose it proper to state very briefly when and where 1 was born, with a word as to my parentage. Ju y 17,1810, was my birthday, and No. 20 Devonshire Place, Marylebone, my birthplace, at that time the last house of London northward. My father, Martin Tupper, a name ever honoured by me, was an eminent médical man, who twice refused a baronetcy first from Lord Liverpool, and secondiy, as offered by thé Duke of Wellington my mother, Ellin Devis Marris, being daughter of Robert Marris, a good landscape artist, of an old Litioolnshire family, and made the heiress, as adopted child, of her aunt, Mrs. Ellin Devis, of Devon-shire Place and Albury. My father's family have sojourned 336 years in Guernsey, having migrated thither from Thuringia, t'KÏ Hesse Cassel, owing to religious persécution in the evil days of Charles V., our remote ancoators being styled Von Topheres chieftains, or head-lords of Treffurth as is recorded in the horaldic MSS. of the British Museum , that being the origin of our name. Of my mother's family in old time Maris, as of the sea, with mermaids for heraldry , 1 have the commis-aions of one who was an Ironside cavalry omcer, signed by Cromwell and Fairfax and several of her relatives besides her father were distinguished artists. In par-ticular, her uncle my wife's father , Arthur William Devis, the well-known historical painter, and her great-uncle, Anthony Devis, who filled Albury House with his landscapes. Somo of our old German stock crossed the Atlantic in Puritan times, and many of the name have, attained 'wealth and position both in Canada and thé Ùnited Statea notably Sir Charles Tupper northwards, and sundry rich merchants in New York, Virginia, and the Carolines southwardiy. Of my in ncy let me record that 1 enjoyed very délicate health, chieny due, as I now judge, to the con-stant cuppings and bleedings whereby thé faouHy of those days combated teething nts, and perhaps with Malthusian proclivities killed off young chiidren. 1 remember, too, that thé broad meadows, since developed into Regënt's Park and Primrose Hill, then- truly rural, and even up to Chalk Farm, then notorious for duels, were my nursery ramblings in search of cowslips and new milk. AIso, that once at least in those' infantile days, my father took me to see Winsor's Patent Gasiights at Carlton Hoùse, and ho~ he prognosticated the domestio failure of so perilous an explosive, more than one blowing-up having carelessly occurred. Another infantile recollection is mémorable, as thus. My father's annual lioliday happened one year to be at Bognor, where a patronpatiéiit ôf his, Lord Arran, rented a pleasant villa, and he h'ad ~br a visitor at thé timono lésa a personago than George thé Third it .must hâve been during some lucid interval, perhaps after the Great Thanksgiving at St. Paul's. My father took his little boy with him to call upon the Ear!, not thinking to see the Eing but when we came in there was his kind-hearted Majesty, who patted my curis and gave me his blessing 1 How far the mysterious efficacy of the royal touch affected my after career believers in the divine rights and spiritual powers of a king may speculate as' they please.. At all events I got a good man's blessing. I remember also in my nursery days to have heard this curious story of a dream. My father, when a young man, was a student at Guy's Hospital, from which school of medicine he went to Yarmouth to attend the wounded after the battle of Copenhagen. He was on one occasion leaving Guernsey for Southampton in the clumsy sea-going smack of those days, when, on the night before embarking, he dreaint, that on his way to the harbour he crossed the churchyard and fell into an open grave. Telling this to his parents at The Pollet, they would not let him go, with a sort of superstitions wiedom for, strangely enough, the smack was seized on ita voyage by a privateer, and all the crew and passengers were consigned-for twelve years-to a French prison 1 1 have heard my father tell this tale, and noted early how true was Dr. Watts' awkward line, On little things what great depend. I might say more about warnmgs in dreams and other somnolencies, whereof we all have expériences. For instance, my Dream of Ambition in Proverbial Philosophy was a real one. And this re-minds me now of another like sort of spiritual monition alluded to in my Proverbial Essay on Truth in Things False, whioh bas several times occurred to myself, as this, for example Years ago, in Devonshire, for the first time, 1 was on the top of a coach passing through a town-I think it was Crediton-and 1 had the strangé feeling that 1 had seen all this before now, we changed horses just on this sida of a cross street, and 1 resolved within myself to test the truth of the place being new to me or not, by prophesying what 1 should see right and left as we passed to my consternation it was all as 1 had foreseen,-a market-place with the usual incidents. Now, if reasonably asked how to account for this and most of us have felt the like , I reply that possibly in an elevated state of health and spirits the soul may out-run the body, and literally foresee coming events both real and ideal. But we must leave this to the Psychical Society for a judgment upon the famous Horatian philo-sophy of more things in heaven and earth, c. On Mr. Galton's topic of hereditary talent 1 have little to report as to myself. Neither father nor mother had any leanings either towards verse or prose but my mother was an excellent pianiste and a fair landscape painter both in oils and water-colour also she drew and printed on stone, and otherwise showed that she came of an artistic family. As to my ther's surroundings, his brother Peter, a consul-général in Spain, wrote a tragedy caUed Pelayo and 1 possess half-a-dozen French songs, labelled by my father in my late dear father's handwriting, but whether or not original, 1 cannot tell. As a Guernsoyman, he might well be as much Frenoh as English. They seem to me clever and worthy of Beranger, though long before him possibly they are my grandsire's. A very fair judge of French pootry., and himself a good Norman poet, Mr. John Sullivan of Jersey writes and tells me that the songs are excellent, and that he remembers them to have been popularly sung when he was a boy. About the matter of hereditary bias itself, we know that as with animais so with men, fortes creantur for-tibus, et bonis this so far as bodies are concemed but surely spirits are more individual, as innumerable instances prove, where children do not take after their parents. If, however, I may mention my own small ex-perience of this matter, literary talent, or at all events aùthorship, is hereditary, especially in these days of that general epidemic, the cacoethes scribendi. I wrote this paper following originallyfor an American publication and as I cannot improve upon it, and it has never been printed in England, I produce it here in its integrity. A true and genuine record of what English schools of the highest class were more than sixty-five years ago cannot fail to have much to interest the present genera-tion on both sides of the Atlantic if only because we may now indulge in thé self-complacency of being every-way wiser, bétter, and happier than our recent forebears. And in setting myself to write thèse early revelations, 1 wish at once to state that, although at times neces-sarily naming names for the too ireq~ent use of dashes and asterisks must otherwise destroy the verisimilitude of plain truth-telling , I desire to say nothing against or for either the dead or the living beyond their just déserts, and 1 protest against any charge of unreason-abio want of charity as to my whilom schools and sohoolmasters, It is true that sometimes 1 loved them not, neither can I in general respect their memory but thé causes of such a feeling on my part shaH be made mamfest amon, and 1 am sure that modem parents and guardians will rejoice that much of my childhood's hard expérience bas not been altogether that of their own boys. I was sent to school much too soon, at the early âge of seven, having previously had for my home tutor a well-remembered day-teacher in little Latin and lèse Greek of the name of -Swallow, whom I thought a wit and a poet in those days because one niorning he pro-duced as an epitaph on himself the following effusion Beneath this atone a Swallow lies, No one laughs and no one cries Where he is gone or how he fares No one knows and no one oares. At this time of day I suspect this epigram not to be quite original, but it served to give me for the nonce a. high opinion of the pundit who read with me Cornelius .Nepos and Csesar and some portions of that hopeless grammar, the Eton Greek, in thé midst of his hard-breathing consumption of perpétuai sandwiches and béer. The nrst school chosen for me though expensive, .there could not have been a worse' one was large mixed establishment for boys of all ages, from infancy to early manhood, belonging to one Rev. Dr. Morris of EgglesËeld House, Brentford Butta, whioh I now judge to have been conducted solely with a view to the pro-prietor's pocket, without reference to the morals, happi-ness, or education of the pupils committed to his care. AU 1 care to remember of this false priest and there werë many such of old, whatever may be the ca~e now are his cruel punishments, which passed for discipline, bis careful cringing to parents, and his careless indi1fer-ence towards their children, and in brief bis total un6t-ness for the twin duties of pastor and teacher. A large private school of mixed ages and classes is perilously liable to infection from licentious youths left to them-selves and their evil propensities, and 1 can feelingly recollect how miserable for nearly a year was that poor little helpless innocent of seven under the unrestricted tyranny of one Cooke in after years a life convict for crime who did ail he could to pollute the infant mind of the little fag delivered'over to his cruelty. Cowper's Tirocinium well expresses thé situation Would you your son should be a sot or dunoe, Lasoivious, headstrong, or all these at once, Train him in publie with a mob of boys, Childish in misohief only and in noise, Elae of a mannish growth and, five in ten, For infidelity and lewdness, men. My next school was. more of a success for Eagle House, Brookgreen, where 1 was from eight to eleven, had for its owner and headmaster a most worthy and excellent layman, Joseph Railton. Mr. Railton was gentle, though gigantic, fairly learned, just and kindly. His school produced, amongst others eminent, the fitmous naval author Kingston, well known from cabin-boy to admirai there was also Lord Paulet, some others of noble birth, and thé two Middletons, nick-named Taukees, whom years after 1 visited at their rained mansion in South Carolina after thé Confederate War. 'fhrough.the personal good influence of'honest Old Joe, and hie middle-aged housekoeper, Mrs. Jones, our whole well-ordëredcompanyofperhapsahundred boys lived and learned, workod and played purely and happily together so great a social benefactor may a good school chieftain be. I have little to regret in my Brook Green recollections the annual fair was mémorable with Richardson's show and Gingel's conjuring, and the walks for mild cricket-ing at Shepherd's Bush, and the occasional Sundays at home and how pleasant to a schoolboy was thé generous visitor who tipped him, a good action never forgotten. and the garden with its flowering tulip-tree, and the syringaa and rose-trees jewelled with the much-prized emerald May-bugs for the whole garden was liberally thrown open to us beyond the gravelled playground all being now given. over to monks and nuns. Then I recollect how a rarely-dark annular éclipse of the sun convulsed the whole school, bringing smoked glass to a high premium and there was a notable boys library of amusing travels and stories, all eagerly devoured and old Phulax thé house-dog, and good Mr. Whitmore an usher, who gave a certain small boy a diamond prayer-book, greatly prized then, though long since'lost, and suitably inscribed for him ~T~M~~cM~x c~ceM and the speech days, wherein the aame émail boy always signalised himself, to thé general astonishment, for he was usually a stammerer, owing much to thé early worries of Brentford ail these are agreeable réminiscences. My next school at eleven was Qharterhouse, or as my schoolfellow Thackeray was wont to style it, Slaughtër. house, no doubt from the cruel tyranny of another educational D.D., the Rev. Dr. Russell. For this .man and the school he so despotioally drilled into passive servility and pedantio scholarship, I have less than no révérence, for he worked so upon an over-sensitivë nature to force a boy beyond his powers, as to fix for many years the infirmity of stammering, which waa my affliction until past middle life. As for tuition, it must all have grown of itself by dint of private hard grinding with dictionaries and grammars, for the exercises, themes, and other lessons were,notoriously difficult, and those before me would be inextricable puzzles now however, we had to do them, and we did them, unhelped by any teacher but our own iridustry. As for the masters in school, two more ignorant old parsons than Chapman and Bob Watki could not readily be found and though the four others, Lloyd, Dickens, Irvine, and Penny were somewhat more intelligent, still aJl six in the lower school were occasionally summoned to a concio, if the interprétation of any ordinary passage in Homer or Virgil or Horace was haply in dispute between a monitor and his class. In the upper school the single really excellent teacher and good clergyman, Edward Churton, had but one fault, a meek subserviency to the tyrannie Russell, who domineered over ail to our universal terror and 1 remember kindly Mr. Churton once affected to tears at the cruelty of his chie What should we think, nowadays of an irate schoolmaater smaahmg a child's head between two books in his shoulder-of-mutton hands till the nose bled, as 1 once saw Or, in these milder times when your burglar or garotter is visited with a brief whipping, what shall we judge of the wisdpm or equity of some slight fault of idleness or ignorance being visited with thé Reverend Bootor's terrible sentence Allen, three rods, eighteen, amdmostaBverely ? 1 Let me comment on this line, one of a sharp satire by a boy hamëd Barnes, long since an Indian ,Judge and 1 suppose translated Eisewhere. Allen was head gown-boy, and so chief executioner, thé three roda being some five-feet bunches of birch amned with buds as sharp as thorns, renewed after six strokes for fresh excoriation 1 sometimes the exhibition was in medio, a. public terror to evil-doers, or doers of nothing, but usually in a sort of side chapel to the lower school where the whipping-block stood. Who oould tolerate such things now and who can wonder that I, aa a lad, proclaimed that 1 would rather die than be flogged, for 1 had resolved in that event to commit justifiable homicide on my Bogger? 1 I do not mean Allen, who became Head of Dulwich Collège, and with whom I hâve since dined annuaUy as donor of a picture there, but Russell, concerning whom 1 vowed that if ever ho was made a Bishop happily he wasn't 1 would desert the Church of Englamd as yet I have nôt, albeit it has lately become so papalised as to be little worth an honest Protestanfs adhérence. As to the exclusively dassic education in my young days, to the resolute neglect of all other languages and sciences, I for myself have from youth upwards always protested against it as mainly waste of time a.nd of very little service in the battle of life. For proof of this, before 1 waa eighteen, I wrote that essay on Education to be seen in my first series of Proverbial Philosophy, whieh long years after the celebrated Dr. Binney of the Weigh-house in Thames Street issued with my leave as a tractate useful. to the present génération. And while there was so much fuss made as to the criminality of a false quantity in Greek, or a déficient acquaintance with those awkward verbs in ~ii, or above ail a fa se con-cord every one of which derelictiona in duty mvdved severe punishment , let us remember that all this time Holywell Street was sunered to infect Charterhouse with its poison I speak of long ago, before Lord Camp-bell's wholesome Act , and that our clerical tutors and governors profëssionally recognised no sort of sins or shortcomings but those committed in classt 1 They practically ignored everything out of school, much as a captain knows nothing of his company off duty. It was the idle system of boys set to govern boys, that the masters might hâve no damage. 1 think the system was called Lancastrian. One very noticeable trait in the pajson-schoohnasters of those old days and perhaps it still survives was the subserviency to rank and wealth towards any pupils likèly to give them livings, whereof more anon at présent, an appropriate instance ocours to me. 1 was in my thirteenth year monitor of the playground, when one Dillon, a scion of a titled family, hunted and killed a stray dog there, and much to their credit for humanity a number of other boys hunted and pelted him into a dry ditch or vallum, dug for the leaping-pole under a Captain Cliaa who taught us athletics. 1 was technicaJIy responsible for this open insult offored to Hibemiam nobility, however well disposed to look another way and let lynch-law take its course.' Accord-ingly, the Doctor had me up for punishment, and he inflicted an almost impossible imposition, Book Epsilon of the Iliad the longest of ail to be translated word for word, English and Greek, and to be given to him in MS. within a month it would have been work for a year , that or expulsion. Had Mr. Dillon been a plebeian, no notice would have been taken of the matter, but he was an honourable, so Russellmust a avenge his-righteous punishment. However, the result of this outrageous set-task was curious and worthy of this ita first and only record. AU the seventy boys in Irvine's house and others elsewhere, volunteered to do the whole imposition for me, and within a week hundreds of pages closely written with Greek and Latin, were sewn together, making a large quarto pamphlet, whioh was duly handed by me to the won-dering Doctor who had, however, too much shrewd-ness to care to inquire closely as to this popular out-burst of a general indignation, so, he said nothing more about it. For other playground réminiscences I saw, even in those tame times for cricket when overhand bowling was illegal, and the fierce artillery of a Spofforth im-possible, a poor lad killed in the field, one Honourable Benry Howard he was taken to the pump for recovery, as from a swoon, but the bail had struck.him behind the ear, stone-dead. Again as to that pump it was some times maliciously used for sousing unfortunate- day-boys, who were allowed two minutes law out of school to enable them to escape pursuit after lessons, most un-' justly, and injuriously, seeing that old Sutton founded his Charterhouse mainly for day-boys John Leech waa one in my time and for pensioners old Cods whereof Colonel Newcome of Thackeray fame, was another but both of these charity classes were utterly despised and ignored by the reverend brigands who kept all the loaves and fishes for themselves. One remarkable playground experience was the fact that it helped to dévelop in me antiquarian inclina-tions, and my own discoyered hunting-ground for Homan numismatics in the south of Englahd, long after~ wards expanded in Farley Heath near Albury. At Charterhouse there was a great slope or semi-mound which had in old times been utilised as a wholesale grave for the victims of plague and other épidémies. It strikes me now as most perilous, but we boys used. to dig and scratch among bones and other ~ rM for an occasional coin or lead token, whereof I found several it is only a wonder that we did not unearth pestilence, but mould is fortunately very antiseptic. Another playground peculiarity was that after the hoop season, usually driven in duplicate or triplicate, the hoops were stored or shied into the branching elms, from wbich they were again brought down by hockey-sticks flung at them a great boon to the smaller boys who thus gratuitously. became possessed of valuable properties. And for aM else, there wore fights behind the school, in those pùgilistic days scientifically conducted with seconda and bottleholders, and some claret drawn, and other like faahionable brutalities also in its season came footbaïï, but not quite so nercely fought as it is now and there was Mr. Rackwitz, the man of sweeta and pàatries at the corner and another sort of rackets in the tennis court and for another sort of court there waa then extant a bit of ruinous Gothic in old Rutland Court, a ghostly entrance from Charterbouse Square, some thoùght haunted, and long since cleared away And now crossing the Square we corne tq No. 41, thé Queen Anne fashiohed mansion where Mr, Andrew Irvine another Reverend Master, who like ail the rest, except Churton, almost never did duty, and when he did manifestly could neither read, preach, nor pray had a housefui of pupils, whereof the writer was one, That long room is full of ancient memories of past and gone Carthusians, though it is now humiliated into a local charity school. I remember some humorous scenes there, chiefly owing to the master's notorious niggardiiness. Andrew had some Gruyere cheese, easily accessible to the boyish plunderers of his larder. Now we had complained that our stabs of butter laid between the eut sides of the rolls often were sait and strong, so one Punsonby afterwards an earl man-aged to put a piece of highly-flavoured Gruyère into a roll, and publicly at breakfast produced it before Mr. Irvine as a proof of the bad butter provided by the un-fortunate housekeeper. He was overborne against his own convictions, by the hcroic impudence of chief big boys whom he dared not offend, and actually pretended indignation, promising better butter in future 1 For another small scholastio recollection Andrew's Indian brother had brought over a lot of ouriosities from the East, including a rhinocéros skin, and bows and arrows, idols, and the like, ail of which were carelessiy stored away in a cellar near thé larder aforeaaid Of course thé boys made a raid upon such spoKa opima, and divers portions of that thick hide were exhibited as Indian rubber but Andrew never knew that many other things vanished, and that for example Knighton used to walk home on Saturdays with preternaturally stin' arms, an arrow possibly poisoned being hid in each sieevet some creeses also were appropriated by. bthers. I wonder if any Carthusian of my time sur-vives as the possessor of such loot. Lot me record, too, that in those evil days for 1 am not one who can think this, age aa pejor avis boys used to go, on their Monday momings' retum from thé weekly holiday, out of their way to see the wretches hanging at Newgate that the scenes of cruelty to animais in Smithfield were terrible that books of the vilest character were circulated in the long-room and that both morality and religion were ignored by the seven clergymen who reaped fortunes by neglecting five hundred boys. If more memories are wanted of those times, here are two the planned famine on one occasion, when-under monitorial inspiration-ail the juniors clamoured for more, more, seeing they had slabbed on the underside of tbe tables masses of bread and butter supposed tô have been eaten-out and on another, that lobsters, surreptitiously obtained from out-ô~-bounds by the big boys were sworn in the M of their smaller claws to be pieces of seaJing-wax 1 and nothing else at ieast a reckless young aristocrat declared that they were so,-and the mean-spirited Andrew, fearful of giving offence in such high quarters, pretended to believe him. Yet another trifle for I find that, such trivials are attractive to homeflock readers, by whose taste I feel the more public pulse, even as Rousseau did with his house-keeper. We, that is Knighton and Ellis and I, used to return on Sunday night in my father's carnage by the back way of Clerkenwell to Charterhouse in order to avoid the crowds of oattle and I well. remember that some-times we would utilise apples and nuts from the dessert as missiles from our carriage window as we sped along. Alas on one occasion Knighton was skilfui enough to smash a. ohemiet's blue bottle with an apple,-and on another I am aware that an oil lamp in Cârthusian Street succumbed to m~ only too-truo cockshy Et hoc meminisse d'oS~M~ Another incident was amusing in its way. PoorMr. Irvine who was going to be married mended up, very much smashed greenhouse to greet his bride thereby with floral joy. Unluckily, the boys preferred broken panes to whole ones, so nothing was easier than by flinging brickbats and even mugs over the laundry wall to revel in the sweet sound of smashed glass moreover this would go to evidence the popular animosity against a wretched bridegroom. Then, when he reappeared aftèr some temporary absence before the wedding, it was after this ridiculous fashion. There was a wooden staircase screened off one side of the long-room down which he would occasionally creep to listen at the door at bottom to the tattle of the boys about him. Ee was heard creaking downstairs, and some active young fellow by a round-about byway managed to steal down behind and suddenly pushed him by the burst open door, spread-eaglé fashion, into the laughing long-room f The poor victim pretended it was an acci-dent, Ye see, Mr. Yates, I was coming down the stair, and me foot slipped. It seems that the luckless Andrew was coming, so he averred, expressly to expostulate'with thé boys, to throw himself on their generosity for a subscription towards his ruined greenhouse, and to ask Messrs. Punsonby, Yates, Co. to promote it. This they promiséd to do, and did after an original fashion. Soveral pounds worth of pence and half-pence were dis-tributed through the house, so that when Andrew with his traitorous aides went round to collect monies, it miraculouslyhappened to be all coppers, unrelieved by single sparkle of silver or gold. On which, in a red rage and he often was in the like he flung the whole bowlful into the long-room fire, from the ashes whereof for days after the small boys gladly collected hot half-pence.. We must recollect that the canny Scot was a mean over-reaching man, so perhaps he was well paid out. Soon after the wedding, the bridegroom held high festival, and gave a grand dinner to all tho masters. Our big boys were equal to the occasion, and as the hired waiters from thé Falcon brought out the viands all was a delusive peace as they went in our harpies flew upon the spoil, and each meat, fish and fowl was cleared off the great dishes held between the helpless hands of the astonished servitors I It was really too bad, but if a man is so manifestly unpopular no doubt he deserves it. Rugbeians would not have so served Arnold. In 1832, my journal about Dorsetshire and the Isle of Wight is chiefly geological as this extract shows, it was mainly a search after fossil spoils at Char. mouth Would you like to see a creature with the head of a lizard, wings of a bat, and tail of a serpent ? î Such things have been, as these bones testify they are called Pterodactyls, and are as big as ravens. Thus, you see, a dragon is no chimera, but attested by a science founded on observation, Geology. As their bones known by their hollowness often occur in thé coprolites or fossil dung of Plesiosauri, mighty monsters of the deep like gigantic swans, it is thought they were their spécial prey,'for which the long and flexible neck of the Plesiosaurus is au à priori argu-ment, c. c. The 1833 journal is Welsh and, inter alia, 1 therein drew and 1 now record that recently destroyed and more recently restored Druidical movement, thé Buck-stone Il A solid mass of rock, not of living adamant but of dead,pudding-stone, seemingly 'by subtie magie poised' on the brow of a steep and high hill, wooded with oaks the top of this mass of rock is an area of fifty-four feet, its base being four, and the height twelve. It was once a logan stone, but now bas no rocking properties though most perilously poised on the side of a slope, and certainly, if in part a work of nature, it must' have been helped by art, seeing the mère action of thé atmosphere nover could have so Maotly chiselled away all but the centre of. gr vity. The secret of the Druids, in. this instance at least, was in leaving a large mass behind, which as a lever counter-acted the prépondérance of the rock. I drew on the spot two exact views of it, taken to scale,-whereof this is one,-now of some curious value, sinee its in-tentional destruction last year by snobbish party of mischievous idiots. For a specimen page of this let me give'what follows the locality is near Inverness and the Cale-donian Canal Wo now bent our steps toward Craig Phadrick, two miles north. This is the site of one of the celebrated vitrified forts, concerning the création of. which there has been so much learned discussion. And verily there is room, for there is mystery I. will detail what we saw. On the summit of a. steep hill of con-glomerate rock we could trace very clearly a double oblong enclosure of eighty yarda by twenty, with entrances east and west, a spaëe of nve yards being between the two oblongs. Thé mounds were outwardly of turf, but uuder a thin skin of this was a thick con-tinuous wall of molten stone, granité, gneiss, and sand-atone, bubbling together in a hotchpot 1 Thé existence of these forts occurring frequently on the heights and of various shapes is attempted to be explained by divers theories. One man tells us they were beacons but, nrst, what an enormous one is here, one hundred and twenty-four feet by sixty of blazing wood, timber being scarce too next, they sometimes occur in low situa-tions from which a flame could scarcely be seen thirdly, common wood fire will not melt granite. Another pundit says they are volcanic. 0 wondrous volcano to spout oblong conoentric areas of stone walls 1 Perhaps the best explanation is that the Celts cemented these hilltops of strongholds by means of coarse glass, a sort of red-hot mortar, using sea-sand and seaweed as a flux. This is Professor Whewell's idea, and with him we had some interesting conversation on that and other sub-jects. Of this Scotch tour, full of interest, thus very curtiy. Tum we now to Ireland in 18~. My record of just fifty years ago is much what it might be now, starvation, beggary, and human wretchedness of all sorts in the midst of a rich land, through indolence relapsed into a jungle of thorns and briars, quaking bogs and sterile mountains whisky, and the idle un-certain potato, combining with ignorance and priest-craft, to démoralise the excitable unreasoning race of modem Celts. Let us turn from the sad scenes of which my said diary is full, to my day at the spar caverns of Kingston. Attho bottom of a stone quarry, we clad ourselves in sack garmonts that mud wouldn't spoil, and with lit candles descended into the abyss, hands, knees, and elbows being of as much service as our feot. Now, I am not going to map my way after the manner of guido-books, nor to nickname 'thé gor-geous architecture of nature according to the caprice of a rude peasant on the spot or the fancy of a passing stranger. 1 might nll a page with accounts of Turks' tents, beehives, judges' wigs, harps, handkerchiefs, and flitches of bacon, but 1 rather choose to speak of thèse subterranean palaces with none of such vulgar similari-ties. No one eversaw such magnineence in stalactites from the black fissured roofs of antres vast and low-browed caves they are hanging, of all conceivable shapes and sizes and descriptions. Now a tall-~uted column, nôw a fringed canopy, now like a large white sheet flung over a beetling rock in the elegant folds and easy drapery of a curtain, everywhere are pure white stalactites like icicles straining to meet the sturdier mdunds of stalagmite below whilst in the smaller caves slender tubes extend from top to bottom like congealed rain. One cavern is qùite curtaihed round ivithdazztingandwaTytàpestry another has gigantic masses of the white spar pouring from its crannied roof like boiled Brobdingnag macaroni others like heâps of snowy linen lying about or hanging from the ceiling. The extent of the caves is quite unknown eleven acres I was told have been surveyed and mapped, while there are six avenues still unexplored, and you may already wander for twenty-four hours through the dis-covered provinces of the gnome king. This is not to be compared with Kentucky, perhaps not quite with Derbyshiro but it seemed to me marvellous. at the time. One of the neighbouring rocks presented on its surface a fine specimen of what are called rock basins but unluckily for the antiquary, this excavation is on the side of the stone, not on the summit so that it could not possibly hold water, and is clearly caused by some particular moss eating away the stone.-By three o'clock returned to ~enzance, had dinner it was break-fast too , bought a mineral memorial, and in the gig. again, over the sands to the outlandishly named Mara Zion, or Market Jew, words probably of similar import. Opposite to this little place, and joined to it by a neck qf rocks passable at low-water, stands that picturesque gem, Mount St. Michael. You know the sort of thing an abrupt pyramid of craggy rock, crowned with an edifice, half stronghold and half cathedral. It is a home of the St. Aubyn family, and is vell kept up in the ancient style, but in rather a small way a portcullised entrance, old armour hanging in the guard-room, a beautiful dining-hall with carved oak roof, and panels, and chairs a chapd to match, with stained windows an elegant Gothio drawing-room, white and gold and everything, down to black-leather drinking jugs, in character with the feudal stronghold..1 mounted.the corkscrew tower, and got to the broken atone lantern they call St. Michael's chair an uncomfbrtable job, but rewarded by a splendid panorama, gilt by the setting sun in the chapel too, 1 descended into a miserable dungeon oommunicating with a monk's stall, where doubtless some self-immured peni-tent had wasted life away, only coming to thé light. for D matins, and only relieved from solitary imprisonment by midnight mass. This has been discovered but very lately in repairing the chapel it was walled up, and contained a skeleton. As a matter of course, this old castle contains a little hidden room, where that ubiqui-tous vagabond, the royal Charles, laid his hunted head the poor persecuted debauchee sponged upon all hia friends like Bellyserious Buggins. Back again, by water this time, to little Mara Zion, but ever and anon'looking with admiration on that beautiful mount the western rocks are really magnificent, as big as the largest hay-stacks, and tumbled about as loosely as an emptied sugar-basin some hanging by a corner, and others rest-ing on a casual fragmeut 1 am sure of one logan-stone, if a little impertinent bit of rock were only moved away and 1 walked under and between more Titanic architec-ture than Stonehenge can show the Druids, for my part, shall have their due, but not where they don't deserve it. Now, you can readily imagine that 1 was by no means hot, and though the night of Thursday last was rather mild, still it waa midwinter aooordingly 1 conceived and executed a marvellous calorificating plan, whioh evon the mail-coachmanhad nover heard of. Haying comforted my interiors with hot grog of thé stiffest, 1 called for. another shillingsworth of brandy, and deliberately emptied it, to the astonished edification of. beholders, into my boots 1 literal fact, and it kept my feet comfortable all night long. And so, wrapped all in double clothing, sped 1 my rapid way, varying what 1 had before seen by passing through desolate Bodmin, and its neighbourhood of rock, moor, and sand hot coffee at Liskeard, morning broke soon after, then the glorious sun over the sea. Hamoaze, the ferry, and Devonport at past 8. Much as 1 longed to get home, 1 went forthwith into a hot bath at 102, to boil out all chills, and thence went spick and span to my happy rest, having within 48 hours seen the best part of Cornwall and its wonders, and rode or walked 250 miles. And so, brother David, commend me for a traveller. HERE ends my Cornish expédition. F. T. JN 1829 1 was entered as a commoner at Christ Cburch, Oxford, and went through the usual course of lectures with fair success. As a fumily we have all favoured Oxford rather than Cambridge my father and two cousins, Elisha and Carré, were at Exeter Collège, to take. the benefit of its Sarnian Exhibitions my brother Daniel was at Brasenose, and my brother William gained a scholarship of Triuity. Enough, sad Muse, enough thy downward night Has oleft with wearied wing the shades of night Be drest in smiles, forget the gloomy past, And, cygnet-like, sing sweeter at the last, Strike on the ohords of joy a happier strain And be thyself, thy oheerful self, again. Hail, goodly company of generous youth, Hail, nobler sons of Temperanoe and Truth 1 I see attendant Ariels oiroling there, Light-hoarted Innocence, and Pmdenco fair, Sweet Chastity, young Hope, and Reason bright, And modest Love, in heaven'6 own hues bedight, Staid Diligence, and Eeaith, and holy Grace, And gentle Happiness with smiling face,-All, all are there and Sorrow speeds away, And Melancholy flees the sons of day Dull Caie is gladden'd with reflèoted light, And wounded Sin flies sickening at the sight. My friends, whose innate worth the wise man's praise And the fool's censure equally betrays, Acoept the humble blessing of my Muse, Nor your assistance to her aim refuse, Shoasksnotnattery, but lether olaim A kind perusal, and a secret name. 1 scarcely like to mention it, as a literary accident, but being a curious and unique anecdote it shall be atated. 1 had the honour at Christ Church of being prizetakèr of Dr. Burton'a theological essay, Thé Re-conciliation of Matthew and John, when Gladstone who had aiso contested it, stood second and when Dr. Burton had me before him to give me the .~25 worth of books, he requested me to allow Mr. Gladstone to have. worth of them, as he waa so good a second. Cer-tainly such an easy concession was one of my earliest literary triumphs. My first acquaintance with Gladstone, whom 1 have known from those college days now for more than five and 6fty years, was a memorable event, and may thus be worthy of mention. It was at that time not a common thing for undergraduates to go to the com-munion at Christchurch Cathedral-that holy célébra-tion being supposed to be for the particular benefit of Dean and Canons, and Masters of Arts. So when two undergraduates went out of the chancel together after communion, which they had both attended, it is small wonder that they addressed each other genially, in defiance of Oxford etiquette, nor that a friendship so well begun has continued to this hour. Not that 1 have always approved of my friend's politics multi-tudes of letters through many years have passed be-tween us, wherein if 1 have sometimes ventured to praise or to blame, 1 have always been answered both gratefully and modestly but 1 have ever tried to hold the balance equally too, according to my lights, and if at one time on occasion of the great Oxford election, 1864 1 published a somewhat famous copy of verses, ending with Il Orator, statesman, soholar, wit, and sage, The Orichton,-more, the Gladstone of the age, my faithfulness must in after years confess to a well-known palinode one of my Three Hundred Sonnets commencing Beware of mere delusive eloquenoe, and a still more caustio lyric, beginning with Glozing tongue whom none oan trust, and so forth, as a caution against a great man's special gift, so proverbiailly dangerous. Some of our most honest Ministers, 6. Althorpe and Wellington, have been very bad speakers some of our most eloquent oratora have proved very bad Ministers. And in this place 1 may introduce some account, long ago in print, of the famous Aristotle class under thé tutorship of Mr. Biscoe at Christ Church, wherein among far nobler and botter scholars your present confessor took the lowest seat. Fifty years ago Biscoe's Aristotle class at Christ Church was comprised almost wholly of men who have since become celebrated, some in a remarkable degree and, as we believe tbat so many namea, afterwards attaining to great distinction,~ have rarely been asso-ciated at one lecture-board, either at Oxford or elae-where, it may be allowed to oné who counts himself the least ond lowest of the company to pen thia brief note of those old Aristotelians. Inkpen was a character, as a self-taught entomologist, breeding in me then thé rabies of colleoting moths and beetles, as a couple of boxes full of such can still prove. He lived at Chelsea, near the Botanical Gardens there and attributed his wonderful finds of étrange insecta in his own pocket-handkerchief garden to tray caterpillars and nies, c., that came his way from among the packets of foreign plants. He used also to catch small fowl on passengers' coats and blank walls, as he passed on his daily walks to his office and back, having pill-boxes in his pocket, and pins inside his hat ao secure the spoil. In the course of years he had amassed butterflies and beetles to so valuable an extent, that when he was compolled by adverse fortune tosell his cabinetaby auction at Stevens's, he netted ~1200 for his collection this he told me in later years .himself immodiately after the sale, ho com-menced collecting anew.-and having been made curator of Lincoln's Inn Fields through Mr. Brodie's interest , he soon found an infinity of new inseots.-derived per-haps û'om thé Surgeon's Hall Muséum, or straying to the nine acres bf that Garden,-is it not the area of Cephren's Pyramid ?-as a -refuge for them out of smoky London. Chess is a chief intellectual resource to.the stammerer for therein he oan conquer in argument without the toil of speech, and prove himself practically more eloquent' than the men full of talk whom he so much envies. Accordingly, in days gone by for of late years 1 have given it up, as too toilsome a récréation 1 played often at that royal game. In these times it is no game at all, -but a wearisome if seductive science just as cricket ia an artillery combat now, and football a most perilous conflict, and boating breaks the athlete's heart, and billiards eau only be played by a bar-spot professional, and tronquil whist itself Las developed into a semi-fraudulent system of open raies and secret signs even so the honest common-sense old game of chess bas come to be so encumbered with pubSsbed openings and gam-bits and other parasitic growths upon the wholesome house-pJant, that 1 for one have renounced it, as a pur-suit for which life is too ahort and serious give me a farce or a story instead , and one moreover in which any fool well up to crammed book games may crow over thé wisest of men in an easy, because stereotyped, check-mate. CHAPTER VII. PRIZE FOBMS, ETC. IN the course of my Oxford career I tried for two New-digate Prize poems, The Suttees and the African Desert, won respectively by Claughton, now Bishop of St. Albans, and Rickards, whose honours of course 1 ought to know, but don't. A good-looking and well-speaking friend of muie, E. H. Abney, now a Canon, was so certain that thé said prizes in those two successive years were to fall to me, that he learnt my poems by heart in order to récite them as my speeoh-substitute in the Sheldonian Theatre at Commémoration, and he used frequently to look in upon me to be coached in his recital. It was rumoured that I came second on both occasions,-ono of them certaioly had a 2 marked on it when returned to me, but 1 know not who placed it there. However, my pièces were afterwards printed both separately, and among my Banads and Poems, by Hall ahd Virtue, and are now before nie. As an impartial and veteran judge of such K~cM~, 1 am bold to say they are far better than I thought, and might fairly hâve won New-digate. prizes, even as friend Abney Co. were sure they would. At the close of my University career came, of course, the Great Go, which I had to do as I did the Little Go, all pu paper for 1 could not auswer ~ wee. And this rule then, whatever maybe thé case now, prevented me from going.in for honours, though 1 had read for a first, and hoped at least to get a second. In fact, some of my oritics hâve heretofore to my disparagoment stumbled on thé printed truth that he ia little betMr than atl improvisa-tore in rhyme. And this word rhyme rominds me now of a very curious question 1 raised some years a~ter my Oxford days in more than one magazine article, as to when rhyme was invented, and by whom the con-clusion being that intoning monks found out how easily the cases of Latin nouns and tenses of verbs, c., jingled with each other, aud that troubadours and trouveres carried thus the seeds of song all over Europe in about the ninth century, until which time rhythm was the only recognised form of versification, rhyme having strangely escaped discovery for more than four thousand years. Is it not a marvel and another marvel that no one noticed it before that not one of the old poets, Hebrew, Greek, Latin, and I think Sanscrit, Arabie, and Celtio too, ever except by manifest accident, now intentionally ignored stumbled upou the good idéa of terminating their metrea with rhyme ? 1 Where is there any ode of Horace, or Anacreon,-wbere any psalm of David, any epigram of Martial, any heroic verse of Virgil, or -philosophie argument of Lucretius,-deco-rated, enlivened, and brightened by the now oniy too frequent ornament of rhyme ? 1 1 have just found among my old archived papers, faded by nearly six decades of antiquity, a treatise which I wrote at nineteen, styled by me Il A Vindication of the Wisdom of Soripture in Matters of Natural Science. This bas never seen the light, even in extraits and probably. never can attain to the dignity of print, seeing 'it is written against all compositor law on both sides up and down of a quarto paper book. Therein are treated, from both the scriptural and the scientific points of view, many subjeota, of which these are some Cos-mogony, miracles in chief Joshua's sun and moon , the circulation of thé blood revealed in Eoolesiastes, mag-netiem as mentioned by Job, He spreadeth out thé north over the empty space and hangeth the world upon nothiug, the blood's innate vita!itiy-which is the life thereof, the earth's centre, or orbit, and inclina-tion, astronomy, spirits, the rainbow, the final con-flagration of our atmosphère to purify the globe, and many other matters terrestrial and celestial. Some day a patient scribe may be found to decipher this decayed manuscript and set out orderly its miscellaneous con-tents. 1 began it at eighteen, and finished it when at Oxford. CARLYLE somewhere gives utterance to a truism, which the present scribe at least can most gratefully counter-sign, that it takes a great deal of providence to bring a man to threescore years and ten. Thé origin thereof was this,-as I now extract it from my earliest literary notebook In August 1838 1 was at Dover, and from a library read for the nrst time Coleridge's Christabel itwas the original edition, before the author's afterward im-provements. Being much taken with the poem, the thought struck me to continue it to a probable issue, espeeially as 1 wanted a leading subject for a new volume of miscellaneous verse. The notion was barren till 1 got to Herne Bay a fortnight after, and then I put peh to paper and nniabed the tale. It occupied me about eight days, an innocent fact which divers dull Zoili have been much offended withal, seeing that Coleridge had thought proper to bring out hia two Parta at a sixteen years' interval a matter doubtiess attributable either to accident or indolence,-for to imagine that he was diligently polishing his verses the whole time as some Mockheads will have it would indeed ba a veriacation ofthejpoM MnM~ monte8 theory. Critiques of course were various, for and against the shuttlecock of fame re-quires connicting battledores .but, as I now again quote from that early notebook, It is amusing to notice, and instructive also to any young author.who may chance to see this, how thoroughly opposite many of the reviews are, some extolling what others vilify it just tends to keep a sensible man of his own opinion, unmoved by such seemingly unreasonable praise or censure. When Coleridge nrst published Christabel intrinsically a most melodious and sweet performance it was positively hooted by the critics see in particular the Edinburgh Review. The author of this book will rank, we are free to say, with the very first spirits of the British world. CHAPTER XIII. A MODERN PYRAMID. IN 183~, Rickerby was again my publisher the new book being A Modern Pyramid to Commemorate a Septuagint of Worthies. In this volume, commencing with Abel, and ending with Felix Ne9,1 hâve greeted both in verse and prose tbreescore and ten of the Exoel-~ lent of the earth. Probably'the best thing in it ia thé Vision Introductory and, as the book has been long out of print, 1 will produce it here as an interesting night of fancy, albeit somewhat of a long one. If an author can be'accounted a fair judge of his own writings, thia.is my best effort in the imaginative line and as it is no new brain-child we always love the last baby best , but was written little short of fifty years ago, the impartial opinion of an old judge is probably a correct one. The sun-dial is still in my garden,-and as 1 stood by it haïf a century since, there grow up to my mind's eye this Vision -1 was walking in my garden at noon and 1 came to the sun-dial, where, shutting my book, I leaned upon the pedestal, musing sothethinshadowpointodtotwelve. 'c Of a sudden, 1 feit a warm s~eet breath upon my cheek, and, starting up, in much wonder beheld a face of the most bowitohing beauty close besido me, gazing on the dial it was only a face and with èarriest fear I leaned, stead stly watching its strange loveliness. Soon, it looked into me with its fascinating eyes, and said mournfully, 'Dost thou not know me?'-but I was speechless with astonishment then it said, Con-sider with that, my mind rushed into me like a flood, and I looked, and considered, and speedily vague outlinos shaped about, mingled with floating gossamers of colour, until I was aware that a glorious living Créature was growing to my knowledge. So I looked resolutely on her for she wore the garb of woman , gazing still as she grew and again she said mildly, 'Considor then I noted that from her jewelled girdie upwards, all was gorgeous, glistening, and most beautifui her white vest was rarely worked with living flowers, but brighter and sweeter than those of earth flowing tresses, blacker than the shadowa cast by the bursting of a meteor, and, like them, brilliantly intorwoven with strings of light, fell.in clusters on her fair bosom her lips were curled with the expression of majestio triumph, yet wreathed winuingly with nickër-ing smiles and the lustre of her terrible eyes, like sans flashing darkness, did bewilder me and blind myreason -'Then I veiled mine eyes with my clasped hands but again she said, Consider '-and bénding all my mind to the hazard, I encountered with calmness their steady radianoe, although they burned into my brain. Round about her sable locks was as it were a chaplet of are ¡ her right hand held a double-edged sword of most atrange workmanship, for the one edge was of keen steel, and the other as- it were the strip of. a peacook's feather on the face of the air about her were phantoma of winged horaoa, and of raoking-wheela and from her. glossy shoulders waved and quivered large.dazzlihg wings of iridescent colours, most glorious to look upon. So grew she slowly to myknowledge and as 1 stood gazing in a rapture, àgain she muttered sterniy,-'Oonsider'-Then 1 looked below.the girdie upon her flowing robes and behold they were of dismal hue, and on the changing surface fluttered fearful visions 1 dis-cerned Mood-spots on them, and ghastly eyes glaring from the darker fbids, and, when these rustled, were heard stifled moanings, and smothered shrieks as of horror and 1 noted that she stood upon a wreath of lightnings, that darted about like a nest of young snakes in the midst of a sullen cloud, black, palpable, and rolling in-wards as thick smoke from a furnace. Then said she again to me, 'Dost thou not know me?'-and 1 answered her.OWonder, terrible in thy beauty, thy fairness hâve 1 seen in dréams, and have guessed with a tremNing spirit that thau walkest among fears are thou notthat dread Power, whom the chiidreu. of men have namëd Imagination?'-And she smiled sweetly upon me aaying, Yéa, my son ' and her smile fell upon my~ heart like the sun on roses, till I grew bold in my love and said, 1 0 Wonder, I would learn of thee show me some strange sight, that I may worship thy fair majésty in secret.' Thon she stood liko a goddess and a queen, and stretohingfbrth her'arm, white as the snow aud glitter-ing with circlots, slowly beokoned with her aword to the points of the diaL .There was a .distant rushing sound, and 1 saw wnite cloads afar off drppping suddenly and together from thé .blue firmament all round me in a oirole and they fell to the earth, and rolled onwards, fearfuDyoonyerging.towhere 1 stood~ and they came on, on, on, like the galloping cavalry of heaven pour-ing in on ail sides as huge cataracts of foam and shutting me out from the green social worid with the awful curtains of the skies.-Then, as myheart was il ing me for iëar, 'and for looking at those inevitable strange onoomings, and the nxt eyes of my queehiike mistresa, I sent reason from his throne on my brow to speak with it calmly, and took courage. That he should at last give way was only probable he waa, iu short, another Adam, and had another II, albeit he wrestled nobly. This word brings me to the' point 1 wish to touch on,-the great compensation winch God gave to Job. Children ean ,never be regarded as other ,than iudividua.Hties, and ïtotwithstanding Eastern feelings about increase in quantity, its quality is, after all, the question for the heart. 1 mean that many children to be born is but an inadequate return for many children dying. If a father loses a well-beloved son, it is small récompense of that aching void that ho gets another. For this reason of the affections, and because 1 suppose that thinkera hâve sympathised with me in the dimoulty, I wish to say a word about Job's children lost and found. It will clear away what ia to some minds a moral and an'ectionate objection. Now this is the state of the case. Thé patriarch is introduced to us as possessing so many camels and oxen, and so forth, and ten children. AU these are represented to him by witnesses, to ail appearance credible, as dead and he mourns for his great loss accordingly. Would not a merchant feel to all intenta and purposes a ruined man, if he received a clear intelligence from different parts of the world at once that all his ships and warehouses had been deatroyed by hurricanes and fire ? 1 Faith given, patience fbilows and the triai is morally the same, whether the news be true or false. Remarkably enough, after the calamitous time is paat, when the good man of Uz is discerned as rewarded by heaven for hia patience by the double of everything once lost-his children remain the same in number, ton. But the scriptural word does not go to say that these things happened but that certain emissaries aaid they happened. 1 think the devil missed hia mark-that the messengers were soared by aome abortive diabolic efforts and that with a natural increase of camels, o., meanwhile the patriarch's paternal heart was more than compensated at the last by the restora-tion of his own dear children. They were dead, and are alive again they were lost, and are found. Like Abraham returning from Mount -Calvary with Isaac, it was the résurrection in a figure. What Mr. Butler says in his préface, no doubt after speech with me, for 1 was his visitor at the time in 1851, is this -AU who have had the good fortune to meet Mr. Tupper during his visit here have been struek with his characteristic impulsiveness. In accordance with this feature of his miud, nearly all of his most successfui performances have been occasioned by something alto-gether incidental and unpremeditated-the result of an impulse acoidentalIy-sbaU we not say, providentially ? 1 -imparted. It was so with the Ërst work in this series four volumes respocting the composition of whichho bas given to me in conversation the following account. Some years ago he purobased a house at Brighton. While laying out the garden, he bad occasion to have several drains made. One day observing a workman, Francis Suter, standing in one of the trenches wet and wearied with toil, Mr. Tupper said to bim in a tone of pleasantry, 'Vouidn't you like to dig up there a orock full of gold?'If I did,' said the man, 'it would do me no good,.because merely nndingit would not make it mine. But suppose you could not only find such a treasure, but might honestly keep it, wouidn't you think yourself lucky -'Oh yes, Bir, I suppose 1 should -but,' after a pnuse, 'but 1 am not so sure, sir, that it is the best thing that could happen to me. 1 think, on the whole, I would rather have steady work and fair wages all the season than find a crock of gold.' Here was wisdom. The remark of the honest trench-digger at once set iu motion a train of thought in the mind of the author. Ho entered his study, wrote in large letters on a sheet of paper these words, THE OBOOK OF GoLD, a Tale of Covetousness,' and in less than a week that remarkable story was written. By the advice of his wife, however, he spent another week in rewriting it, and then gave it to the world in its finished state. In the same Butlerian volume occurs the following MS. notice writton by me in about 1853 respecting the origins of my two other taies, the three being issued together As in the instance of my Crock of Gold,' both 'Thé Twins' and Heart' were undoubtedly the out-come in after years of early observations, anecdotes, and incidents, whereof memory kept in silence an expérimental record. Very few artists succeed in the deliueation of life without living models but no good one servilely will betray the forms they rather get hints from than actuaUy copy. Thug though 1 sketched Roger Acton from ono Robert Tunnel, -an Albury labourer, and took the cottage near Postford Pond as his home,-adding thereto Mr. Campion's park aud houseat Danney, near Hurst I was then living at Brighton as the model for Sir John Vincent'a estate,-as well as Grâce, Bon But'ke, and so on om persons 1 I had soen,-1 need not say that my sketches from nature were but outlines to my Rnished work of art. Simon Jennmgs, however, is an exact portrait of a man 1 knew at Brighton. So aiso with these taies, and others of my writings. About The Twins a curious and somewhat awk-ward coincidence happened, in the fact that my totally ideal characters of Général Tracey and his family were auppoaed to be intended for some persons whom the cap it seems fitted pretty accurately, and who then lived at the southern watering-place 1 had too diaphanously depicted as Burleigh-Singleton. Mr. Martiti Tupper the author is already known to the world by his Proverbial Philo-sophy,' and other works whioh indicate an extraordi-narily gifted mind and an originality of conception and treatment rare indeed in thèse latter days,-but he bas never demonstrated thèse qualities to suoh perfection as in his present deeply interesting work, wherein romance is united to wisdom, and both to practical uttlity. It grew naturally out of the simple circumstance that 1 used daily to ride out alone on one of my horses-more exactly, mares-Miuna and Brenda, and jotted down my cantering -fancies in prose or verse when 1 got home. One curions matter is that my ideal scènes, hâve taken such hold upôn my neighbourhood that streams of touriata come codstantly through Albury to visit Thé Silent Pool and other sites of scenes invented by me, andhavetherebyènriohed our village inn aud thé nymen, as well as givon to us a new sort ôf fame. I quote a few particulars from one of my diaries. This book tended to olear my brain of sundry fancies and pictures, as only the writing of another book could do that. Its seed is truly recorded in the nrst chapter as to the two stonë coffins still in the chancel of, St. Martha's. 1 began the book on November 26, t8~, and finished it in exactly eight weeks, on January 21, 1838, reading for the work included. In two months more it was printed by Hurst Blackett. I intended it for one full volume, but the publishers preferred to issue it in two scant ones it has since been reproduced by Lasham, Guildford, in one vol., at one-and-sixpence it was i4s. 1 consulted and partially read for it as 1 wanted accurate pictures of John's reign in England the histories of Tyrrell, Hollingshed, Hume, Poole, Markland, Thomson's Magna Charta, James's Philip Augustus, Milman's Latin Ohristianity, Hallam's Middie Ages, Maimbourg's Lives of the Popes, Ranke's Life of Innocent III., Maietiand on the Dark Ages, Ritson's Life of Robin Hood, Salmon's, Bray's, and Brayley's Surrey, Tupper's and Duncan's Guernsey, besides the British and National aud other Enoyclopsedias and Diotionarioa as required. It was a work of hard and quick and fervid labour, not an idle pièce of mere brain-spinning, a.nditmaybedopended on for archoeological accuracy in every datail. More than thirty localities in our beautiful oounty Surrey are painted in thé book of other parts of England twelvo ,of Franco and Italy twelve there are more than twenty historical characters honestly as I judge depicted and aome Rfteen idéal ones fairly enough invented as accessories I preferred Stephan to the commoner Stephen, for etymological and archesological reasons it is clearly nearer the Greek, and is spelt so in ancient records. The AngIo-Saxon préface to that volume commences thus AI ed, King, was the translator of this book and from'book-Latin turned it into Old English, as it is now done. Awhile he put word for word awhile sense for sense. He learned this book, and translated it for his own people, and turned it into song, as it is now done. His Old English song, that is, Anglo-Saxon alliteration, is all now modernised in this curious little book of English metres. It was well praised by many critics but at present is out of thé market. When 1 am translated myself, all these old works of mine will rise again in a voluminous complete édition. The Alfred Jubilee, on that great king's thou-sandthyear, 1848, is one of thé exploits of my literary life, undertaken and accomplished by Mr. Evelyn, the brothers Brereton, Dr. Giles, and myself in thé year 1848, ohiefly at Wantage, where Alfred was born. We arranged meetings and banqueta in several places, notably Livorpool, where Mr. Bramwell Moore, the mayor, gave a great feast in commemoration, a medal was struok, thé Jubilee édition of King Alfred's works was at least begun at Dr. Oiles's private printing-press, whilst at Wantage itself 20,000 people ooUeotod om all parts for old English games, speeohes, appropriate sbhgs, such as To-day is the day of a thousand years from my pen, collections for a local school and college as a lasting mémorial, and-to please the commonalty-a gorgeous procession and an ox roasted whole, with gilded horns and ribbons,-the huge carcase turned like a hare on a gigantic spit by help of a steam-engine before a furnace of two tons of blazing coal and that ox waa consumed after a most barbarie Abyssinian iashion in the open air. My Anglo-Saxon Magazine came out strong on the occasion,-but it'is obsolète now and 1 care not to use up space in reprinting patriotic indigna-tion for lot me state that, considered as a national commemoration of the Great King, the chief founder of our liberties, this Wantage jubilee was all bat a failure the British lion slumbered, and it was flogging a dead horse to try to wake him up very iew of the magnates j'eaponded to our appeal but we did our best, neverthe-less, as independent Englishinen, and locally achieved a fairsuccess. TRANSLATIONS AND PAMPHLETS. THE best of my unpublished MSS. of any size or conséquence is perhaps my translation of Book Alpha of the Iliad, quite literal and in its original metre of hexameters hitherto 1 hâve failed to find a publisher kind enough to lose by it for there are already at !east twelve English versions of Homer unread, per-haps unreadable. Still, some day 1 don't despair to gain an enterprising Sosius for my literal and hexa-metrical translation is almost what Carthusians used to call Il a crib, and perhaps some day the School Board or their organ, Mr. Joseph Hughes's Praètical Teacher, may adopt my version. Its origin and history is this Rûding winter evonings in the country wearisome to my homeflock, 1 used to read to thein profusely and dis-cursively. Amongst other books, a literary daughter suggested Popo's Homër whioh, as 1 read, after a little while, 1 found to be so very ee and incorrect a transla-tion if my memory served me rightiy that 1 resolved to see what 1 could do by reading from the original Greek in its own Euglish metre. 1 soon found it quite easy to be both terse and literal and having rhythm o.nly to care for withôut the tag of rhyme, 1 soon pleased my hearers and in some sort myself, reading o6f thé réel direotlyfrom the Greekiuto the English. WHEN î returned in the autumn of 1855 from my prin-cipal continental tour, wherein for three months 1 had conductéd my whole family of eleven servants inclu-sive ail through the usual route of French and Swias travel,-I committed my journal ta Hatchard, who forthwith published it but not to any signal success,-for it was anonymous, whioh was a mistake however, I did not care to make public by name all the daily details of my homéflock pilgrimage. The pretty little, book with its fine print of thé PMa of Gondo as a frontispiece, nevertheless made its way, and bas been inserted in Mr. Gregory's liât of guide-books as a conve-nience if not a necessity to travellers on the same roads, though in these days of little practical use indeed, wherever we stopped, I contrived to exhaust, on the spot all that was to be seen or donc, with the advan-tages of persoual inspection, and therefore of graphie and true description. Thé book has been praised for ita ih-terest and includes divers accidents, happily surmounted, divers exploits in the milder form of Alpine climbing as thé Mauvais Pas, which 1 tou,ch experimentally at the end of Life's Dessous, in Proverbial Philosophy, Séries IV. , divers grand sights, as the Great Exhibition, CHÀPTEB XX close to which we lived for some weeks in the Champs Ëlysëes, and many pleasant incidents, as greetings with friends, old and new, and other usual memorabilia. Among these let me mention the honest kindliness of Courier Pierre,-always called Pere by my children, with whom he was a great favourito-thé more readily because he bas long gone to the bourne whenco no traveller returns, so he needs no recommendation from bis late employer. This, then, 1 say is memorable. At Lucerne, as my remittance from Herries failed to reach me, I seemed obliged to make a stop and to return but Pierre objected, saying it was gréât pity not to pass the Simplon and see Milan,-and, if Monsieur would permit him, he could lend whatever was needful, and could be paid again. Certainly I said this was very kind, and ao 1 borrowed at his solioitation -it was ~100, as 1 find by the journal our travel was costing us ~o a week. 'Wo!l, to recount briefly, when, after having placed in our 'ep6f Mf6 Bellinzona, Como, Milan, c. c., I found myself at Geneva, and with remittances awaiting me, my first act was to place in Pierre's hands ~'t0~and when he counted the notes, he said, Sare, there is one five-pound too many. Of course, my worthy Pierre, 1 hope you will accept that as interost.Non, Monsieur, pardon 1 could not, 1 always bring money to help my families -and he would not. Now, if that was not a model oourier, worthy to be commemorated thus,-well, hope there are soma othera of hia brethren on the omoe-books of Bury Streot, St. James's, who are equallyduteoua and disintorested. Some people are heroes to their valets my worthy help is a hero to me so saithmy journal. Horo'a ànother extraot, after two slight earthquakes at Brieg, and Turtman Turris Magna Again a bad accident. One of our spirited'wheelers got his hind leg over the pole in going down a hill at once there was a chaos of fallen horses and entangled harness, and but for the screw machine drag looking both hind-wheels we must have been upset and smashed,-as it was, the sorambling and kicking at nrst was frightfui but Pater-familias dragged the younger children out into the road, and other help was nigh at hand, and the providential calm that comes over faUen horses after their initiatory struggle was at hand too, and in due time matters were righted that those two fiery stallions did not kick everything 'to pièces, and that all four steeds did not gallop us to destruction, was due, under Providence, to the skill and courage of our good Pierre and the patient MuscateUi.Baiiways have since superseded all this peril, and cost, and care and trains now go through the Simplon, instead of good horses, six to the heavy carriage, four to the light one, pulling us steadily and, slowly over it thus losing the splendid scenery climaxed by the Devil's Bridge but let moderns be thankful. Paterfamilias's Diary bas long been out of print, and its author is glad .that he made at the time a fuU record of thé happy past and recommends its perusal to any one who can find a copy anywhere. My friend, the late Major Hely, who claimed an Irish peerage, was very fond of this Il Diary, and thought it the best book of travels he had ever read. GUERNSEY.
