NEVER GIVE UP, AND SOMB OTHER BALLADS. SuNDBY of my short lyrics have gained a great popu-larity in particular Never give up, whereof there are extant-or were-no fewer than eight musical settings. Of this ballad, three stanzas, 1 have a strange story to tell. When I went to Philadelphia, on my Brat American tour in ï 851, 1 was taken everywhere to see everything amongst others to Dr. Kirkland's vast in-stitute for the insane let me first state that he was not previously told of my coming visit. When 1 went over the various wards of the convalescents, 1 noticed that on each dodr was a printed placard with my Never give up upon it in full. Naturally I thought it was doue so out of compliment. But on inquiry, Dr. Eirk-land didn't know who the author was, aud little suspected it was myself. He had seen the verses, anônymous, in a newspaper, and judging them a good moral dose of hopefulness evon for the half insane, placed thom ou every door to excellent effeot. Whon to his astonish-ment ho found the unknown author bèfore him, greatly pleased, he asked if l would allow the patients, to thank me of course I complied, and soon was surrounded by kneeling and weeping and kisaing folks, grateful for the good hope my verses had helped them to. Aud twenty-CHAPTER XXI. five years after, in 1876,1, again without notice, visited Dr. Kirkland at the same place, scarcely expecting to find him still living, and certainly not thinking that 1 should see my old ballad on the doors. But, when the happy doctor, looking not an hour older, though it waa a quarter of a century, took me round to see his con-valescents, behold.the same words greeted me m large print,~a.nd probably are there still the only change being that my name appears ail foot. 1 gave them a two hours' reading in their handsome theatre, and 1 never had a more intense!y attentive audience than those three hundred lunatics. The ballad runs thus,-if any wish to see it, as for the first time Never give up 1 it is wiser and botter Always to hope than once to despair Flihg off the load of Doubt's heavy fetter And break the dark spell of tyrannical oare Never give up 1 or the burden may aink you,-Providence kindly bas mingled the oup, And, in ail trials or troubles, bethink you Thé watchword of' life' muât be Never give up 1 Never give up 1 there are chances and changes Helping the hopeful a hundred to one, And through the chaos High Wisdom arranges Ever suocoss, if you'11 only hope on Never give upt for the wisest is boldest, Knowing that Providence mingles the oup, And of ail maxime the béat as the oldest Is the true watohword of Never give up 1 Never give up though the grapeshot may rattle Or the full thunderbolt over you burst, Stand like a rook,-and the storm or the battle Little shall harm you, though doing their worst I can quite feel what a moral tonio and spiritual stimulant thèse sentiments would be to many among the thousand patients under Dr. Kirkland's care. 1 recollect also now, that once when 1 read at Weston-super-Mare, witli Lord Cavan in the chair, a military man among the audience, on hearing me recite Never give up, came forward and shook hands, showing me out of his pocket-book a soiled newspaper cutting of the poem without my name, saying that it had cheered him all through the Orimea, and that he had aiways wished to find out the author. Of course we coalesoed right heartily. Some other suoh anecdotes might bo added, but this is enough. Perhaps the best of them is one for which Bishop Samuel Wil-berforce wrote to thank me cordially for a real Chris-tian hymn with thé true ring in it. There are, or were, many musical sottings thereof, the best being one of a German composer. It may count as one of my heresies in an orthodox theological sensé, but I certainly cling to the great idea of Eternal Hope and, after any amount of retributive punishment for purifying thé loat soul, 1 look for ultimate salvation to all God's creatures. This short and partial trial-soene of ours is not enough to make an end with we begin here and progress for ever else-where. Evil must die out, and good must survive alone for ever. In reply to some excellent members of the Romish Church, who have publicly accused me of maligning holy women and sacred retreats, my obvious answer is that 1 contend against thé ovil side both of nunneries and monkeries, whilst 1 may fairly admit some good to be found in both. My real protest is for liberty both to mind and body, and against coercion of any kind, material or spiritual. Given perfect freedom, 1 would not meddle with any one's honest convictions to a nunnery go if thou wilt only let the resolve be revocable, not a doom for over. In particular, the Roman discoveries at Farley Heath in the neighbourhood of Albury wore mainly due to my juvénile antiquarianism, when as a student along with Harold Browne now Bishop of Winchester we used to soarch for coins there, and found one happy day a GaIIienus ail which 1 recorded years after in a now scarce booklet, Farley Heath, and its Roman Remains, p.ublisbed, with illustrations, by Andrews, 'Guildford. Ultimately the nnds of coin from Nero to Honoriua , some being rare and nuoly patinated, as wéll as several small bronzes, and old British money, were given by Mr. Drummond who as lord of thé manor employed labourers in the searoh for many months to the British Muséum, where they fill a niche near thé prehistorio room. Some of our nnds were very ourious, e. we were digging in the blick mould of the burrit o buts round thé wall-foundation.3 all above ground of said hectagonal wall having since been ruthlessiy utilised by parochial economists in making a road across the heath , and found amongst other spoil a little green bronze ring,-whieh 1 placed on the finger of our guest of the day, Mrs. Barclay of Bury Hill oddly enough it had six angles exactly like one of gold she wore as her wedding-guard. Again we had picked up some pieces of pottery decorated with human ncger-tips,-just as, modern cooks do with pie-crust a son of mine said, perhaps we shall find a dog's foot on some tile,-and just as he said it, up came from the spàde precisely what he was guessing at, the large foot-print of dog or wolf stamped fifteen centuries ago on the unbaked clay. Again I was leaving for an hour a labourer in whose industry and honesty I had not the fullest faith. So in order to employ him in my absence, I set him to dig up an old thorn bush and told him to give me when I returned the piece of money he would find under it. To my concealed but his own manifest aetonishment, he gave me when I came back a worn large brasa of Nero, saying with a scared face, How-ever could you teU it was there, sir 1 looked wis.e, and said'nothing. Among the rarest copper coins was one ofCarausius our English Carew , with two heads on it symbolling thé ambition of our native usurper to assert em-pire over East as well as West, and among more treasure-trove was a unique gold coin of Veric,-thé Berious of Taoitus as also the rare contents of a sub, terranean potter's oven, preserved to our day, and yield-ing several whole vases. Mr. Akerman of numismatic, fame told methat out of Rome itself he did not know a richér site for old-world curiosities than Farley in the course of years we found more than 1200 coins, besides Samian ware, and plenty of common pottery, as well as bronze ornaments, enamelled nbulse, weapons of war, household implements, c., both of the old British and the Roman, the AngJo-Saxon, and more recent periods Farley haviugbeen a preetorian station on the Ikenild highway. This is quite a relevant episode of my literary antiquariana. As also is another respecting My Mummy Wheat, a record of which found its way into print and made a stir many years ago. AuTHORSHiP reaps honour in these latter days quite as much as it did in the classic times of Augustns with Virgil and Horace for his intimates, and of Petrarch crowned at the Capitol laureate of all Italy during thé vacancy of a popedom in the Vatican. Not but that, with or without any titular distinction, authorship is practically the most noticeable rank amongst us. Many will pass by a duke who would have stopped and waited to have looked at a Darwin when he was in this lower sphère and I am quite sure that the grand présence of Alfred Tennyson would attract more affectionate hom-age than that of any other ennobled magnate in the land. As to his title, I was glad that his good taste and wisdom elected to be called by his own honourable patronymic rather than haply Farringford or Hazlemere how can great names consent to be eclipsed in such obscure signatures as Wantage or Esher, Hindlip or Glossop, Dalling or Grhnsthorpo ? One geta quite at a loss to know who's who. My letter to the Times of December 10, !883, headed Literary Honours, in praise of Tennyson's elevation to the House of Lords, and showing how in every age all nations except our own have given honours to authors, literally from China to Peru, elioited plenty both of approval and of censure from journal of many denominations. As a matter inévitable when Baron Tennyson was gazëtted, the less euphonious Tupper was stigmatised in the papers as desiring to be a Baron too, -at all events, the Echo said so, and the Globe good-humouredly observed that he deserved thé coronet. They little knew that in the summer of 1863 as para-graphs in my tenth volume of Archives are now before me to show the same derided scribe was seri-ously announced as about to be raised to thé peer-age ail over England and America see two available and respectable proofs in the British Controversialist Hpulston Wright for July 1863, p. 79,-and Bry-ant's Evening Post for September 17, 1863. I name these, as the reverse of comio papers,-and publishing what they supposed true, as in fact was told me by the editors when inquired of. At the time I repudiated the false rumour openly~-with all the greater readiness, inasmuch as 1 dispute both thé justice of hereditary honour and thé wisdom of hereditary législation to say less of thé angusta e~oMt which, in our Mam-monite time and clime, obliges money to support rank, oven if, as in sundry late cases of raising to thé peerage, it does not purchase it. It is fair also to state as a iaot, that when. my father for thé second time refused hie baronetcy, I, as eldest son, gave thé oasting vote against myself, not to im-poverish my four younger brothers.-all now gone before me to the botter world,-and that, for reasons 'mentioned above, I certainly could,not take it nov. Let this sumoe as myreply'tosome recent sneers and strictures. As for letters of the alphabet attached to one's name, almost any one nowadays may have any amount of them by paying fées or subsoriptions in partioular, America has given me many honorary diplomas. And for the matter'of gold medals, who can'covet them, when oven the creators of baking-powder and sewing-machines are surfeited therewith. My poor Prussian medal looks small in comparison. And then, as for knighthood, that ancient honour bas been lately so abused that vanity itself could scarcely desire it, and even modesty now might hesitate in its acceptance. INVENTIONS. It may be worth a page if I record here sundry inventions of mine, surely bits of authorship, which 1 found out for myself but did'not patent, though others did. As thus i. A simple and cheap safety horse-shoe.-seoured by steel studs inserted'into thé prdinary soft iron shoes. 2. GJasssorew-topstobottIes. 3~ Steam-vessels with the wheels inside in faet, a double boat or catamaran, with the maohinery amid-ahips. 4. The introduction of coca-leaf to allay hunger, and to be as useful hère as in Chili. 5. A pen to carry its own ink. 6. The colouring of photographs on the back. 7. Combined vulcanite and steel sheathing. There were also some other small matters wherein authorial energybusied itself. But althougb 1 had models made of some, and wrote about others, no good re-sults accrued to me. i. As for the hbrse-shoes, black-smiths did not want to lose custom by steel' saving the iron. 2. For the glass-stoppers, I had against me all the cork trade, and the wine-merchants too, who recork old wines. 3. The steamers were never tried on a large scale, and models are pronounced deceptive. Thé coca loses most of its virtues when in a dried state. 5. The pen I had it made in silver, long hollow handie ending with a conical point either grew clogged if the ink was too thick, or emitted blots' when too thin. 6. Au establishment. in Leicester Square bas since .8 worked on this idea. 7. 1 also troubled the Ordnance ,Office, and had an interview with Sidney Herbert about two more futile inventions one a composite cannon missile of quoits tied tôgether another of a thick vul-canite sheathing for ships, over eithér wôod or iron.' I have letters on these to and from the office. Briefly, I did not gain fortune as an inventor though I urged my horse-shoe at least as a valuable thought, and one worth a trial, to save our poor horses on asphalte pave-ments and in hard frosts. It is a losing game to attempt to force an invention so many vestod interests oppose, and ao many are the oompetttors moreo ver, some oné always rushes into the pool' of Bethesda before you. I thought also that there might as well be essenoe of tea, as well as of coSee but nothing came of it. Also amongst other of my addled egga of invention, 1 may mention that in my chemistry days as a youth 1 suggested to a scientific neighbour, Dr. Eerrison, that g ass might be rendered lésa fragile by being mixed in the casting with some chemical compound of lead,-much as now has come out in the patent toughened glass. Also we initiated mild experiments about an imitation of volcanic forces in melting pounded stone into moulds,-as recently done by Mr. Lindsay Bucknall with slag -but unluckily we found that the manufac-ture of basait was beyond our small furnace power 1 fancied that apparently carved pinnacles and gurgoyles might be cast in stone and though beyond Dr. Kerrison and.myself, perhaps it may still be done by the hot-blast melting up crushed granite. Among these small matters of an author's natural inventiveness, I will preserve here a few of the literary class 6.g., i. I claim to hâve diseovered the etymology 'of Punch, which Mark Antony Lower in his Patrony-mica says is a name the origin of which is in total obscurity. Now, I found it out thus,-when at Haver-fordwest in 1858 1 saw over.the maritel of the hosteiry, perhaps there still, a map of thé Roman earthwork called loeally Punch Castio and considering how that the neighbouring hills are named Preoelly Procella, storm as often drawing down the rain-clouds.-that Caer Léon is Oastrum Legionis, and that there is a Roman bridge over the little river thoro still styled Ultra Pontem-I decided at once that Pontii OasteUum was thé true name for Punch Castle. Of course, Pontius Pilate and Judas appear in the modioval puppet-plays as Punch and Judy,-while Toby refers to Tobit's dog, in a happy confusion of names and dates. The Pontius of the Castle was Proetor of the Second Legion. 2. Similarly, I found out the origin of Humpty Dumpty sat on a wall, c., to refer to the death of William the Conqueror Z'AoMMe qui d!oKtp e , who was ruptured in leaping a burnt wall at Rouen being very stout,lie had a great fall, and burst asunder like Iscariot, while ail thé king's horses and ail the king's men couldn't set Humpty Dumpty up agaiu. We must remember that the wise Fools of those days dared not call magnates by their real names,-nor utter facts openly so accordingly 3 they turned Edward Long-shauks into Daddy Longlegs,and ~ sang about King John's raid upon the monks, and the consequent famine to the poor, in Four and twenty blaokbirds baked in a pie, o.thé key to this interpretation being a dainty dish to set before the king, John being a notorious glutton. My friends at Ledbury Manor, where there is a gallery full of my uncle Arthur's Indian pictures, will remember how 1 expounded all this to them some years ago. NOTE.-The value of the Greek letters, as numéros, in'thé two words above, is as follows -The three kappas 6o the three omiorons 2io, thé three iotas 30, thé two pis i6o, the one sigma 20 , the one epsilon 5, and the one alpha i. in all exaotiy making 666. CHAPTER XXVII. F.R.S. As I have now been more than forty years a Fellow, 1 ought to be ashamed to confess that 1 never contri-buted a Paper to its learned Proceedings all of which as they corne to me 1 give appropriately enough to the famous Wotton Library, belonging to my excellent friend Evelyn, heir and successor to the celebrated John Evelyn of the Sylva, one of the Society's founders. That 1 have seldom even read them is also a pitiful truth for the mysterious nomenclature of modern chemistry, the incomprehensibility to my ignorance of the higher mathematics, the hopeless profundity of treatises on the tides, dynamics, electricity, and micro-scopic anatomicals, are, 1 am free to avow, worse to me than heathen Greek, nay for I can in some sort tackle that , more difficult than the clay tablets of Assyria or a papyrus of Rameses II. So I must confess to being an idle drone among the working bees. Only thrice have I ventured to ask questions oC conséquence, scarcely yet answered by thé pundits. One regards Spectrum Analysis How can we be sure that the lines indicative of gases and other elements are not mainly due to the emanations from our own globe, swathed as it is by more than forty miles of an atmosphere imprognated by ita own salts and aoids in aerial solution? May we not be deducing false con-clusions as to the varying lights of stars and nobuloe, if all the while to our vision they are as it were olouded by our own smoke ? 1 Telescopes have to pierce so thick a stratum of earth's aura and ether that it is expootable they would show us only our own composites in those of other worlds. The spectra are varied, 1 know, but so may bo our wrappings of atmosphere from one night to another. Let this ignorant query sumoo about Dr. Huggins' gréât discovery. Again, I certainly after some knowledge of strange facts could have wished that Mr. Crookes's philoso-phical spiritualism had met with a more patient hear-ing than Dr. Carpenter or Mr. Huxley offered at the time and that Faraday's clumsy mechanical refutation of table-turning had not been considered so conclusive. For there really are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, c., than even your omniscience is aware of and without pinning faith on Madame Blavatsky, or Mr. Hume, or any other wonder-worker from America or Thibet, there doubtless are petty miracles in what is called spiritualism possibly some form of electricity that demand more serutinythan our materialists will hâve the patience to vouchsafe I for one believe in human testimony even as to the miraculous. For a third and last inquiry justly indignant at the horrors of Continental vivisection, and especially in our own humane England at Dr. Ferrier's red-hot wires thrust into live monkeys' brains, I have ôften vainly asked cui bono such terrible cruelty? 1 The highest authorities are at variance with each other as to the practioal utility in human therapeutice of experiments upon agonised brutes but all must be agreed that, so far as morals are concerned, vivisection only hardens the heart and sears the feelings and conscience of doc-tors who may surround thë dying- bod of our dearest, and very possibly make capital of peculiar symptoms in their patient, by experiments transferred from dogs and rabbita to himself 1 Single votes are useless against the annual list of seleoted candidates, or I for one would have at ail inconvenience testified both at Oxford. and in the Royal Society against the eleotion of a certain Professor whose glory lies in vivisection. For an appropriate end to these discursive sentences, let me add this pootic morsel in my own vein. Mr. Butler of Philadelphia was quite right in his judgment of my indoles I write by impulse on occasion. CHAPTER XXVIII. PERSONATION. IT bas several times happened to me, as doubtless to others of my brethren, to find that 1 have been person-ated, certainly to my considerable discredit. Take these instances. When at Brighton, a fellow bad the effron-tery to collect money in my name, and I suppose he somewhat resembled me, as 1 heard more than once that I had been seen here and there, where 1 undoubtedly was not, and proved an alibi. At Bignor, where 1 went to see some Roman pavements on the property of a Sussex yeoman of my name very possibly a German cousin the owner reoeived me with more than suspicion when I said who 1 Was,-because thé true Martin Tupper had been his gùest for a week, and brought him a book he had written, and one of mine then was lying on the table t But 1 soon made it clear that he had been deceived, and that the real Simon Pure was now before him. Divers other cases might be mentioned however, perhaps the most ourious is this, and I extract the whole statement from ohe of my scrap-bopks now before me. It is headed An anecdote to account for certain slanders,thé date beingAugust 1865!-1 I have heard it seriously asserted of me that I am a great pugilist 1 and very far in conduot and manners from what one might expeot, and so forth. Now it bas just come to my knowledge that a sporting publican and dog-fancier who called his publio-house in the Waterloo Road Thé Groyhound my créât , and has my name over the lintel, has claimed to be the author, and is supposed to be myself 1 Mr. Payne my publisher told me about the pugilist,' and said he had heard it in the clubs that 1 was a match for Sayera,-as I conclude my sporting namesake is. In America, too, 1 found that my double lived at Hardwick, Worcester Co., N.Y., and that another Martin hailed from Buffalo. So, like poor Edgar Poe, who had to suffer from the machinations of a profligate brother, who gave Edgar's name whenever he got into a scrape, 1 may have sometimes been credited with the sins of atrangers. No one is free from this sort ofcalumny. We all have heard of Sheridan's wicked witticism, in that when taken up in Pall Mali for drunkenness, he gave his name Wilberforoo and it is said that he got drunk on purpose to say so 1 My venerable friend, Thomas Cooper, the pious and eloquent old Chartist, has been similarly confused with Robert Cooper, the atheist, lecturer not but that Thomas had once been an atheist too. In this connection, here is a curiousiy compli-cated caae of alibi, which 1 abstract verbatim from one of -my Archive-booka. On Sunday, thé lyth of September 1848,1 was a!l the afternoon and evening at myhouseon Furze Hill, Brighton, qmetly reading and teaching my children, o. Next day thé 'Rov. J. 0. Biohmond an American friend called with me on thé Rev. Mr. Vaughan, and in the course of conversation the latter said to me in a good-natured tone of rebuke 'Somo ofmy congrégation tell me they saw you yesterday afternoon smoking a cigar in a fly on the Marine Parade.' 1 had hardiy time to deny the soft impeachment, which I might well have done with emphasis, as a loather of cigars, and as little as possible a traveller on Sundays, when Richmond broke out with That's impossible for I saw him myself in Shoreham Church five miles distant , and noticed that he went away in the middle of the sermon, as 1 supposed, to get home to Mrs. Tupper.' Mr. Richmond says he could have made oath that 1 had been there, and that he told several persons after church that I had heard part of the sermon in the afternoon.' So, upon human and trustworthy evidence, 1 could have been proved to have been in three places at once. My fetch similarly once rescued a young lady from death on Snowdon at least a stranger in company once came up to me, to thank me for my prowess in having stopped his daughter'a pony, which had run away down. the mountain t-in vain I denied it -and he addressed me by my name, too 1 Somebody muât have given him my card by accident. And let me here allude if can without indelicacy tci another sort of personation of more financial impor-tance to myself. Lately, I.have seen some not very refined nor considerate paragraphs in American papers Mr. Bok.'a a Brooklyn editor, has told me that more than four hundred repeated them to thé eneot that in the battle of life 1 had-truly enough-sun'ered reverses, and needed material help from my many professing friands. The annoyance in my own mind, and in the suspicion of some others round me, is the awkward fancy that sundry small collections may have been intercepted. Possibly some other Martin Tupper bas the spoil. Another sort of dishonest personation whereto we are aU liable, whether authora or not, is the having imputed to us divers forged or garbled sentiments, even in the immutability of print, I have now before me a Boston copy of my first Proverbial published by one Joseph Dowe in 1840, which, though stated to be from the London edition, designedly omits all allusion to the Trinity, even my whole essay thereon, for Mr. Dowe as a Unitarian chose to make me one t AIso, 1 have seen my name attached to verses I never wrote, and have been claimed both by Swedenborgians and Freemasons as a brother, while Jesuitry bas otherwise traduced me. Artists also as well as authors are similarly misrepre-sentod my son-in-law, Clayton Adams, for instance, tells me that his name bas been added to Jandscapes he never painted, and that they sold by auction at high prices. Modern aociety should punish such cheateries severely. CHAPTER XXIX. HOSPITAMTIBS-FARNBAM, ETC. IN such a record of personals as this, it is fortunate both for the author and his readers if he bas never been one of those literary lions who are merely histrionic crea-tures of society. It is a privilege not to have to repro-duce the common small-talk of ball-rooms and garden-parties, nor to be obliged to make the most, after a semi-libellous fashion, of after-dinner scandais, or gossip in the smoking-room. Not having heard them ho oannot well report raoy anecdotes, whereof sundrymemoirs have been too full. In the happier condition of à partial anchoritism 1 have escaped clubs, London seasons, and country mansion gaieties as a youth and to middle manhood a stammerer, 1 would not willingly court the humiliations of chattering society, and thereafter, up to to-day, a domestio country gentleman of literary pur-suits, 1 haye avoided as far as possible fashionable gatherings of every sort, social, theological, or politioal. And here is an Alburian anecdote which may amuse, as 'illustrative of the mental calibre of some of those myriads of untutored rustics whom our partisan gover-nors have made politically equal with the wisest in thé land. Three young friends came to spend a day with us, and for fun brought in their pockets the absurd noses popular at Epsom races. We came upon some turf-diggers, and my visitors mounted their masks to mystifythem. The clodpoles looked scared and very quiet, till 1 went up to one of them who knew me,-of course I was in my natural physiognomy,-and I said to him, My friend, these are foreigners and thé poor ignoramus staring at those portentous noses said séri-ously, Ees, 1 sees they be. Amongst other specialities of ancient Albury House, which bas 1661 on a weathercock and 1701 on à kitchen wing, is the same peculiarity which Tennyson told me, at Farringford vexes him in his own less ancient dwell-ing,-and which Pindar of old declared to be thé privi-lege of poets. We are, and have been for générations, a very house-hive of'bees the whole front of two gables bas them under ita oak floors and panelled walls throughout,-and when guests sleep in certain rooms they have to be forewarned that the groans at midnight are not those of perturbed spirits, but the hum and buatle of multitudinous bées. We oannot drive them away, nor destroy them utterly.-as often has been attempted and if we did, the worry would be only wor-sened, as in that case hornets would corne and succeed to the sweet heritage of bee-dom. When the stuccoed on ! of our house was demolished, to show the oaken pattern but it had to be re-roughcast to keep out the weather , there were pailsful of honey carried off by the labourers, of course not without wounds and strife but in ordinary times it is a strange fact that our bées never sting their hosts be oarefui only to remain quiet, and there is no war between man and bee. Two years ago a great comb was built outside an eaveboard, pro-bably because there was no room for more comb inside. It is curious that it should hâve survived two hard winters. Long after all had gone to bed, we heard with trepidation stealthy stops crunching the snow round the house, and aoHM~MMjf that now and then touohod the ground-floor doors and windows, as if quietly trying to get in - at last fumbled at the ancient hanging handle of the outside kitchen-door 1 Now was the time for Paterfamilias to show his pluck, in the universal scare so, armed cap-a-pied, with candies held in the rear by the terrified household, he valor-ously drew the bolts and flung open the heavy oaken door,-to greet-his childrén's donkey, escaped some-how from its stable, and trying to get indoors that cold night for warmth. Laugh as we might, and as you may, the test of courage was all thé same and if this donkey story is pounced upon by some critic or comic as a weak link in my chain of autobiography, I only. hope he will behavo as bravely if a real ruffian tries his doors and windows by night by no moans an. improbable hypothesis in 'these days of communistio radicatism. The old house itself may deserve a word. It came to me as a-shall 1 say 7-matrimony, from my mother if patrimony means from a father, why not matrimony from a mother, hergreat-uncle, Anthony Devis, having bought it in 1780. He was a remarkable man in his way and before his age a good landscape painter. as Pilkington avouches , a collector of pictures and curio'-sities,-mostly sold by exeoutors at his death, aged eiglity-niiie, though a full gallery romains at Albury a. carver too, and a constructor of cabinets,whereof two Rue spécimens inlaid with brecoiated jaspers,.and made of ebony and cedar from his own turning-Iathe decorate our large drawing-room and the oldest folk in our village still remember the good old gentleman who always had gingerbread in his pockets for them as children, and who was known by them as the man mushroom, seeing he was the nrst who ever had an umbrella in the place 1 There was, however, another and a better reason for this name, inasmuch as he built for himself an outer painting-room on a hilltop near which ho called Mushroom Hall, because it was just like one as a picture in our drawing-room testifies , being a circular turret surmounted by a Bat broad dome, with overshadowing eaves all round. This strange summer-house has long vanished. Anthony came of a good old stock paternally, as the civic archives of Preston, in Lancashire, testify ,and his mother was Ann Blackburne, of Marrick Abbey, York-shire,the title-deeds whereof, old slip parchments and maps from Henry II. to Henry VIII., 1 found in a chest at Albury, and years after transmitted them to Lord Beaumont, the present owner albeit, as a boy, I had been allowed to cut off thé seals and paste them in a oopy-book 1 AU these deeds, and the history thereof, I had printed in Nichols's Antiquariana. Thé main social interest of my two visits consisted in the contrast shown between the one in 1851 and that in 1876, just a quarter of a century after between in fact CHAPTER XXXII. AMERIOAN VISITS. the extreme drinking habits of one generation and the extreme temperance of another mainly due, amongst other causes, to the overflowing prosperities of the middle of this century and the comparative adversities of its declining years. Jeshurun once waxed fat, and kicked, -but since then he bas become one of the lean kine wines and spirits were formerly in abundance as well as bard.dollars, but hâve now been replaced by the cheaper water and discredited paper. Moreover, such shrewd and caustic writers as the Trollopes and Dixon and Charles Dickens have done great good service to their sensible and. sensitive American brothers,-who, far from resenting strictures which for the moment stung, took the best advantage of their utterance in self-improvement. My first visit was hospitably redolent of -all manner of seductive drinks,-wherein, however, 1 was as they thought too temperate my second was as hospitably plentiful so far as eating went, but iced water wherein I was temperate too appeared solitarily for the universal beverage though even in the most teetotal homes this English guest was always generously allowed his port or Madeira or even his whisky if he wished it. Tempérance was a fashion, a~'Ofe, on my second visit, as its opposite had been on my first and on each occasion, 1 persisted in a middle course, the golden mean,which 1 know to be proverbially a wisdom though not at present universally so accepted. It is hopeless for me to look through the multi-tudinous large quarto pages of mynrst diaryand its letters, commenta, paragraphs, o. they are only too full of compliments and kindnesses from friends in many instances passed away and I will simply record two or three of the more public hospitalitios whioh greeteâ. me. Oné of these was a grand dinner with the Maryland Historical Society at Baltimore, May i~, 1851, my late friend Mr. Kennedy in the chair as president, while Sir Henry Bulwer and myself supported him right and left, some hundreds of other guests also being présent. Of course all was very well done, luxuriously and magni-ficently but perhaps the best thing I can do if my reader's patience and my present tired penmanship wiU approve it is to extract from a newspaper, the Baltimore C pe~ of the above date, a précis of my speech on the occasion. Some distinguished gentleman having proposed my health, This brought to his feet Mr. Tupper, who, having expressed his thanks in an appropriate manner, and acknowledged his superior gratitude to the Author of all good, alluded to that international loving-kindness whioh he aYowed to be one main errand of his life and he very happily brought in Horace's prophetical description of England and America in their relation of mother and child, 0 matre pulohrâ filia pulchrior.' He followed by relating some striking incidents of the good feeling which per-vades the old country in favour of her illustrious on-spring. One we cannot fail to give was that thé Royal Naval School at Greenwich had inserted his well-known' ballad 'To Brother Jonathan' in a collection published for the use of the Royal Navy. The speaker thën paid an eloquent compliment to the literature of Amerioa-her poets, statesmen, historians, and divines. Ho re-joiced that Insular Amerioa and Continental England' were so intimately and inseparably intermingled in thé authorial productions of the hùman mind, as well as bound together by the strongest ties of nature and reli-gion, of lineage, laws, and language. Adverting tb thé wise piety of such associations as the one before him, he exhorted to keep together the records of the past, that they may sanctify the present and be an encourage-ment to good and a warning against evil for the future. He commented severely upon the vandal act of thé British troops under General Ross in burning thé national archives at Washington. In this connection he introduced the beautiful lines from Milton Lift not thy spear against the Muse's bower The great Emathian conqueror bid spare Thé house of Pindarus, when temple and tower Went to the ground.' In conclusion, Mr. Tupper related an interesting fact, which in his mind suggested what should be to Americaus a pleasing idea-possibly a discovery-as to the origin of the national flag. On making a pilgrimage just lately to Mount Vernon, he was forcibly struck by the circum-stance that the ancient family coat-of-arms of the illustrious Washington consisted of three stars in the upper portion of the shield, and three stripes below the crest represented an eagle's head, and the motto was singularly appropriate to American history, Exitus aota probat.' Mr. Tuppor said he could not but con-sider this a most interesting coincidence. He thougbt the world might well oongratulate America upon being thé Geographical Apotheosis of that gréât unspotted character, who, while he yet lived, was proapectively her typical impersonation. 'Another memorable event was a grand dinner given to Washington Irving and myself, as chief guests amongst others, by Prince Astor at his palatial residence in New York. As for the profusion of gold plate, glittering glass, innumerable yellow wax.caadios in ormolu chandeliers, and général exhibition of splendid aud luxurious extravagance, and all manner of costly wines and rarest gourmandise, I never have seen its like before or since and more than this if I may state the fact without much imputation of vaingloriousness , the intellectual treat was, to my OMMOMr jp?'op 'g at least, of a still more exquisite character, when our host pro-tested to his company in a generous and genial speech -that, if he could make the exchange, he would give ail his wealth for half the literary glory of Washington Irving and 'Martin Tupper 1 We whispered to each other we heartily wished he could. I strangely missed visiting Irving at his own home, though urgently in-vited to it but somehow other pressing engagements hindered, and so it was not to be. On the same day with the Astorian dinner, Mr. Davis, a man of high social position, had urged me to dine with him, but 1 could not come as engaged till the evening. Now he, a local poet himself, had asked me in divers stanzas of fair rhyme and so, not willing either to beat him in versification or to let him beat me, 1 made this epigrammatic reply in dog-Latin, whioh was taken to be rather 'cute Certes, arnica Davis, Ibo quoounque mavis, Sed princeps Astor primo Me rapuit ad prandium Oum me relinquit, imo In me videbis handyum. My first acquaintance with N. P. Willis arose in this way. He had as I have mentioned before beon in the habit of quoting month after month in his own paper passages from my Proverbial Philosophy, believing that book to be an obscure survival of the Shakespearean era, and that its author Lad been dead some three cen-turies. When he came to town, 1 called upon him at his lodging near Golden Square, walking in plainly MMM tambour et trompette, but simply announcing the then young-looking author as his old Proverbialist t 1 never saw a man look so astonished in my life he turned pale, and vowed that he wouldn't believe that this youth could be his long-departed prophet how-ever, 1 soon convinced him that I was myself, and carried him off to dine in Burlington Street. After-wards we improved into a friendship till he went the way of all nesh in Heaven's good time. Perhaps another notable matter to record is that Presi-dent FiIImore invited me to meet his Cabinet at dinner in the White House, and that 1 there met and conversed im-mensely with Daniel Webster, a colossal unhappy beetle-browed dark-angel-looking sort of man, with a depth for good and ovil in his eye unfathomable also with Home Secretary Corwen, a coarse but clever man, who had been a waggon-driver and with Graham, Secrotary of the Navy, and with Conrad, Secretary at War, both gentle-men and having lofty foreheads and with many more, includmg above all thé excellent President, o. c. Barnum hunted me out from the two or three acres of faces,-because the fair and melodious Jenny had expressed to him an urgent wish to see me. When I got to her boudoir, where Barnum introduced me, 1 really thought she would have cried outright,-as feel-ihg herself a stranger in a foreign land, and in the pre-sence of an old unseen book-friend for it seems,-as she told me in beautiful slightly broken English,-that my poor dear Proverbial Philosophy,which 1 never thought she had seen till 1 gave it to her,-bas been to her 'such a comfort, such a comfort, many days ' and she was 'so glad, so ver glad,' to see me, and she looked so unhappy,-though the immense hall was still echoing with those tumults of applause,-and she clasped my hand so often, and would hardly let it go, and made me sit and talk with her, for 1 was her friend,' and really seemed like a child clinging to its elder brother. 1 was quite sorry to leave her,-and wheu, putting aside all idle musical compliments, 1 tried to cheer her by the thought,-how nobly and generously for many good purposes she was using the melodious gift of God to her, poor Jenny on!y looked up devoutly, and shook her head, and sighed, and seemed unhappy. However, it was time to go, so with another hearty shake-hands, and 'my love to dear England,' Jenny Lind and 1 took leave. This testimony as to my book's good use for comfort,-sho will read more now she sees me, is very pleasing,-it ia much to do poor Jeuny good, who does good to so many others. 1 think l've for-gotten to say that great old Webster, the Secretary of State, avows that lie always after hard work re eshes his mind' with that book and-I might fill volumes with the same sort of thing. God has blessed my writ-ings to millions of the human race 1 And from prince to peasant good has been done through this hand, in-calculable.-God alone be praised. The world bas misjudged you, mistrusted, maligned you, And should be quick to make honest amends Let me then speak of you just as I find you, Humbly and heartily, cousins and friends 1 Let us remember your wrongs and your trials, Slander'd and plunder'd and crush'd to the dust, Draining adversity's bitterest vials, Patient in courage and etrong in good trust. Yes, it is slander to say you oppressed them i Does a man squander the prioo of hia pelf 1 Was it not often that he who possessod them Eather was ownedbyhis servante Mmseift 1 Caring for all, as in health so in sicknesses, He was their father, their patriaroh chief Age's infirmities, infanoy's weaknesses Leaning on him for repose and relief. When you went forth in your pluck and your bravery, Selling for freedom both fortunes and lives, Where was that prophesied outburst of slavery Wreaking revenge on your ohiidren and vives ? 1 Nowhere t you left all to servile safe keeping, And this was faithful and true to your trust i Master and servant thus mutually reaping Double reward of the good and the just t Generous Southerners 1 who address you Shared with too many belief in your sins But 1 reoant it,-thus, let nie confess you, Knowledge is viotor and every way wins For 1 have seen, 1 have heard, and am sure of it, You have been slandored and suffering long, Paying ail Slavery's cost, and the cure of it,-And the gréât world shall repent of its wrong. I need not say what a riot that honest bit of verse raised among the enthusiasts on both sides. One day when casually dipping into Addison's Spectator at Albury, I made the following discovery which I recorded in the newspapers at the time, and give the extract now fully as thus In thé a~ist No. of Addison's ~pec~o?', bearing date Thursday, December 6th, 1711, and as signed fi C. one of the letters of the mystié OEio , by the great Joseph Addison himself, oecurs the following remarkable anticipation of our presumably most modern diacoyery. Those who have access to the London edition of the Spectator of i8~.f, published by J. J. Chidiey, 123 Aldersgate Street, can verify the verbatim faithfulness of thé following extract from page 274 Strada, in one of his Prolusions Lib. II. prol. 6 , gives an account of a chimerical correspondence between two friends by the help of a certain loadstone, which had such virtue in it, that if it touched. two several needles, when one of the needles so touched began to move, the other, though at never so great a distance, moved at the same time, and in the same manner. He tells us that the two friends, being each of them pos-sessed of one of those needles, made a kind of dial-platë, inscribing it with four-and-twenty letters, in the same manner as the hours of the day are marked upon the ordinary dial-plate. They then nxed one of the needles on eaoh of these plates in such a manner that it could move round without impediment, so as to touch aay of the, four-and-twenty letters. fi Upon their separating from one another into distant countries, they agreed to withdraw themselves puno-tually into their closets at. a certain hour of the day, and to converse with one another by means of this their in-vention. Accordingly, whon they were some hundred miles asunder, each of them shut himself up in his closet at the time appointed, and immediately cast his eye upon his dial-plate. If he had a mind to write anything to his friend, he directed his needle to every letter that formed the words which he had occasion for, making a little pause at the end of every word or sentence, to avoid confusion. The friend in the meanwhile saw his own sym-pathetic needle moving of itself to every letter which that of his correspondent pointed at. By this means they talked together across a whole continent, and con-veyed their thoughts to one another in an instant over cities or mountains, seas or deserts. If Monsieur Scudery, or any other writer of romance, had introduoed a necromancer, who is generally in the train of a knight-errant, making a present to two lovera of a couple of these above-mentioned needles, the reader. would not have been a little pleased to have seon them corresponding with one another when they were guarded by spies and watchers, or. separated by castles and adventures. Il In the meanwhile, if ever this invention should be revived or put in praotioe, 1 would propose that upon the lovor's dial-plate there should be written not only the four-and-twenty letters, but several entire words which have aiwaya a place in passionate epistles, as ûames, darts, die, language, absence, Oupid, heart, oyes, hang, drown, and the like. This would very much abridge the lover's pains in this way of writing a letter, as it would enable him to express the most usefai and significant words with a single touch of the needle.-C. Thus far Addison, a hundred and seventy years ago, and Strada whoever he may be, for ordinary bio-graphical dictionaries ignore him , perhaps fifty before him, and the two unknown experimentalists, perhapa twenty beyond that, making iu ail two hundred and forty or fifty years ago as the date of electrical in-vention whereof we Bée no further mention in the Spectator. But is it not aiso among the Century of the Marquis of Woreester'B Inventions ? -as is pos-sible the scarce volume is not near me for reference. Let the curious reader who can, turn to it and see. Meanwhile, how strangely Addison and Strada have anticipated the dial-plate, and thé needles, and the letters, and the short forma for common words, all so familiar to our telegraphists. Verily there is nothing new under the sun. Extract from my Archive-book, No. 8. Now, understand that I never pre-tended to be a crack shot, thougli 1 did make fair practice through the Indian twist, thé sling support-ing one's arm if 1 hit the target occasionally, 1 was aa.tis6ed. But it once happened at Teignmouth, where 1 was a casual visitor that, seeing a squad of volunteers praotisiDg at a mark on the beach, 1 went to look on, and was courteously offered a shot, being not unknown by fame to some of them. The target was at some goc~ yards say about a third of a mile , so it was not likely 1 could hit it, with a chance rifle, perhaps carelessly sighted yet, when I did let fly, to the loud admiration of the others and to my own astonishment which of course 1 did not reveal , the marker signallod for a buR's eye 1 Entreated to do it again, this prudent rifleman modestly declined, for he remembered Sam Slick's lucky shot at the floating bottle it was manifestly his wisdom not to risk fame won by a fluke. So the moral is, don't try to do, twice what you've done well once. AUTOGRAPHS AND ADVERTISEMENTS. stamped and addressed envelopes, which is a thing both consideratè and praiseworthy but a very different sort and not easily to be excused are those who send registered albums by ppst for one's handwriting, ex-peeting to hâve them returned similarly at no small cost. Longfellow told me of this kind of young lady taxation, and mentioned that he once had to pay twelve shillings for a registered return quarto. I dare say that our popular Laureate has had similar. experiences. The most wholesale order for my signature was at New York in 1851, when at a party there my perhaps too exacting hostess put a large pack of plain cards into my hand, posted me at a corner table with pen and ink, and natteringly requested an autograph for each of her 100 guests 1 of course, even this was graciously con-ceded,-though rather too much of a good thing, I thought. 'There is wisdom somo have hinted to me in pre-ferring a card to a sheet of paper not only beoause 1 I promise to pay might possibly be written t extra over one's signature, but also because and far more pro-bably any speèial fad, politioal, social, or. religious, might be added above-to all seeming-your written approbation e.g., I was told in Amprica that myauto-graphed opinion in favour of Unitarianism had been so. seen at Boston. Some zealots for a cause oven go so far as that. My saie course is to write the hand-writing of So-and.so, where from total ignorance of my correspondent 1 cannot honestly say I am truly Il yours. Interviewing is another sort of homage nowadays to popular authorship in America it is very rife,-and I never came to any city but, immediately on arriva!, two or three représentatives of opponent editors would call, and very courteousiy request to be allowed to turn me inside out, and then to report upon me 1 only remem-ber one or two cases which I will not specify wherein my inquisitor was not all 1 could hâve wished, or treated his patient victim more unkindly than perhaps a venial native humour might make necessary. Almost always the scribes were fair and gentlemanly. As TO ÂDVERTISINCt. A word about advertisements, surely an authorial topic. The absurdly extravagant profusion in whioh thousands of pounda are now being continually flung away in advertising, is one which was nèver approved by me, and as long as' my books remained in print, at ~7 suggestion they all got sold without it. At present there are almost none in the market except Proverbial Philosophy, my Poems, Stephan Langton, and Dramas, and these still live and sell as before, after a silent life of many years. 1 suppose advertisiag must answer, or it would not be persisted in and oertainly thé news-papers that chiefly live thereby exhort all, to orowd their columns, if they,wish to win fortune but how the perpétuai and reiterated obtrusion of, auch single words as Oopack, or Syndicatea, or Beecham's Pills, or Argosy Braces, or Grateful and Ooinfortiag, c. 6., can prbve seductive baits, 1 do not see nor feel the shamoless amount of space they 611 in our newspapers, and especially the impertinent way in which thëy intrude upon us while reading, as interleaved into books and magazines, so entirely disgusts me that 1 have often de-claréd 1 would rather go without tea, coffee, tobacco, or snuff this is a phrase, for the two latter 1 abomi-nate than deign to patronise those persistent advertisers A, B, 0, D, or E. And yet 1 do know a splendid church at Eastbourne wholly built of pills, and Professer Holloway's ointment has produced a palatial institute, and another wholesale advertiser tells me he spends ~30,000 a year on notices and paragraphs, to gain there-by ~'50'ooo'ssd so one cannot but. acquiesce in Car-lyle's cynical dictum, so cruelly alluded to by Deau Stanley in his funeral sermon at .Westminster, that there are in our community 26,000,000, mostly fools, otherwise how can folks be weak enough to be forced to pay for goods, or bads, merely by dint of, réitération ? 1 There is, however, one form of advertisement which I have found to pay,-and that is not praise, but abuse. A certain article, written as 1 was told by Alario Watts, and stigmatising my readera as idiots, and their author as a bellman, was said to have actually sold off 3000 copies at a run and Hep-worth Dixon's attack in some other paper-1 for-get the name-was so lucrative to me in its results that 1 entreated him at Moxon's ono day to do it again. Once 1 took it into my head totconeot and puMish a page of adverse criticisms if 1 can find a copy it shall be printed here to excellent sale-enect as regarded my tales. And I remember hearing at a publisher's, that when a book didn't sell through puffing, their Herald of Fame upstairs was directed to abuse it, and in one case a society novel by a lady of title was prose-cuted by management for libel, in order to get off the edition. That publishing-house used to advertise in nve figures -that is, upwards of~ 10,000 a-year, and was professionally antagonistic to another, from which it had sprung originally. KINDNESS TO ANIMALS. As to tny several efforts in print to hinder cruelty to animaJs, bestdo and beyond what a reader may aiready find in my published books, let me chiefly mention thèse two ny-leaves, widely circulated by the Humane Society in Jermyn Street to wit, Mercy to Animals, and my Four anti-Vivisection Sonnets. The latter 1 must preface with an interesting anecdote. Before Louis Napoleon was Emperor, 1 accompanied a depu-tation from Guernsey to Cherbourg, met him, had pleasant speech with him, and gave him a book, Proverbial Philqsophy , thus making his personal acquaintance which many years after 1 utilised as thus. The horrors of that infernal veterinary torture-house at Alfort, where disabled cavalry horsés were on system vivisected to death, had been known, to us by. letters in the Times, of course denounoing the crimi-nality 1 remember reading that one poor old horse survived more than threesoore opérations, and used to be led in daily strapped With bandages and plaistérs amid the cheors of the domdniaoal students 1-and this exoited me to make a strong personal effort to stop the outrages'at Alfort. Acoordingly, I wrote from Albury a letter to the Emperor if 1 kept and can find a oopy I will print it hère as from one gentleman to another fond of his horse and dog, exhortin'g him to interfère and hinder such horrors. 1 told him that I purposely did thia in a private way, and not through any news-paper or minister, beoause 1 wished him to cure,jM op~o ~o M, à crying evil whereof he was ignorant and there-fore innocent leaving the issue of my appeal to his own generous feeling and to Providence, but otherwise not expecting nor requesting any reply. 1 therefore got none but whether post hoc or pro .pter Aoc 1 do not know thé result was that vivisection at Alfort was suspended at once, though how long for is unknown to me. Those sterile-looking isles of the North Sea are so swept by stormy winds as to be absolutely treeless insomuch that it is jocularly said, that for cutting down a tree at Kirkwall, the penalty is.death! simply because no trees exist there. A pleasanter thing to mention is the Fair Isle hosiery, the patterns whereof in the woven worsted are distinotly Moorish, just like those at Tangiers said to be a survival of soma wreck from the Spanish Armada cast upon the shore, with of course its crew and contents, the local manufacture of said patterns having been kept up ever since, with dyea derived from seaweeds, and from flowers. I frequently observed how diligent in knitting the island women were reminding me of those notable spinsters of Herodotus working the needles all the while they tended cattle, and with the pile of some oostly sbawl upon their heads while they ndget at the fringe its various devices being of natural unstained wools, white, grey, or brown. On our return voyage we skirted the whole north of Seotland, having had the rare chance of the steamer which once a year is chartered to take back the horring-fishers from Thurso to the Hebrides. At Thurso town 1 conversed with the local genius, Robert Dick, made of worldwide fame sinoe by that kind-hearted and olear-minded author, Samuel Smiles, the said genius boing a noted solf-taught naturalist, who as a small baker struggled with poverty through life, to be inconsistently rewardéd after death by a national monument his fellow-townsmen let the living starve to deify him when dead. Cervantes and his like have met the same fate elsewhere. And hère may come a brief memory I wrote lately of Colonel Fred. Burnaby for an American editor. 1 am asked to give a short note of personal reminis-cence about my lately departed friend, Colonel Fred. Burnaby, with whom 1 was intimate for three years before his death. Every one bas read his popular life, and heard of his many exploits how alone in mid-air he navigated a balloon across the Ohannel how he aocomplished, in spite of State telegrams to'the oontrary, his adventurous and patriotio ride to Khiva in dead winter and defying perils of ail sorts how he stood six feet four in his stockings with another foot to be added to that magnincent specimen of manhood when in jack-boots and in his plumed helmet how he was strong enough to bind a kitchen poker round his neck, to crack cobnuts in his nngers, and to carry a pair of Shetland ponies upstairs under his arms,-how alao the genial giant, quite the Arao of Tennyson's Princess, was the gentlest and kindest and least dangerous of knights-errant unless, indeed, his just wrath was aroused by anything mean or insolent, when doubtless he could be terrible , and how he was the idolised of men, eapeoially his own brother giants of the Royal Régiment of Blues, and naturally was also the. adored of women wherever he showed himself This Admirable Crichton had every social acoomplishment, but as he was also gifted with a knowledge of many tongues, even to Turkish and Arabie, beyond the more familiar French, German, Italian, and Spanish, of course he must dare all sorts of perilous travel, if only to provo that he was no oarpet-knight, no mère 'gold stick' at court, or silver-oasqued statue at, the Horse Guards. So he foarlessiy risked his life in aU ways on every possible occasion which thé War Omco routine gave him on holiday. Khiva and Kars, and of late at last the fatal Mahdi war, had fascinations for him of danger which bis thirst for, active service too muoh refused to him as obliged officially to bo a stay-at-home had not power to resist and we all know how gallantly, if indeed too rashly, he fougbt and fell on what his Viking blood loved best as a deathbed, the field of battle. For he came of an old Teutonie family, and on his mother's side was also a direct descendant, as he told me himself, of our heroia and gigantio King Edward III., whom he is said greatly to have resembled, as the portrait at Windsor Oastle proves. We were talking about ancestry and the anec-dote came out naturally enough. In politics a strong Conservative, he, with charac-teristic antagonism, chose radical Birmingham for his coveted seat in Parliament, but alas he bas not lived to hazard the election. He. was a neat, fluent, and epigrammatic speaker, as potent with his tongue as with his sword and as for the pen albeit his hand-writing muât have puzzled compositors , the myriade of readers who hâve enjoyed his atirring books in print, can testify how brilliant and eloquent he was for the matter of authorship. He tôld me of a new novel-of the satinco-political sort-which he had written for thé press, but as yet we hear nothing definite of its publication. My own personal acquaintance with the familiar 'Fred. Burnaby' was oonnned to several hospitable dinner-parties at thé houso of his relative, Lady W-my néar neighbour and friend at Norwood, about whioh 1 might anecdotiao to any extent but 1 nover altow myself to record private conversation nor to reveal domesticities.' AU such are sacred in my memory, a~d on principle I despise the modern mischief-maker whose reminiscences are practically reminuisànaes. On a cer-tain public occasion, however, Burnaby stood by me, to my great pleasure and advantage, and let me record bis kindness thus. When 1 gave my lecture on Flying at thé Royal Aquarium, he most appropriatoly took the chair, and made some excellent remarks. AItogether, let my testimony, however brief, however inadequate, to the merits of Fred. Burnaby be this 1 lost in his too sudden death a friend, as 1 had hoped, for many years to come, and my regrets are for him as one of the noblest of mankind. Let me add a word further, as the worthy witnessing of one, quite a kindred spirit, whose acquaintance I made some long time back, and look for great things from his energy and enterprise, and multifarious talents,-C~CM'~ J~M~t~, then the famous Eastern Pioneer, who in his book on Asia, says Yes, our Burnabys, our Bakers, our MacGregors, our Gordôns-these are the real piJIars of the Empire, Thèse are the men who confer provinces upon Englànd, Wbo risk their lives to guard them. When, thé world is a little older, and the working man's vote is worth more than the statesman's opinion, then the splendid achievements of suoh men will be more generously appreciated and the warm English feeling expended to-day on torpid, stupid, unpatriotic party politioians will be directed towards heroes whose steady undaunted patriotism, in face of public indifference and bureau-cratie disdain, conveys a moral as grand as their careers. A DiNINQ-OUT ANECDOTE. As have before said, not having been much given to society, nor thereforè a professional parasite of Amphi-tryon though sometimes tempted to his side as a lion, but more often vainly, for 1 always refused if 1 could , 1 have an instructive anecdote to give about a celebrated conversationist, whom 1 will not name nor indieate even by initiais. One evening 1 found myself compelled to accompany him to a great man's banquet-nota bene, it was after 1 had well recovered speech-and so 1 found myself at his chambers perhaps ten minutes too soon. He called to me from his dressing-room, bidding me to amuse myself till he was ready. Now, on the study table were laid several books, open, with weights to keep them so and 1 glanced from one to another to while -away the time. Then up came his brougham, and off we went. At dinner my diner-out started a topic, whereof innocently enough 1 remembered instàntly a suitable epigram. Not long after another subject .gave me occasion to tell a witty story, which somehow came to me at the moment. My friend asked me with a keen glance where 1 had read it, and at once 1 recolleotëd those open books and understood the position, resolving mischievousiy to out-ûank the manoenverer. Accordingly, at each oppor-tunity, with seeming innocence, 1 wiped hia eye, as they say at a battue, and certainly reaped thé anecdotic AM ?os Mr. So-and-so had ounningly contrived and hoped to achieve for himself. Ï confess it was vicious of me, but who could help taking the benefit of suoh a chance ? Hosts should beware of wits who oram their jokes and anecdotes. Years after 1 met the same gentleman at another entertainer's table, where 1 found him in my présence not qùito thé livener-up they had expected, and he seemed a little shy of me probably he thought me an omniscient, for I never told the pobr man 1 had found him out. 1 fear ho bas departed to a world where genuine truthfulness is more accepted as a virtue than in this. A MORMON GUEST. Quito recently 1 have had a visit from a young American, who brought me a letter from a so-called cousin-at aU events a namesake-in the Far West, asking me to tell her about her German ancestry. My visitor was good-looking, well-dressed, fair-spoken, and gentlemanly also well-bred and well-to-do. 1 will not indicate his name, but I may state that he is a n'ear relative of the eminent electrician who illuminates so magnificently the fountains at South Kensington. Of course, as pleased with his manners and deportment, I. kept him to luncheon and finding that he hailed from Utah, naturally asked if he knew Sait Lake City and. the Mormons there. Certainly he lived not a hundred miles from the city, and those were his own pëople as a Mormon himself from in noy, ho had nothing but good to say of them, and we in England had been very much mialed by Mrs. Stenhouse and other trayellers. As to plurality of wivës, not two per cent. of their whole 200,000 had more than one wife. His own father, a rich merchant and a church-hierarch, a stake of the tabernacle much as we should say a pillar , had but one-his own dear mother-and he scarcely knew any one with more. It was quite a European misjudg-ment tbat many followed Brigham Young's doctrine, whioh never had been Joseph Smith's.-and the present ohief, Taylor, had but one. He showed us many cabinet photographs of Sait Lake City, his own family, leading Mormons, and the like especially of the Old tabernacle, like a monstrous tortoise, and one from a flnished draw-ing. of the new, of even more tasteless architecture, being the most gigantic piece of perpendicular ever perpetrated, and full of unsightly windows. When asked about the golden book,-well ho had never seen it, but believed in it thoroughly because all the .twelve apostles had seen it and he trusted their testimony. Eleven of those apostles were now dead, one only sur-viving. Just as with our friends of Mr. Irving's sect at Albury, which arose in the same year as Mormonism. We had never set eyes on the originals of our own Scriptures-in tact, they did not exist-but believed the witnessing of others, as he did. Ho himself was not a missionary, but would go if he was sent by the Ghurch though he mightn't like it, he was bound to obey authority, c. c. 1 had plenty more talk with him, and found him intelligent, modest, and in every way a remarkably agreeable young fellow and I added to my mental Mpef~oM'6 of botter judgments that on Mormonism,-even as heretofore Mr. Sinnett has taught me not utterly to despise Buddhism, Dr. Wilkinson to revere Swedenborgianism, and a few othér people 1 might name who are true believers, to be charitable as to other sorts of strange isms once 1 met a very religioug olergyman who still held by Johanna Southcote and we hâve ail heard how Lady HesterStanhope had an Arab horse always rëady saddied for Messiah when He is to ride into Jerusalem and how some other person had a gold spoon and fork laid daily at his table for the sudden ooming of a Divine Guest 1 Car personal lesson is to be tolérant of all manner of innocent onthusiasms, to hear both sides and bear with all opinions,-s.ome-times finding to our astonishment that Maok sheep may after all be whiter than they looked, and that unchari-table préjudice is but another name for ignorant folly. Before taking leave of my Mormon guest, 1 ought to report that he was teetotal, handsome, taciturn rather than talkative, a hunter among the Rockies, an author himself, and of course an old book-friend, so 1 made him happy with some autographic poetries. With reference to Joe Smith's own theological creed, there is a very neat and notable ~M'~M of it on p.-i~! of a bright little book 1 have lately read, titled Frank's Ranche, or my Holiday in the Rockies, easily accessible. That creed is so good that when 1 read it aloud to my homeflock they said, Why, we believe ail that 1 -and as to the evil matter of many wives, not only did the original Joseph repudiate that doctrine, but his namesake son, still a chief among the Mormons, does the same, and so far bas seceded from the Brigham heresy whioh a son of mine says is not bigamy, but Brighamy. A banknote expérience when a very small child I used to be taken to the Postford paper-mill at Albury by my nurse, who had a follower or a followed in the foreman there. While they talked together, 1 was deputed to amuse myself by making banknote paper, as thus a spoonfulof pulp put into a shallow tray of wire and shaken deftly made a small oblong of paper duly impressed with Britahnia and water-marked being then dried on a nannel pad. Many years after, when .1 was preparing for Oxford under Mr. Holt at Postford House, there was discovered a secret oupboard in the wall of his drawing-room whieh was found to contain several forged plates for printing banknotes and this discovery ac-counted for the recent suicide of a Mr. H- a previous owner of the paper-mill, who evidently feared exposure and conviction. No one now is allowed to make bank-note paper, except the honourable firm of Messrs. Portal, which bas the monopoly thereof but when I was a child, any one might do it, and if there was a forger handy, fraud was possible to any extent. Our New-land's Corner on Merrow Downs is so called from Abraham Newland, whose name is printed on old bank-notes as F. May is on new ones, and who owned Postford Mill. Rence the word Sham-Abram for a forged note. 2. Apropos to my mention of Mortimer Collins' visit to Albury on another page, 1 make this extract from his Pen Sketches by aVa.Niahed Hand, vol. i. pp. 167. 168 PP- 167, Walk through Surrey. At Albury 1 called upon a poet,-one whoni cri tics love to assail, but who derides critica and arrides the public. Pleasant indeed is the nno old house, with emerald lawn and stately trees, wherein he residés. Not Horace in his Sabine farm, nor OatuIIus at Tiburs, had a more poetio retreat than the author of Proverbial Philosophy at Albury. But, like Catullus, the advent of May had set the poet longing for a flight far away Jam ver egelidos refert tepores, Jam coeli furor oequinootialis Juoundis Zephyri silescit auris Jam mens prestrepidans avet vagari Jam loeti studio pedes 'vigesount.' And he was about to take wing for sea-side resorts, and the soft cyclades of the Channel, beloved by Victor Hugo. Right hospitable was he a bottle of cool claret cheered the dusty wayfarer, and an hour's pleasant talk was even more choering. Hence 1 walked through Albury Park towards Gomshall. Let me a so give a brace of home sketches of Long-fellow. I have had two principal interviews with him in his beautiful home at Cambridge, Massachusetts, at the wide interval between those visita of twenty-five years. Of the first of these 1 record a few words from my American MS. journal in 1851, adding some un-written thoughts and recollections. On April i6th, then, in the year just named, Longfellow wrote to me cordially, and with much kindly appreciation, and soon after, calling on me at Boston, took me off in his carriage over the flooded lowlands to the ancient for America University of Cambridge, where the Queen Anne-like colleges are nestled in fine old elms. He treated me, of course, most hospitably, and had asked several iends to meet the traveller but one, a chief guest, was otherwise engaged, and so 1 missed Lowell, to my great disappointment. It is not my form to detail private conversation, nor to describe the Lares and Penates of sacred domesticity but 1 may reveal génerally that I spent several golden hours of intel-lectual communion with the Abbott 'Laurences, Ticknor, Fields, Preàcott, and Everett-illustrious names, which will sufficiently indicate the reception they gave me. At this time of day 1 cannot remember the thousand winged speeohes that Bew about that genial board, and, as 1 failed, from conscientious motives, to record them in my journal, I will not invent, after thirty-four years have passod over my memory, with their crowds of other words and fanoies. Be this enough I reoolleot to have asked Longfellow why ho wrote Exoelsiof, and not the more grammatical BxceIsMM, as the title to one of his most iamous pooms. The reason is a ourious one he wrote those stirring verses, by request, on thé motto 0 for the New York coat-of-arms, whieh is legended not quite accurately, Excelsior. And when, in the samo line of thought, 1 inquired why he named a German story Hyperion, with no apparent reason om clas-sical associations, he pertinently enough answered me by pronouncing the name ~Mpe~-tOM~ going higher , the story being a tale of progress in human character. And now to leap over twenty-five years, at whioh interval I paid my second visit to America in 1876, when again 1 had the privilege of being Longfellow's guest in the same historic abode where Washington had once his headquarters. My kind-hearted host insisted on my occupying the same arm-chair I had before, and which since, he said, had been the throne of Dickens and Thackeray, and every book-celebrhy that had visited Cambridge. Among invited guests unable to. corne was Oliver Wendell Holmes, but 1 soon after made up for this loss by having a long talk with that shrewd and amusing writer at Boston and once more, alas 1 no Lowell, whom 1 missed again, though 1 had waited for him that quarter of a century 1 Longfellow, out of compliment so he kindly said to his English guest, had specially provided pheasants and Stilton cheeae, among such more Transatlantic delicacies as wild venison from Tupper.Lake, in the Adirondacs , and canvas-back ducks from Baltimore to say less of terrapin soup, whereof the unhatched eggs of tortoises are the OMMe-oMcAe After dinner he gaTe me an apple from Beaupré, Evangelino's farm, the pips whereof 1 sent to Albury for planting. Mr. Fields, on this festive occasion, reoitedsome of Mark Twain's humour, and 1 had to give sundry of my American ballads, and the host himself bis exquisite Psalm of Life j my Venus, in reply to his Mars, having appeared, and been praised by him, somo years before. And this meagre record is all 1 care, or have space, to give of that feast of reason and flow of soul. With Charles Kingsley, however seldom we met, I had strong sympathy in many ways, as a man of mon, to be loved and admired but chiefly we could feal for each other in the matter of stammering, sort of amiction not sufficiently appreciated. Kingsley con-quered his infirmity, as I did mine, and rose to frequent eloquence in his public ministrations privately his speech would often fail him, and was his thorn in the flesh to the end. 1 remember a most pleasant day spent with him about the fishponds and cascades of Wotton,-and I noted how skilfully he threw the fly some five-and-twenty feet under the bushes, to the wonder of a gaping trout, soon to nnd its lodging in the creel and our kind host may still recollect, as 1 do, how charming was our inter-course that day with thé genial author of Yeast, Alton Look, Il Hypatia, Westward ho and other of our vouritea. I hâve met Kingsley later, in bis cloistered nest, as Canon of Westminster, and remember how heartily he expressed his abundant charity for all sorts of misérable sinners, especially about one of whom I came to speak, for there never lived a more universal excuser of human imperfection than Charles Kingsley. In this connection 1 may give an anecdote to the point. Soon after my return from America in 1851 1 dined with my neighbour at AI-bury, Henry Druinmond, the humoursome M.P., always not a little good-naturediy misohievous. He knew that I had not approved of Lord Elgin's petulant removal of his viceroyal establishment from Montreal to Toronto, and cunningly resolved t6 draw me out before witnesses on the matter. Now I had taken in to dinner' an elderly Scotch lady unknown to me, and sat next to her of course. Soon my lively host somewhat unfairly asked me about my visit to Canada, and what 1 thought tif the then notorious flight of the Governor to far dis-tant Toronto,-forcing me to express my disapprova!, whioh naturally as an honest man 1 did, on which my left-hand neighbour, a lady of rank whom I knew, whis-pered Mind what you are saying, you took in his mothor. Accordingly, I had frankly to turn and say, And l'm sure Lady Elgin will ,agree with me, and you too, Mr. Drummond, for no captain should fly from his post because he's laughed at. This candid speech was fortunately applauded all round the table, and not least by the friendly Countess and the ba~ed mischief lover. Lord Elgin most kindly interested himself in the restoration of the Brock monument at Queenstown Heights, which had then recently been damaged by gunpowder, and is since rebuilt my good reason for asking h~aidbeing that Sir Isaao Brook was my near relative his mother bearing my name , and that he had saved Canada by his death in victory.
