For other of my politicals, take this common-sense essay from my pen, hitherto unpublished 1S THE ONE-VOTE SYSTEM RIGHT OR WRONCt? a In a nation self-governed through its own representa-tives, it seems reasonable to admit that each citizen should have a vote each citizen, wo say, simply as such whether mâle or female, labourer, pauper, civil, niilitary, naval, or omcial, every one not convicted of crime nor an atteated lunatic, of full age, of sufficient capacity evidenced by being able to read and write , cglibate or married, rich or poor,-everypersou in our commonwealth should equitably, it may well bo con-ceded, Lave his or her single vote in the government of the country. Poverty is no crime, therofore the Work-, house should not disfranchiso sex is no just disqualin-oation, thereforo the woman should have her vote as freely as the man, for surely marriage ought not to' suffèr derogation and disgrace by denial of the common right of citizenship as its penalty the soldier, sailor, policeman, government onicial, and any other class which may now be deprived of their birthright by law or custom, should certainly be admitted to thé poil like other patriotio citizens in. short, manhood sunrage, it may be theoretically argued, is just and wise-manhood of course including womanhood, as suggested above for even a wife either sides with her husband or controls him in common cases and in the less usual instances where he rules, thére need be no more tyranny about poli-tical matters than about. domesticities, and so the home would scarcely. bé any the.worse even for partisan zeal. However,.whi!st admitting the theoretical propriety of a one vote for each citizen in the state, there remains to be coinsidéred the higher practical justice ofmany having more than one. Numbers alone are not the strength of a people if of infenor quality they are rather its weakness. For the Parliament of England représentation is demanded of all the virtues, talents, and acqùirements, not cortainly of the vice, ignorance, poverty, and other evils mord rife amoug the lower rungs of the social ladder than to those above them. Thé single vote system so far as the franchise bas any influence at ail depresses and demoralises every class, as reducing all to one dead levé!. Thé ballot plan is now law and. cannot well be done away with but it is manifestly a h~miiiation fur intelligence to have to sign with his mark in order that ignorance may thus feel itself on an equality and for honest geniaHty to be hushed into silent aocresy, that it may not put to shame the cunning fraud of a partizan who wishes to hide his real opinion. However, it is now too late to mend thé ballot-box let it be, aud let the single voter' use it if lie pleases. Another and a wiser scheme presents itself, practi-cally if possible even now to avert the national ruin wrought by the machinations of a rash and blind self-seeking spirit of party, often. seen hoist by its own petard, though too liable to destroy the foundations of society in the explosion. Shortly and simply, the scheme is this. Let every man, high or low, add to his one vote others as lie may and can. Be there a vote for the Victoria Cross, another for the Albert Medal, auother for long good-service in' the hous.ehold or thé farm, another for any such intellectual exploits among thé poor as .Samuel Smiles bas recorded all thèse being accessible to thé humblest, and so elevating them thus far. And now to asoend a few rungs, let additional votes be given to owners of a stated number of acres, to possessors of a certain amouut of money, to those who have been deemed worthy of public honours, and the like. A little further, let every mayor of a town have his omcial vote, and the Presidents of the Royal Society and Royal Academy, and perhaps two or three other cbiefs of science and art and so forth. Thus, tbeu, we might get, by way of oounterpoise to the voting power of a bare and overwhelming prolé-tariat, the worthier aud far sweeter voices of those who have virtues aud excellences ofYarioua kinds to recom-mend them,-so that if the lowest constituent côuMta for one, the highest may add up to six or eight. And thus, while no one of the mob is denied his one vote, those who rise above the crowd receive the more than one they hâve earned by good-doing or position, and plunip them all accordingly to the worthiest candidate., The method of ascertaimag and ensuring such votes might be this. IN connection with the above, I will hère print for thé first time a paper written long ago on the now rife subject of a cure for Irish misery at all events partially. Ireland bas been with me a theme for many kinds of literature from that usual sort of authorship, letters in the Times, to journalising on occasion, balladising in or out of season, and now and then a political squib or graver article. I have known that hapless land well in old days irom Giant's Causeway to Cape Clear have been a guest in several noted homes,, as with geological Enniskillen and astronomical Crampton know the natives well, and how they hâve been taught by prieats and démagogues to hate the Sassenacb, and like most well-meaning men, who, after every kind effort, find tbemselves utterly misunderstood, am as a -merely private and quite unprejudicedpolitician entirely at a loss .to know how to please that inipracticable people, or to mend their misérable condition. However, that in my authorial fashion I A tM tried, let the follôwing paper prove written and published nearly thirty years ago. Nations think and feel and act much as individuals do for, after all, the largest orowd of men is, only an aggre-gate of units. If contempt provokes a man to anger, and avowed negleot forces him into indolence and hope-lessnesa, we shall see the same result in masses as we do in single persons and the causes which may have generated hatred and despair will everywhere and everywhen find cures in their contraries, honour being accorded in the place of contempt, and kindly care instead of cold indifference. Thus, the far too common phrase, 'No Irish need apply,' bas doubtless wrought inanité ill-feeling and the Levite's chilling rule of passing by on the other side' evermore arouses indig-nation nationally no less than individually. Now, it cannot be denied in an ethnological sensé that the Celtic nature is peculiarly sensitive any more than it can be denied historically that its good feelings have been too often systematically crushéd, and its generous impulses seared. If the l'eutonio mind illus-trates in sterner traits the manhood of human intelli-gence, the Ceit shows its gayer youthfulness, if not indeed tha lighter phases of its recHesa childhood and it bas been a second nature for the Saxon to hold mas,tery over the Celt, as a weaker race is everywhere subject to a strong one. Moreover, opposition in re-ligious creed bas had its evil influences, scarcely yet extinct, however caustically such a cure may in vain have been hitherto attempted. We must take nations as we find them thé Keltoi and the Sakai aiways at contrariety, do not seem to have altered in character from the earliest prehistorio reports,of old Herodotus even to our own times, more than three thousand years..Racial peculiarities are known to survive the actual transplantation to new lands see in especial the Irish of America as the Roman poet bas it, 'Those who cross the sea may change their sky, but not their mind.' Therefore it is that a far-seeing and philosophical statesmanship should ever deal spocineally-and as if individually-with national churacter for example,. if we would couvert the typical Irish mind from muât we say it ? hatred of England to the love of her, we must commence as we would in domestic life, by somehow managing to please our too sensitive sister, by showing her our sympathies, and by treating her with honour instead of contemp-tuoua indifference thus investing her with thé gar-ment of praise for the spirit of heavinesa. It is a quarter of a century since the writer of this paper published in the course of a book of his, now somewhile out of print Thé Rides and Reveries of ~Eaop Smith , the following short chapter, on page 322, hère reproduced textually. It was headed The Unsunned Corner, and runs thus Ireland came upon the tapis, and JEsop said, when bis turn came to speak One of my fields, on the wrong slope of a hill-Bide and surrounded by trees, scarcely ëver sees the sun and by consequence its crops are short when arable, and when in pasture its grass sour, and the hay musty. And why then, he went on to say, shouidn't Ireland have a palace a Balmoral at.EiUarnoy, or another Osborne at Killiney~ Poor Erin is that unsunned corner of our Empire's field and it seems a thousand pities,that the kingdom of Ireland should be denied some auch special royal home as is even found rather superûuousiy at the camp at AIdershot. What if oneof those lovely arbutus-wooded islands at the foot ofM'GHilicuddy's Reeka were' ntted with a Swiss cottage for the Queen? Or if Bantry Bay supplied its marble for a royal castle near Cape Clear ? 1 Or if the railroad to Galway were supplied with a gilt carriage or two to waft Majesty and children to some western palace in Connemara ? Think you such gleams of sunshine wouldn't fertilise that poor neglected field, nor make its crops abundant, and its peasants happy? z Think you that the gold mine of Royal bounty, and the graciousness of Royal favour, would not work a blessed change for grateful Ireland 1 Try it, 0 good Queen t-a Viceregal Court, excellent as ours is now, is but a sorry substitute for the real Majesty, nickel for eilvèr, electrotyped plate in-stead of the true golden buffet not without snobbism too, and toadyism and vulgarism and other détestable small heresies. If but once in three years Viotoria's rural Court were housed in an Irish palace, her présence would do more for happiness, prosperity, and patriotism than..all of these that Maynooth grants have ever hindered. Thus ~!sop Smith in 1858 delivered his mind on the matter. It is by no means pretended or supposed that a palatial résidence would of itself cure Irish evila aud misfortunes but it might be a step towardsthisgood resuit!, and at any rate would rembve one very allegible accusation of negleot Ireland should enjoy the like privilèges with her sister kingdoms England and Soot-land and however inadéquate, ~f'M, suoh a simple prescription may soem as jEsop Smith suggeats, his advioe contains at least one very obvious and easy cure for Irish disaneotion and 1 am not aware that either by.pamphlet or in Parliament it bas yot been seriousiy mooted. Thé Celts are a folk of easentially loyal in-stincts but much as Americans often are heard to complain in their own behaJf they have, as an inde-pendent nation, no seen and known object for their loyalty. Since the days of Brian Boroime at his mytbic court of Tara, the Irish people have hardly set eyes upon thé monarch of their country perhaps if we except the conquering William of thé Boyne our elderly Adonis, George the Fourth, was the sole specimen of English Majesty that has illuminated Ireland until our gracious Queen herself made two very short but notable visita-tions in 1849 and 18~ yet even in the Georgian instance, unfavourable as personally it must have been, the enthusiastic reception he met with some sixty years ago at the hands of his Irish subjeots is still reniembored after two générations with a gratefui and effusive loyalty. Imagine, if only from such an example as this, what might be the bohencent effect of our good Queen periodically visiting her kingdom of Ireland, and per-manently having thero soine such happyhomestead as Osborne or Balmoral if also, in her absence, one of the princes of our Royal, house represented his Imperial mother as Vicoroy and if'in their train the tide of aristooracy, wealth, and fashion Ëowed in upon im-poverished Ireland. It is not easy to caloulate the advantages of such a social revolution as this and surely, in spite of many obvious objections, such an experimeut might be worth the trial. A beginning might avowedly be made in the right direction, by building or purchasing some suitable castle as a permanent palace for Ireland's Queen say, for old assooiation's sake, at Tara, if ànyhow adaptable,-or any other picturosque neighbourhood connected with some anoient chieftain of the Irish quasi-heptarchy wherein a Royal Establishment might be commenced, in present proof of the serious intention as to an early future résidence the mind of the people might be thus prepared for the speedy coming of their Sovereign and her Court, and would be softened and gratified by the evident confidence and good-feeling thus shown as well as their condition materially benented by the necessary expenditure that must be laid out looaJIy in labour and materials, giving work to the needy, and so helping to cure Erin's chief disease,poverty to the verge of famine. As to actual life-peril,-every due precaution being taken,-the happy result of such a humanising experiment might fairly be left to the generous native loyalty of a kindly treated people, and to the gracious guardianship of God's good providence. 1 am sure that present Royalty would neither be boy-cotted nor burked. We remember with what generous cordiality our Prince and Princess were received by ail classes and creeds in their recent brave visit to Ireland. I cannot honestly protend to have always taken quite so amiable a view of Oeltio matters. 1 plead guilty to having more than once assailed in print Daniel O'Connell and his kind, and to have written a pair of once famous poetical fly-leaves, Edn gobragh and Hurrah for Repealt copies of which beyond my arohivod ones can now only be found in the Ballad Collection of the British Museum, which 1 used to supply with my Sibyllines at a chief librarian's ro. quest 1 forget the name, but he coHeoted suoh placards. 1 fear the two above were not very complimentary but'what can one do for a perverse people, who com-plain of it as a wrong that they are excused the Queen's .taxes? Also I wrote certain famous letters on Ireland, especially four long ones signed T. iu the Times of January i8 .7. In Ireland I hâte caught a salmon at Killarnoy and cooked it too on an arbutus stake I have bruised my shins at the Giact's Causeway 1 have been an honoured guest at olassioal Florence Court have picked up native gold at Avoca have donc the Round Towers, possibly Phoenician Baal-temples have handled Brian Boroime's harp and have been shooked everywhere by the poverty and degradation of that musical barbarian's misérable because idle people. Mrs. p. had an invalid daughter subject to violent headaohes, and as she had read of the remedial powers of mesmerism from Chauncey Townsend's book, privately resolved to try and cure her, and soon set her to sleep by the usual passes. However, when after twelve and even eighteen hours the girl could not be awakened, Mrs. P. and her husband a dergyman, who knew nothing of the cause were alarmed and summoned doctor after dootdr, to wake her, if they could. In this connection I will extract from one of my Archive-books the curious story of a mysterious koy in whioh my family are still interested for thé secret is not yet solved. In the fourteenth volume, then, of my Archives ocoura this long note, aooompanied by thé drawing whioh 1 made years ago of the weird-looking key with a loose ring handle, a threefold staircase body, and a strangely ringed column. My father died in his sleep, December 8, 18~, at Southwick House, in Windsor Park, on the same night after Its owner, Lord Limerick, had also died there in his arma, my father having been his medical friend for thirty yeara. My father used to carry in his pocket a strange key, whereof the figure was vèry unusual, as it folded up, and though large he carried it in his pocket habitually and ho used to say in his quietly humorous and reserved manner, 'under thitt key lies a fortune ' my mother and I and others remember this well. When 1 came to be executor, there was nearly nothing to guide me as to the amount of my father's property,-and 1 certainly did not sucoeed iu realising all that he was supposed to have acquired. It was wonderful that with his large income he left so little.. So, wo all thought that some hoard locked by this key contained the missing treasure my father's habituai taoitumity. and secretiveness favouring this idea. But, nowhere could the lock to fit it be found nowhere either at banks or lawyers or anywhere about our old house in Burlington Street or at Albury, ap-peared thé chest or cupboard containing the fanoied accumulations and to this hour, June 12, 18~3, nearly thirty years after my father'a audden death, bas thé mystery not been cleared up. Once, on an occasion of a spiritualistio ~Mce at Mr. Carter Hall's, I handod the said key ,to Mr. Home when entranoed, and ho sbuddered at it, and uttered the name 'Elizaboth Hendërson,whioh 1 thought at the time a bad guess, as one utterly unknown to me but oddly enough it' 1 proved to be the name of the Queen's housekeeper at Windsor. However, on inquiry nothing further came of this, for she was not in office when my father died at the Park. To-day I have taken the key to a Miss Hudson, a clairvoyante, who never saw me before, nor was told my Dame, nor my errand, except that I laid that key silently before her. She can tell me very little, except that the mystery is soon to be cleared up, and that certain spirits from description possibly my mother and brother William much wish it. I gave no sort of clues, but the medium guessed at my father's character, and at the long lapse of time since the losa of the chest, and at the hiding of it in some 'bank, whether underground or at a banker's did not appear. The medium's 'attendant spirit'-one 'Daisy,an Indian papoose'- says it is 'in a dark place, like a vault, and .mouldy.' 1 am urged to inquire further. Miss Hudson, a common-looking but respectable woman of about thirty,-iving in a lodging near Bloomsbury Square,-utterly ignorant who I was and all about me, -said in her spirit voice that 1 was a writer of books, and did gréât good, and was inspired by two spirits, one of the fair and lively sort all in white, and thé other an old philosopher-a strange guess at my mixed mediey of writings. Miss Hudson promised me that I should soon know the secret of the key, because the spirits wiéhed it, and because there was a blue magnetic circle round the key. F.It is only proper to state that up to this pré-sent writing, January 13, 1886, 1 have heard nothingat all from the spirits aforesaid, and that the family key ia as mysterious as ever. On page 3 of this book I proposed no mention of private domesticities or of personal religious experiences -the one being ofinterest merely to my family, the other a matter between God and the soul. However, the recent sudden death of one for fifty years my faithful friend and companion in marriage, urges me to record here simply her many excellent qualities, which must not be passed by without a regretful word as if I were a Stoic, or as if my dear good wife of half a century could be silently forgotten by her bereaved husband and chil-dren. I began this biography when she was in her usual health and spirits, but soon after its commencement a fit of apoplexy took her unconsciously from our happy circle,-andve are made to feel bythis aSiotion, as also by another over leaf, how truly in the midst of life we are in death. Her body awaite the Resurrection in Albury Churchyard, and her spirit lives with us in aRee-tionate remembrance. DE BEAUVOIR CHANOERY SUIT AND BELGRAVIA. M? lamented son, Henry de Beauvoir, active and athletic, was killed in South Africa by the most un-likely accident of being jolted on the front seat in a rutty road and crushed to death under the wheel of an ox-waggon creeping at two miles an hour 1 This sad event occurred on May 31, i8~t and thé news-papers at thé time, both British and South African, fully recorded not only the accident but the heroism of thé brave youth, the kind but unavailing assiduities of friends, and the municipal honours accorded to him at his funeral, when the mayor and council, the volun-teers and chief inhabitants of King William's Town every window shuttered followed him to the grave, where Archdeacon Kitton read the solemn service and some months after, a marble headstone was placed over his remams. His two, brothers have written some touching stanzas to his memory but they are private. I mention all this sadnesa now by way of publicly acknowledging the kindness of Archdeacon Kitton and, other friends at King William's Town, not fqrgetting a most friendly officer of the American navy, from whom we have received many excellent letters and présents from ail round the world, ever since he was among thé Qrst to break to us the death o~ my son, now Ëfteen-years ago 1 désire, then,' cordially to thank T. G. for these CHAPTER XLVI. kindnesses as also Mr. Robertson, of Brechin, N.B., whose son was Henry's African comrade, with him at the time of the catastrophe, and following him to the grave. Henry having been for good ancestral reasons chris-tened de Beauvoir, remiuds me of a memorable matter of our family history which, as it is on record, 1 will, here relate. In the days of King James I. to quote with pedantic omissions from a pedigree , one Peter de Beau-voir, descended from a younger branch of the ducal house of Rutland, had an eldest son, James, whose daughter Rachel married Pierre Martin my spiritual sponsor after Martin Luther , and her daughter married a Carey of Guernsey, whose descendant married my grandfather. Peter's second son, Richard, married a Priaulx, also related to us, and her daughter married a Benyon, in Charles II.'s time, whose descendant is now the mil-lionaire, Sir Richard Benyon de Beauvoir of Reading, o. o. Now, this is thé strange fact which bas always puzzled me as well as others. The old De Beauvoir was a very thrifty miser, and died two hundred years ago possessed of great wealth, which bas increased enor-mousiy up to our day, seeing he bad landed property in the north of London,. now including De Beauvoir l'own. In the second generation, bis grand-daughters Rachel Martin of the elder branch and Marie Priaulx of the younger, contended at law for the inheritance after some intestacy and a terrible lawsuit raged in Ohancery for 150 years, between thé Tuppers and thé Benyons,-and was carried even to the House of Lords, being finally decided in my memory for the Benyons. 1 remember my unole saying he would not take thirty thousand pounds for his individual ohanoet'-but my lésa sanguine father carod not to join in the lawsuit,-saying he woùM not throw good money after bad. For my own judgment, and I can speak as an old conveyancing barrister though without business or expérience of nearly fifty years' standing, our side as the elder had the best right, though the two sisters might well and wiselyhave shared in a compromise. Butsomehowit came to be decided that the younger claimant of that vast property must bave all,-and the elder be atrangely left out in the cold. After the conclusion of the Lords, further litigation was hopeless so those whom I now represent as almost the last of the Abruzzi must acquiesce in getting nothing, while the opponent side bas the good luck to possess, as Dr. Johnson has it, wealth beyond the dreams of avarice. Such is life,-and law the most obstinate and the riohest win the less pertina-cious and the poorer are allowed to fail it is a process of Darwin's survival of the fittest. Ail this is now too late to mend but 1 do hope that if ever 1 go to Engelfield Castle, Sir Richard will be kindly and genial to his far-off cousin, who but for some legal quibMe unknown might have dispossessed him. My father numbered among bis patients the Duke of Rutland, and 1 have heard him say that they half-humorously called each other cousins. A LOST CHANCE IN BBMBAVIA. In this connection of possible good luck .that nevor happened, let me record this. Another of my father's patients was thé long deceased Earl Grosvenor, grandfather of the present Duke of 'Westminster and about him 1 bave a tale to tell, which shows how nèarly we might have been possessed of, another vast property-but wo missed it. One day in my boyhood, 1 remember my father coming,home after his round and telling my mother that he had a gréât mind to buy thé five Ëeids of Lord Grosvenor's, beoause he thought London might extend that way. Those five fields are now covered with the palatial streets of Belgravia,-but were then a dismal marshy Bat intersected by black ditches, and notorious for high-way robbery, as a district dimly lit with an oil lamp here and there, and protected by nothing but the useless old watchman in his box it is the tract of land between Grosvenor Place and Sloane Street. His lordship had a reputation for parsimony, and he fancied it a bargain if he could sell to my father those squalid fields for ~2000,-so he offered them to him at that price. When my mother heard of this, she was dead against so extravagant an outlay for that desolate région so much dreaded by her whenever her aunt's black horses in the old family coach ploughed their way through the slush MacAdam had not then arisen to givô us granite roads to caU on an ancient relative, Mr. Hall, who possessed a priceless cupboard of old Chelsea~hina, and lived near the hospital. A tradition existed that the said family waggon had once been stopped thereabouts by some vizored knight of the road, and this memory connrmed my mother's disapproval of tbe,purchase. So my father was dissuaded, and declined thé Earl's offer. 1 don't suppose that if he had accepted it the property would long hâve bëen his, but must have changed banda directly he bad doubled his investment otherwiae, imagine what a bargain waa there t-However, nobody can foresee anything beyond au inch or a minute, and so this other chance of weaith beyond the dreams of avarice long agbfaded away. Of this lecture, not to be tedious, 1 will here give only the peroration. And now, in conclusion, let us answer thèse reason-able questions What has Martin Luther done and sunered tbat we at this distant interval of four centuries should reverence his memory with gratitude and ad-miration ? What was the lifewôrk he was raised up to do, and bow did ho do it ? and what influence have his labours of old on thé times in which we live?-We must remember that in the sixteenth century priest-craf~ bad culminated to its rankest height of fraud, cruelty, vice, and superstition the lay-folk everywhere were its serfs and victims, not to mention also numbers of the worthier clerios who hated but could, not break their bonds. Luther was the solitary champion to head and lead both the remonstrant layman and the botter sort of monk up to the thon well-nigh forlorn hope of oombating Antiohrist in his stronghold Luther broke those chains for ever o~,the neoks~f groaning nations,. -freeing to this day from that bitter bondage not alone Germany, Sweden, France, and England, but thé very ends of the earth from America to China with-out the energies of Luther nearly four hundred years ago, and the living spirit of Luther working in us now, we should be still in our own persons adding to the Book of Martyrs in the flames of the Inquisition, still immersed in blankest ignorance, with the Bible every-where forbidden, and soientino research condemned, still cringing slaves at the feet of confessors who fraudu-lently sell absolution for money, still both spiritually and politically thé mean vassals of an Italian priest instead of brave freemen under our English Queen. Luther relit the well-nigh extinguished lamp of true religion, and'it shines for him all thé more gloriously to this hour Luther refreshed the gospel sait that had thrôugh corruption lost its savour, until now it is more antiseptic than ever as the cure of evil, more purifying than ever as the quickener of good Luther, under God's good grâce and providence, has rescued the con-.science and reason of our whole race from the thrald'om of self-elected spiritual despots, who worked upon the superstitious fears ôf mon as t6 another~worid in order to strengthen their own power in this Luther, for the resuit of his great labours, is more to us now thàn ever was the fabulous Hercules of old,-for he has cleansed the real Augoean stable,more than any mythiçal William Tell,-for he bas ensured the boon of ever-lasting liberty, more to us than a whole army Qf so-called heroes in conquest, patriotism, or even local philanthrôpy.-for the enemies he fought and van-quishod were our spiritual foes.-the country hé opened to us is thé heaveuly one.he good-doing he inaugurated is wide as the world, and shines an electric universal threefold light of faith, hope, and charity. I HAVE often been asked to prepare an autobiography, but my objections to the task have ever been many and various. To one urgent appeal I sent this sonnet of refusai, which explains itself@@ You bid me write the story of my life, And draw what secrets in my memory dwell From the dried fountains of her failing well, With commonpiaces mi~t of peaoe and strife, And such émail faots, with good or evil rife, As happen to us ail@@ have no tale Of thrilling force or enterprise to tell,-Nothing the blood to@.Rre, the ohoek to pale My life is in my books thé rooord there, A@truthful@photograph@.is@aIlIohoMe To give the world of self, nor will excuse Mine own or others' failures glad to spare From blâme of mine, or praise, both friends and foes, Leaviag@unwritton@whatCtod@only@knows. In fact 1 fdwaya rejocted thé proposai wa@med by récent volumes of pestilenfial réminiscences and,would none of it not only @'om its apparent vainglory as to the inevitable extenuation of one's own faults and failures in life, and the equally certain amplification of self-registered virtues and successes, but even still more from the misuhief it might occasion from a petty record of commonplace troubles and trials, due to the changes and chances of this mortal life, to the casual mention or omission of friends or foes, to the influence of circumstances and surroundings, and to other reve-lations~-whether pleasant or the reverse-of matters merely personal, and therefore more of a private than a public character. Indeed, so disquieted was I at the possible prospect of any one getting hold of a' mass of manuscript in old days diligently compiled by my~elf from year to year in several small diaries, that I have long ago ruthlessiy made a holocaust of the heap of such written self-mèmo-ries, fearing their posthumous publication and in this connection let me now add my express protest against the printing hereafter of any of my innumerable private letters to friends, or other MSS., unless they are'strictiy and merely of a literary nature. Biography, where honest and trne, is no doubt one of the most fascinating and instructive phases of litera-ture but it requires a higher Intelligence than. any however intimate friend of a man to do it fairly and fully so many matters of character and circumstance must ever be to him unknown, and therefore will be by him unrecorded. And even as to autobiography, who, short of the Omniscient Himself, can take into just account thé potency of outward surroundings, and still more of inborn hereditary influences, over both mind and body! thé biaa to good or evil, and thé possession or otherwise of gifts and talents,. due very-much under Providence to one's ancient ancestors and one's modern teaohers ? We are each of us morally and bodily the psychical and physical composite of a thousand generations. Albeit every individual pos-sesses as his birthright a@freewill to turn either to thé right or to the left, and is liable to a due responsibility for his words and actions, still the Just Judge alone can and must make allowance for the innate inclinings of heredity and the outward influences of circumstance, and He only can hold the balance between the guilt and innocence, the merit or demerit, of His créature. So far as my own~will goes, 1 leave my inner spiritual biography to the Recording Angel, choosing only to give some recollections and memories of my outer literary life. For spiritual self-analysis in matters of religion and affection 1 desire to be as silent as 1 can be but in such a book as this absolute taciturnity on such subjects is practically impossible. For the matter,. then, of autobiography, 1 decline its higher and its deeper aspects as also I@wish not to obtrude on the public eye mere domesticities and priva-oies of life, But inainly lest others less acquainted 'with. thé petty incidents of my career should hereafter take up the task, 1 accede with all @@anl ness and humility to what seems to me like a present oall to duty, having little time to spare at seventy-six, so near the end of my tether,-and protesting, as 1 well may@ against the charge bf se@insh egotism in a book neces-sarily@spotted on every page with the insignificant letter I and while~ of course on human-nature-principles, wi@Uing enough to exhi.bit myself at the best, promising also -not to hide the second best, or worse than that@ where@@loan perceive it.. That shrëwd old philosopher, Benjamin Franklin, thus excuses his own self-imposed task of autobiography, and 1 cannot do better than quote and adopt his wise and just remarks@@ In thus employing myself, 1 shall yield to thé in-clination so natural to old men, of talking of themselves and their own actions, and I shaJl indulge it without being tiresome to those who, from respect to my a~e, might conceive themselves obliged to listen to me, since they will always be @@ee to read me or not. And I may as well confess it, as the denial would be believed by nobody 1 shall, perhaps, not a little gratify my own vanity. Indeed, I never heard or saw the introduotory words, @Without vanity 1 may say,' c., but some vain. thing immediately followed. Most people dislik@ovanity in others, whatever share they may have of it them-selves but 1 give it fair quarter wherever 1 meet with it, being persuaded that it is often productive of good to the possessor, and to others who are within his sphère of action and there@ re, in many cases, it would not be altogether absurd if a man were to thank God for his @vanity@ among the other comforts of life. And now 1 speak of thanking God, 1 désire, with ail hunulity, to acknowledge that 1 attributë the happi-nesa of my past life to Bis divine providence, which led me to the means 1 used, and gave the success. My belief of this induces me to @hope@, though I must not @~fes@M~e, that the same gbodness will still be exeroised towards me in continuing that happiness or enabling me to bear a fatal reverse, which î may expérience as others have done the oomplexion of my future fortune being known. to Him only in whose power it is to. bless us, even in our a@fHictions. Thus speaketh the honest wisdom of Benjamin Franklin. I do not see that a better plan can be chosen for carry-ing out the title of this book than the one 1 have adopted, namely, tracing from the earliest years to old age the author's literary life-work, illustrated by accounts of, and spécimens from, his various books and writings, especially those which are absolutely oùt of print, or. haply have never been published. No doubt, in auch excerpts, exhibited at their best, the critical accusations of un@ irness, self-seeking, and so foith, will be'made, and may be met by the true considération that some-thing of this sort is inevitable in autobiography. How-ever, for the matter of vanity, ail 1 know of myself is the tact that praise, if consciously undeserved, only de-presses me instead of elating that a noted characteristie of mine through life bas been to hide away in the rosr rather than rush to the front, unless, indeed, forced for-wald by duty, when I can be bold enough, if need be and that one defect in me ail know to be a dislike to any assumption of dignity-surely a @@eling the opposite to self-conceit whilst, if I am not true, simple, and sin-cere, 1 am worse than I hope 1 am, and all my friends are deceived in their kind judgment of me. But let this book speak for itself 1 trust it is honest, charitable, and rationally religious. If 1 have and I show it tcrough aJl my writings a s of every denomination, that feeling I take to be due to some ancient heredity ingrained, or, ~nore truly, inburnt into my nature from sundry pre-Lutheran ooNfessors and martyrs of old, from whom I claim to be deacended, and by whose spirit 1 am imbued. Not but that.I profess myself broad, and wide, and liberal enough for ail manner of allowances to others, and so far as any narrow pre-judices may be imagined of my idiosyncrasy, 1 must allow myself to be changeable and uncertain-though hitherto having steered through life a fairly straight course-and that sometimes 1 can even doubt as to my politics, whether they should be defined Whig or Tory as to my religion, whether it is most truly chargeable by the epithet high or low as to my likings, whether 1 best prefer solitude or society as to literature, whether gaieties or gravities please me most. In fact, 1 recognise good in everything, though sometimes hidden by evil, right by intention, at least in sundry doctrines and opinions otherwise to my judgment wrong, and 1 am wifling to believe the kindliest of my opponents who appear to be honest and'ea@mest. This is a very @@ir creed for a citizen, of the world, whose motto is Terence's famous avowal, Homo sum, humani nihil a me alienum puto. CHAPTER II. INFANOY AND SOHOOLDAYS. IN a short and simple way, then, and without any desire ostentatiously to chronicle small béer, as lago sneers it, I suppose it proper to state very briefly when and where 1 was born, with a word as to my parentage. Ju y 17,@1810, was my birthday, and No. 20 Devonshire Place, Marylebone, my birthplace, at that time the last house of London northward. My father, Martin Tupper, a name ever honoured by me, was an eminent médical man, who twice refused a baronetcy first from Lord Liverpool, and secondiy, as offered by thé Duke of Wellington my mother, Ellin Devis Marris, being daughter of Robert Marris, a good landscape artist, of an old Litioolnshire family, and made the heiress, as adopted child, of her aunt, Mrs. Ellin Devis, of Devon-shire Place and Albury. My father's family have sojourned 336 years in Guernsey, having migrated thither from Thuringia, @t'KÏ Hesse Cassel, owing to religious persécution in the evil days of Charles V., our remote ancoators being styled Von Topheres chieftains, or head-lords of Treffurth as is recorded in the horaldic MSS. of the British Museum , that being the origin of our name. Of my mother's family in old time Maris, as of the sea, with mermaids for heraldry , 1 have the commis-aions of one who was an Ironside cavalry o@@mcer, signed by Cromwell and Fairfax and several of her relatives besides her father were distinguished artists. In par-ticular, her uncle my wife's father , Arthur William Devis, the well-known historical painter, and her great-uncle, Anthony Devis, who filled Albury House with his landscapes. Somo of our old German stock crossed the Atlantic in Puritan times, and many of the name have, attained 'wealth and position both in Canada and thé Ùnited Statea notably Sir Charles Tupper northwards, and sundry rich merchants in New York, Virginia, and the Carolines southwardiy. Of my in@ ncy let me record that 1 enjoyed very délicate health, chie@ny due, as I now judge, to the con-stant cuppings and bleedings whereby thé faou@Hy of those days combated teething @nts, and perhaps with Malthusian proclivities killed off young chiidren. 1 remember, too, that thé broad meadows, since developed into Regënt's Park and Primrose Hill, then- truly rural, and even up to Chalk Farm, then notorious for duels, were my nursery ramblings in search of cowslips and new milk. Another infantile recollection is mémorable, as thus. My father's annual lioliday happened one year to be at Bognor, where a patron@patiéiit ôf his, Lord Arran, rented a pleasant villa, and he h'ad ~br a visitor at thé tim@ono lésa a personago than George thé Third it .must hâve been during some lucid interval, perhaps after the Great Thanksgiving at St. Paul's. My father took his little boy with him to call upon the Ear!, not thinking to see the Eing but when we came in there was his kind-hearted Majesty, who patted my curis and gave me his blessing 1 How far the mysterious efficacy of the royal touch affected my after career believers in the divine rights and spiritual powers of a king may speculate as' they please.. At all events I got a good man's blessing. I remember also in my nursery days to have heard this curious story of a dream. My father, when a young man, was a student at Guy's Hospital, from which school of medicine he went to Yarmouth to attend the wounded after the battle of Copenhagen. He was on one occasion leaving Guernsey for Southampton in the clumsy sea-going smack of those days, when, on the night before embarking, he dreaint, that on his way to the harbour he crossed the churchyard and fell into an open grave. Telling this to his parents at The Pollet, they would not let him go, with a sort of superstitions wiedom for, strangely enough, the smack was seized on ita voyage by a privateer, and all the crew and passengers were consigned-for twelve years-to a French prison 1 1 have heard my father tell this tale, and noted early how true was Dr. Watts' awkward line, On little things what great depend. I might say more about warn@mgs in dreams and other somnolencies, whereof we all have expériences. For instance, my Dream of Ambition in Proverbial Philosophy was a real one. And this re-minds me now of another like sort of spiritual monition alluded to in my Proverbial Essay on Truth in Things False, whioh bas several times occurred to myself, as this, for example Years ago, in Devonshire, for the first time, 1 was on the top of a coach passing through a town-I think it was Crediton-and 1 had the strangé feeling that 1 had seen all this before now, we changed horses just on this sida of a cross street, and 1 resolved within myself to test the truth of the place being new to me or not, by prophesying what 1 should see right and left as we passed to my consternation it was all as 1 had foreseen,-a market-place with the usual incidents. Now, if reasonably asked how to account for this and most of us have felt the like , I reply that possibly in an elevated state of health and spirits the soul may out-run the body, and literally foresee coming events both real and ideal. But we must leave this to the Psychical Society for a judgment upon the famous Horatian philo-sophy of more things in heaven and earth, c. On Mr. Galton's topic of hereditary talent 1 have little to report as to myself. Neither father nor mother had any leanings either towards verse or prose but my mother was an excellent pianiste and a fair landscape painter both in oils and water-colour also she drew and printed on stone, and otherwise showed that she came of an artistic family. As to my @@ther's surroundings, his brother Peter, a consul-général in Spain, wrote a tragedy ca@Ued Pelayo and 1 possess half-a-dozen French songs, labelled by my father in my late dear father's handwriting, but whether or not original, 1 cannot tell. As a Guernsoyman, he might well be as much Frenoh as English. They seem to me clever and worthy of Beranger, though long before him possibly they are my grandsire's. A very fair judge of French pootry., and himself a good Norman poet, Mr. John Sullivan of Jersey writes and tells me that the songs are excellent, and that he remembers them to have been popularly sung when he was a boy. About the matter of hereditary bias itself, we know that as with animais so with men, fortes creantur for-tibus, et bonis this so far as bodies are conce@med but surely spirits are more individual, as innumerable instances prove, where children do not take after their parents. If, however, I may mention my own small ex-perience of this matter, literary talent, or at all events aùthorship, @is@ hereditary, especially in these days of that general epidemic, the cacoethes scribendi. I wrote this paper following originally@for an American publication and as I cannot improve upon it, and it has never been printed in England, I produce it here in its integrity. A true and genuine record of what English schools of the highest class were more than sixty-five years ago cannot fail to have much to interest the present genera-tion on both sides of the Atlantic if only because we may now indulge in thé self-complacency of being every-way wiser, bétter, and happier than our recent forebears. And in setting myself to write thèse early revelations, 1 wish at once to state that, although at times neces-sarily naming names for the too ireq~ent use of dashes and asterisks must otherwise destroy the verisimilitude of plain truth-telling , I desire to say nothing against or for either the dead or the living beyond their just déserts, and 1 protest against any charge of unreason-abio want of charity as to my whilom schools and sohoolmasters, It is true that sometimes 1 loved them not, neither can I in general respect their memory but thé causes of such a feeling on my part sha@H be made ma@mfest amon, and 1 am sure that mode@m parents and guardians will rejoice that much of my childhood's hard expérience bas not been altogether that of their own boys. I was sent to school much too soon, at the early âge of seven, having previously had for my home tutor a well-remembered day-teacher in little Latin and lèse Greek of the name of -Swallow, whom I thought a wit and a poet in those days because one niorning he pro-duced as an epitaph on himself the following effusion Beneath this atone a Swallow lies, No one laughs and no one cries Where he is gone or how he fares No one knows and no one oares. At this time of day I suspect this epigram not to be quite original, but it served to give me for the nonce a. high opinion of the pundit who read with me Cornelius .Nepos and Csesar and some portions of that hopeless grammar, the Eton Greek, in thé midst of his hard-breathing consumption of perpétuai sandwiches and béer. The @nrst school chosen for me though expensive, .there could not have been a worse' one was@@ large mixed establishment for boys of all ages, from infancy to early manhood, belonging to one Rev. Dr. Morris of Eggles@Ëeld House, Brentford Butta, whioh I now judge to have been conducted solely with a view to the pro-prietor's pocket, without reference to the morals, happi-ness, or education of the pupils committed to his care. A@U 1 care to remember of this false priest and there werë many such of old, whatever may be the ca~e now are his cruel punishments, which passed for discipline, bis careful cringing to parents, and his careless indi1fer-ence towards their children, and in brief bis total un6t-ness for the twin duties of pastor and teacher. A large private school of mixed ages and classes is perilously liable to infection from licentious youths left to them-selves and their evil propensities, and 1 can feelingly recollect how miserable for nearly a year was that poor little helpless innocent of seven under the unrestricted tyranny of one Cooke in after years a life convict for crime who did ail he could to pollute the infant mind of the little fag delivered'over to his cruelty. Cowper's Tirocinium well expresses thé situation @@Would you your son should be a sot or dunoe, Lasoivious, headstrong, or all these at once, Train him in publie with a mob of boys, Childish in misohief only and in noise, Elae of a mannish growth and, five in ten, For infidelity and lewdness, men. My next school was. more of a success for Eagle House, Brookgreen, where 1 was from eight to eleven, had for its owner and headmaster a most worthy and excellent layman, Joseph Railton. Mr. Railton was gentle, though gigantic, fairly learned, just and kindly. His school produced, amongst others eminent, the fitmous naval author Kingston, well known from cabin-boy to admirai there was also Lord Paulet, some others of noble birth, and thé two Middletons, nick-named Taukees, whom years after 1 visited at their rained mansion in South Carolina after thé Confederate War. 'fhrough.the personal good influence of'honest Old Joe, and hie middle-aged housekoeper, Mrs. Jones, our whole well-ordëred@company@of@perhaps@a@hundred boys lived and learned, workod and played purely@ and happily together so great a social benefactor may a good school chieftain be. I have little to regret in my Brook Green recollections the annual fair was mémorable with Richardson's show and Gingel's conjuring, and the walks for mild cricket-ing at Shepherd's Bush, and the occasional Sundays at home and how pleasant to a schoolboy was thé generous visitor who tipped him, a good action never forgotten. and the garden with its flowering tulip-tree, and the syringaa and rose-trees jewelled with the much-prized emerald May-bugs for the whole garden was liberally thrown open to us beyond the gravelled playground all being now given. over to monks and nuns. My next school at eleven was Qharterhouse, or as my schoolfellow Thackeray was wont to style it, Slaughtër. house, no doubt from the cruel tyranny of another educational D.D., the Rev. Dr. Russell. For this .man and the school he so despotioally drilled into passive servility and pedantio scholarship, I have less than no révérence, for he worked so upon an over-sensitivë nature to force a boy beyond his powers, as to fix for many years the infirmity of stammering, which waa my affliction until past middle life. As for tuition, it must all have grown of itself by dint of private hard grinding with dictionaries and grammars, for the exercises, themes, and other lessons were,notoriously difficult, and those before me would be inextricable puzzles now however, we had to do them, and we did them, unhelped by any teacher but our own iridustry. As for the masters in school, two more ignorant old parsons than Chapman and Bob Watki could not readily be found and though the four others, Lloyd, Dickens, Irvine, and Penny were somewhat more intelligent, still aJl six in the lower school were occasionally summoned to a concio, if the interprétation of any ordinary passage in Homer or Virgil or Horace was haply in dispute between a monitor and his class. As to the exclusively @dassic education in my young days, to the resolute neglect of all other languages and sciences, I for myself have from youth upwards always protested against it as mainly waste of time a.nd of very little service in the battle of life. For proof of this, before 1 waa eighteen, I wrote that essay on Education to be seen in my first series of Proverbial Philosophy, whieh long years after the celebrated Dr. Binney of the Weigh-house in Thames Street issued with my leave as a tractate useful. to the present génération. And while there was so much fuss made as to the criminality of a false quantity in Greek, or a déficient acquaintance with those awkward verbs in ~ii, or above ail a fa se con-cord every one of which derelictiona in duty @mv@dved severe punishment , let us remember that all this time Holywell Street was su@nered to infect Charterhouse with its poison I speak of long ago, before Lord Camp-bell's wholesome Act , and that our clerical tutors and governors profëssionally recognised no sort of sins or shortcomings but those committed in classt 1 They practically ignored everything out of school, much as a captain knows nothing of his company off duty. It was the idle system of boys set to govern boys, that the masters might hâve no damage. 1 think the system was called Lancastrian. One very noticeable trait in the pajson-schoohnasters of those old days and perhaps it still survives was the subserviency to rank and wealth towards any pupils likèly to give them livings, whereof more anon at présent, an appropriate instance ocours to me. 1 was in my thirteenth year monitor of the playground, when one Dillon, a scion of a titled family, hunted and killed a stray dog there, and much to their credit for humanity a number of other boys hunted and pelted @him@ into a dry ditch or vallum, dug for the leaping-pole under a Captain Cliaa who taught us athletics. 1 was technicaJIy responsible for this open insult offored to Hibe@miam nobility, however well disposed to look another way and let lynch-law take its course.' Accord-ingly, the Doctor had me up for punishment, and he inflicted an almost impossible imposition, Book Epsilon of the Iliad the longest of ail to be translated word for word, English and Greek, and to be given to him in MS. within a month it would have been work for a year , that or expulsion. Had Mr. Dillon been a plebeian, no notice would have been taken of the matter, but he was an honourable, so Russell@must a avenge his-righteous punishment. However, the result of this outrageous set-task was curious and worthy of this ita first and only record. A@U the seventy boys in Irvine's house and others elsewhere, volunteered to do the whole imposition for me, and within a week hundreds of pages closely written with Greek and Latin, were sewn together, making a large quarto pamphlet, whioh was duly handed by me to the won-dering Doctor who had, however, too much shrewd-ness to care to inquire closely as to this popular out-burst of a general indignation, so, he said nothing more about it. For other playground réminiscences I saw, even in those tame times for cricket when overhand bowling was illegal, and the fierce artillery of a Spofforth im-possible, a poor lad killed in the field, one Honourable Benry Howard he was taken to the pump for recovery, as from a swoon, but the bail had struck.him behind the ear, stone-dead. One remarkable playground experience was the fact that it helped to dévelop in me antiquarian inclina-tions, and my own discoyered hunting-ground for Homan numismatics in the south of Englahd, long after~ wards expanded in Farley Heath near Albury. At Charterhouse there was a great slope or semi-mound which had in old times been utilised as a wholesale grave for the victims of plague and other épidémies. It strikes me now as most perilous, but we boys used. to dig and scratch among bones and other @@~ r@@M for an occasional coin or lead token, whereof I found several it is only a wonder that we did not unearth pestilence, but mould is fortunately very antiseptic. Another playground peculiarity was that after the hoop season, usually driven in duplicate or triplicate, the hoops were stored or shied into the branching elms, from wbich they were again brought down by hockey-sticks flung at them a great boon to the smaller boys who thus gratuitously. became possessed of valuable properties. Poor@Mr. Irvine who was going to be married mended up@, very much smashed greenhouse to greet his bride thereby with floral joy. Unluckily, the boys preferred broken panes to whole ones, so nothing was easier than by flinging brickbats and even mugs over the laundry wall to revel in the sweet sound of smashed glass moreover this would go to evidence the popular animosity against a wretched bridegroom. Then, when he reappeared aftèr some temporary absence before the wedding, it was after this ridiculous fashion. There was a wooden staircase screened off one side of the long-room down which he would occasionally creep to listen at the door at bottom to the tattle of the boys about him. Ee was heard creaking downstairs, and some active young fellow by a round-about byway managed to steal down behind and suddenly pushed him by the burst open door, spread-eaglé fashion, into the laughing long-room f The poor victim pretended it was an acci-dent, Ye see, Mr. Yates, I was coming down the stair, and me foot slipped. It seems that the luckless Andrew was coming, so he averred, expressly to expostulate'with thé boys, to throw himself on their generosity for a subscription towards his ruined greenhouse, and to ask Messrs. Punsonby, Yates, Co. to promote it. This they promiséd to do, and did after an original fashion. Soveral pounds worth of pence and half-pence were dis-tributed through the house, so that when Andrew with his traitorous aides went round to collect monies, it miraculously@happened to be all coppers, unrelieved by @@single sparkle of silver or gold. On which, in a red rage and he often was in the like he flung the whole bowlful into the long-room fire, from the ashes whereof for days after the small boys gladly collected hot half-pence.. We must recollect that the canny Scot was a mean over-reaching man, so perhaps he was well paid out. Soon after the wedding, the bridegroom held high festival, and gave a grand dinner to all tho masters. Our big boys were equal to the occasion, and as the hired waiters from thé Falcon brought out the viands all was a delusive peace as they went in our harpies flew upon the spoil, and each meat, fish and fowl was cleared off the great dishes held between the helpless hands of the astonished servitors I It was really too bad, but if a man is so manifestly unpopular no doubt he deserves it. Rugbeians would not have so served Arnold. In 1832, my journal about Dorsetshire and the Isle of Wight is chiefly geological as this extract shows, it was mainly a search after fossil spoils at Char. mouth@@ Would you like to see a creature with the head of a lizard, wings of a bat, and tail of a serpent ? î Such things have been, as these bones testify they are called Pterodactyls, and are as big as ravens. Thus, you see, a dragon is no chimera, but attested by a science founded on observation, Geology. As their bones known by their hollowness often occur in thé coprolites or fossil dung of Plesiosauri, mighty monsters of the deep like gigantic swans, it is thought they were their spécial prey,'for which the long and flexible neck of the Plesiosaurus is au @à priori@ argu-ment, c. c. On the summit of a. steep hill of con-glomerate rock we could trace very clearly a double oblong enclosure of eighty yarda by twenty, with entrances east and west, a spaëe of @nve yards being between the two oblongs. Thé mounds were outwardly of turf, but uuder a thin skin of this was a thick con-tinuous wall of molten stone, granité, gneiss, and sand-atone, bubbling together in a hotchpot 1 Thé existence of these forts occurring frequently on the heights and of various shapes is attempted to be explained by divers theories. One man tells us they were beacons but, @nrst, what an enormous one is here, one hundred and twenty-four feet by sixty of blazing wood, timber being scarce too@ next, they sometimes occur in low situa-tions from which a flame could scarcely be seen thirdly, common wood fire will not melt granite. Another pundit says they are volcanic. 0 wondrous volcano to spout oblong conoentric areas of stone walls 1 Perhaps the best explanation is that the Celts cemented these hilltops of strongholds by means of coarse glass, a sort of red-hot mortar, using sea-sand and seaweed as a flux. This is Professor Whewell's idea, and with him we had some interesting conversation on that and other sub-jects. Of this Scotch tour, full of interest, thus very curtiy. Tu@m we now to Ireland in 18@~. My record of just fifty years ago is much what it might be now, starvation, beggary, and human wretchedness of all sorts in the midst of a rich land, through indolence relapsed into a jungle of thorns and briars, quaking bogs@ and sterile mountains whisky, and the idle un-certain potato, combining with ignorance and priest-craft, to démoralise the excitable unreasoning race of mode@m Celts. Let us turn from the sad scenes of which my said diary is full, to my day at the spar caverns of Kingston. At@tho bottom of a stone quarry, we clad ourselves in sack garmonts that mud wouldn't spoil, and with lit candles descended into the abyss, hands, knees, and elbows being of as much service as our feot. Now, I am not going to map my way after the manner of guido-books, nor to nickname 'thé gor-geous architecture of nature according to the caprice of a rude peasant on the spot or the fancy of a passing stranger. 1 might @nll a page with accounts of Turks' tents, beehives, judges' wigs, harps, handkerchiefs, and flitches of bacon, but 1 rather choose to speak of thèse subterranean palaces with none of such vulgar similari-ties. No one ever@saw such magni@neence in stalactites from the black fissured roofs of antres vast and low-browed caves they are hanging, of all conceivable shapes and sizes and descriptions. Now a tall-@~uted column, nôw a fringed canopy, now like a large white sheet flung over a beetling rock in the elegant folds and easy drapery of a curtain, everywhere are pure white stalactites like icicles straining to meet the sturdier mdunds of stalagmite below whilst in the smaller caves slender tubes extend from top to bottom like congealed rain. One cavern is qùite curtaihed round ivith@dazzting@and@waTy@tàpestry another has gigantic masses of the white spar pouring from its crannied roof like boiled Brobdingnag macaroni others like heâps of snowy linen lying about or hanging from the ceiling. The extent of the caves is quite unknown eleven acres I was told have been surveyed and mapped, while there are six avenues still unexplored, and you may already wander for twenty-four hours through the dis-covered provinces of the gnome king. This is not to be compared with Kentucky, perhaps not quite with Derbyshiro but it seemed to me marvellous. at the time. F. T. JN 1829 1 was entered as a commoner at Christ Cburch, Oxford, and went through the usual course of lectures with fair success. Enough, sad Muse, enough thy downward @night Has oleft with wearied wing the shades of night Be drest in smiles, forget the gloomy past, And, cygnet-like, sing sweeter at the last, Strike on the ohords of joy a happier strain And be thyself, thy oheerful self, again. Cer-tainly such an easy concession was one of my earliest literary triumphs. My first acquaintance with Gladstone, whom 1 have known from those college days now for more than five and @6fty years, was a memorable event, and may thus be worthy of mention. It was at that time not a common thing for undergraduates to go to the com-munion at Christchurch Cathedral-that holy célébra-tion being supposed to be for the particular benefit of Dean and Canons, and Masters of Arts. So when two undergraduates went out of the chancel together after communion, which they had both attended, it is small wonder that they addressed each other genially, in defiance of Oxford etiquette, nor that a friendship so well begun has continued to this hour. Not that 1 have always approved of my friend's politics multi-tudes of letters through many years have passed be-tween us, wherein if 1 have sometimes ventured to praise or to blame, 1 have always been answered both gratefully and modestly but 1 have ever tried to hold the balance equally too, according to my lights, and if at one time on occasion of the great Oxford election, 1864 1 published a somewhat famous copy of verses, ending with Il Orator, statesman, soholar, wit, and sage, The Orichton,-more, the Gladstone of the age, my faithfulness must in after years confess to a well-known palinode one of my Three Hundred Sonnets commencing Beware of mere delusive eloquenoe, and a still more caustio lyric, beginning with Glozing tongue whom none oan trust, and so forth, as a caution against a great man's special gift, so proverbiailly dangerous. Some of our most honest Ministers, @@@6.@@ Althorpe and Wellington, have been very bad speakers some of our most eloquent oratora have proved very bad Ministers. And in this place 1 may introduce some account, long ago in print, of the famous Aristotle class under thé tutorship of Mr. Biscoe at Christ Church, wherein among far nobler and botter scholars your present confessor took the lowest seat. Fifty years ago Biscoe's Aristotle class at Christ Church was comprised almost wholly of men who have since become celebrated, some in a remarkable degree and, as we believe tbat so many namea, afterwards attaining to great distinction,~ have rarely been asso-ciated at one lecture-board, either at Oxford or elae-where, it may be allowed to oné who counts himself the least ond lowest of the company to pen thia brief note of those old Aristotelians. ONE of the apparent calamities of my life overruled, as 1 have long since seen, for good was thé before-mentioned affliction of a very bad impediment of speech, which blighted my youth and manhood from fifteen to thirty@.nve, obliging me to social humiliations of many kinds, to silence in class and on examination occasions hence my written poetries in lieu of spoken prose , and in early manhood preventing me from taking orders, and tLereafter from speaking in the law courts. Chess is a chief intellectual resource to.the stammerer for therein he oan conquer in argument without the toil of speech, and prove himself practically more eloquent' than the men full of talk whom he so much envies. Accordingly, in days gone by for of late years 1 have given it up, as too toilsome a récréation 1 played often at that royal game. In these times it is no game at all, -but a wearisome if seductive science just as cricket ia an artillery combat now, and football a most perilous conflict, and boating breaks the athlete's heart, and billiards eau only be played by a bar-spot professional, and tronquil whist itself Las developed into a semi-fraudulent system of open raies and secret signs even so the honest common-sense old game of chess bas come to be so encumbered with pub@Ssbed openings and gam-bits and other parasitic growths upon the wholesome house-pJant, that 1 for one have renounced it, as a pur-suit for which life is too ahort and serious give me a farce or a story instead , and one moreover in which any fool well up to crammed book games may crow over thé wisest of men in an easy, because stereotyped, check-mate. And this word rhyme rominds me now of a very curious question 1 raised some years a~ter my Oxford days in more than one magazine article, as to when rhyme was invented, and by whom the con-clusion being that intoning monks found out how easily the cases of Latin nouns and tenses of verbs, c., jingled with each other, aud that troubadours and trouveres carried thus the seeds of song all over Europe in about the ninth century, until which time rhythm was the only recognised form of versification, rhyme having strangely escaped discovery for more than four thousand years. Is it not a marvel and another marvel that no one noticed it before that not one of the old poets, Hebrew, Greek, Latin, and I think Sanscrit, Arabie, and Celtio too, ever except by manifest accident, now intentionally ignored stumbled upou the good idéa of terminating their metrea with rhyme ? 1 Where is there any ode of Horace, or Anacreon,-wbere any psalm of David, any epigram of Martial, any heroic verse of Virgil, or -philosophie argument of Lucretius,-deco-rated, enlivened, and brightened by the now oniy too frequent ornament of rhyme ? 1 1 have just found among my old archived papers, faded by nearly six decades of antiquity, a treatise which I wrote at nineteen, styled by me Il A Vindication of the Wisdom of Soripture in Matters of Natural Science. Some years ago he purobased a house at Brighton. While laying out the garden, he bad occasion to have several drains made. One day observing a workman, Francis Suter, standing in one of the trenches wet and wearied with toil, Mr. Tupper said to bim in a tone of pleasantry, 'Vouidn't you like to dig up there a orock full of gold?@@'If I did,' said the man, 'it would do me no good,.because merely @nnding@it would not make it mine.@@ But suppose you could not only find such a treasure, but might honestly keep it, wouidn't you think yourself lucky@ -'Oh yes, Bir, I suppose 1 should -but,' after a pnuse, 'but 1 am not so sure, sir, that it is the best thing that could happen to me. 1 think, on the whole, I would rather have steady work and fair wages all the season than find a crock of gold.' Here was wisdom. The remark of the honest trench-digger at once set iu motion a train of thought in the mind of the author. Ho entered his study, wrote in large letters on a sheet of paper these words, THE OBOOK OF GoLD, a Tale of Covetousness,' and in less than a week that remarkable story was written. By the advice of his wife, however, he spent another week in rewriting it, and then gave it to the world in its finished state. The Alfred Jubilee, on that great king's thou-sandth@year, 1848, is one of thé exploits of my literary life, undertaken and accomplished by Mr. Evelyn, the brothers Brereton, Dr. Giles, and myself in thé year 1848, ohiefly at Wantage, where Alfred was born. We arranged meetings and banqueta in several places, notably Livorpool, where Mr. Bramwell Moore, the mayor, gave a great feast in commemoration, a medal was struok, thé Jubilee édition of King Alfred's works was at least begun at Dr. Oiles's private printing-press, whilst at Wantage itself 20,000 people @ooUeotod @@om all parts for old English games, speeohes, appropriate sbhgs, such as To-day is the day of a thousand years from my pen, collections for a local school and college as a lasting mémorial, and-to please the commonalty-a gorgeous procession and an ox roasted whole, with gilded horns and ribbons,-the huge carcase turned like a hare on a gigantic spit by help of a steam-engine before a furnace of two tons of blazing coal and that ox waa consumed after a most barbarie Abyssinian iashion in the open air. My Anglo-Saxon Magazine came out strong on the occasion,-but it'is obsolète now and 1 care not to use up space in reprinting patriotic indigna-tion for lot me state that, considered as a national commemoration of the Great King, the chief founder of our liberties, this Wantage jubilee was all bat a failure the British lion slumbered, and it was flogging a dead horse to try to wake him up very iew of the magnates j'eaponded to our appeal but we did our best, neverthe-less, as independent Englishinen, and locally achieved a fair@success. TRANSLATIONS AND PAMPHLETS. THE best of my unpublished MSS. of any size or conséquence is perhaps my translation of Book Alpha of the Iliad, quite literal and in its original metre of hexameters hitherto 1 hâve failed to find a publisher kind enough to lose by it for there are already at !east twelve English versions of Homer unread, per-haps unreadable. Still, some day 1 don't despair to gain an enterprising Sosius for my literal and hexa-metrical translation is almost what Carthusians used to call Il a crib, and perhaps some day the School Board or their organ, Mr. Joseph Hughes's @Praètical Teacher@, may adopt my version. Its origin and history is this @Rûding winter evonings in the country wearisome to my homeflock, 1 used to read to thein profusely and dis-cursively. Amongst other books, a literary daughter suggested Popo's Homër whioh, as 1 read, after a little while, 1 found to be so very @@ee and incorrect a transla-tion if my memory served me rightiy that 1 resolved to see what 1 could do by reading from the original Greek in its own Euglish metre. 1 soon found it quite easy to be both terse and literal and having rhythm o.nly to care for withôut the tag of rhyme, 1 soon pleased my hearers and in some sort myself, reading o6f thé réel direotly@from the Greek@iuto the English. WHEN î returned in the autumn of 1855 from my prin-cipal continental tour, wherein for three months 1 had conductéd my whole family of eleven servants inclu-sive ail through the usual route of French and Swias travel,-I committed my journal ta Hatchard, who forthwith published it but not to any signal success,-for it was anonymous, whioh was a mistake however, I did not care to make public by name all the daily details of my homéflock pilgrimage. The pretty little, book with its fine print of thé P@Ma of Gondo as a frontispiece, nevertheless made its way, and bas been inserted in Mr. Gregory's liât of guide-books as a conve-nience if not a necessity to travellers on the same roads, though in these days of little practical use indeed, wherever we stopped, I contrived to exhaust, on the spot all that was to be seen or donc, with the advan-tages of persoual inspection, and therefore of graphie and true description. Thé book has been praised for ita ih-terest and includes divers accidents, happily surmounted, divers exploits in the milder form of Alpine climbing as thé Mauvais Pas, which 1 tou,ch experimentally at the end of Life's Dessous, in Proverbial Philosophy, Séries IV. , divers grand sights, as the Great Exhibition, CHÀPTEB XX close to which we lived for some weeks in the Champs Ëlysëes, and many pleasant incidents, as greetings with friends, old and new, and other usual @memorabilia@. Among these let me mention the honest kindliness of Courier Pierre,-always called Pere by my children, with whom he was a great favourito-thé more readily because he bas long gone to the bourne whenco no traveller returns, so he needs no recommendation from bis late employer. This, then, 1 say is memorable. At Lucerne, as my remittance from Herries failed to reach me, I seemed obliged to make a stop and to return but Pierre objected, saying it was gréât pity not to pass the Simplon and see Milan,-and, if Monsieur would permit him, he could lend whatever was needful, and could be paid again. Certainly I said this was very kind, and ao 1 borrowed at his solioitation -it was ~100, as 1 find by the journal our travel was costing us @~o a week. 'Wo!l, to recount briefly, when, after having placed in our 'ep6f Mf6 Bellinzona, Como, Milan, c. c., I found myself at Geneva, and with remittances awaiting me, my first act was to place in Pierre's hands @~'t0~and when he counted the notes, he said, Sare, there is one five-pound too many.@@ Of course, my worthy Pierre, 1 hope you will accept that as interost.@@@Non, Monsieur, pardon 1 could not, 1 always bring money to help my families -and he would not. Now, if that was not a model oourier, worthy to be commemorated thus,-well, @@hope there are soma othera of hia brethren on the o@@moe-books of Bury Streot, St. James's, who are equallyduteoua and disintorested. One of our spirited'wheelers got his hind leg over the pole in going down a hill at once there was a chaos of fallen horses and entangled harness, and but for the screw machine drag looking both hind-wheels we must have been upset and smashed,-as it was, the sorambling and kicking at @nrst was frightfui but Pater-familias dragged the younger children out into the road, and other help was nigh at hand, and the providential calm that comes over fa@Uen horses after their initiatory struggle was at hand too, and in due time matters were righted that those two fiery stallions did not kick everything 'to pièces, and that all four steeds did not gallop us to destruction, was due, under Providence, to the skill and courage of our good Pierre and the patient Muscate@Ui.@@Baiiways have since superseded all this peril, and cost, and care and trains now go @through@ the Simplon, instead of good horses, six to the heavy carriage, four to the light one, pulling us steadily and, slowly @over@ it thus losing the splendid scenery climaxed by the Devil's Bridge but let moderns be thankful. Paterfamilias's Diary bas long been out of print, and its author is glad .that he made at the time a fu@U record of thé happy past@ and recommends its perusal to any one who can find a copy anywhere. NEVER GIVE UP, AND SOMB OTHER BALLADS. SuNDBY of my short lyrics have gained a great popu-larity in particular Never give up, whereof there are extant-or were-no fewer than eight musical settings. Of this ballad, three stanzas, 1 have a strange story to tell. When I went to Philadelphia, on my @Brat American tour in ï 851, 1 was taken everywhere to see everything amongst others to Dr. Kirkland's vast in-stitute for the insane let me first state that he was not previously told of my coming visit. When 1 went over the various wards of the convalescents, 1 noticed that on each dodr was a printed placard with my Never give up upon it in full. Naturally I thought it was doue so out of compliment. But on inquiry, Dr. Eirk-land didn't know who the author was, aud little suspected it was myself. He had seen the verses, anônymous, in a newspaper, and judging them a good moral dose of hopefulness evon for the half insane, placed thom ou every door to excellent effeot. Whon to his astonish-ment ho found the unknown author bèfore him, greatly pleased, he asked if l would allow the patients, to thank me of course I complied, and soon was surrounded by kneeling and weeping and kisaing folks, grateful for the good hope my verses had helped them to. It may count as one of my heresies in an orthodox theological sensé, but I certainly cling to the great idea of Eternal Hope and, after any amount of retributive punishment for purifying thé loat soul, 1 look for ultimate salvation to all God's creatures. This short and partial trial-soene of ours is not enough to make an end with we begin here and progress for ever else-where. Evil must die out, and good must survive alone for ever. To gratify an eminent friend who wished not to ex-clude Jews and Mahometans from an open profession of godiiness as they viewed the question, I altered, in subséquent reprints, the last line, Christian and Pro-testant'in life and light, to Loving and fearing God in faith and light though personally my sturdy Orangeism inclined to the original. I will in this place give a remarkable extract in a letter to me from Glad-stone, to whom my faithfulness had appealed, exhorting him, as I often have donc, to be on the right side we know how he quoted Luoretius on the wrong against which 1 wrote a strong protest in the @@~M@M~. I like not to show private letters,-but this is manifestly a public one. He says I thank you for your note, and I oan assure you that I believe the promoters of the Affirmation Bill to be already on thé side you wish me to take, and its opponents to be engaged in doing un-wittingly serious injury to religious belief. It is strango to see how muoh intellectual subtlety combined with interested partisanship can be self-deceived, oven in a man who believes himself and is thought by others thoroughly conscientious. Amongst other of my récent notorious ballads of thé polemic sort, 1 ought to name a. famous couple@ The Nun's Appeal, and Open the Convents -which were written at the request of Lord Alfred Churchill, and given to Edith O'Gorman, the Escaped Nun otherwise the excellent and eloquent Mrs. Auffray , to aid her Protestant Lectures everywhere she bas circulated them over the three kingdoms, and is now doing the like in Australia and New Zealand. In reply to some excellent members of the Romish Church, who have publicly accused me of maligning holy women and sacred retreats, my obvious answer is that 1 contend against thé ovil side both of nunneries and monkeries, whilst 1 may fairly admit some good to be found in both. My real protest is for liberty both to mind and body, and against coercion of any kind, material or spiritual. Given perfect freedom, 1 would not meddle with any one's honest convictions to a nunnery go if thou wilt only let the resolve be revocable, not a doom for over.
