Among my twelve dramatic scènes, the most ap-propriate to mention in thie volume of peraonalia, are the two which détail certain periloua matters a@neoting the. lives of two anoient anoestora~ the one on my mother's aide, the other on my father's. The latter records the historie incident whereby John Tupper saved the Channel Islands for William and Mary re-ceiving from them a gold oollar and medal, now in our heraldry and enabling Admirai Russell to win hia naval victory at La Hogue, The former shows how nearly an Arthur Devis at Preston paid the penalty of death owing .to his strange resemblance to Charles Edward the Young Pretender, for whom the savage Government of the time offered a reward of ~30,000 to any one who could catch him alive or dead. My mother's ancestor was thus very nearly murdered in !74@ for his good looks, as a life-sized portrait at Albury, and an ivory miniature here at Norwood, help to prove. Some of our @nnds were very ourious, @e@@.@@ we were digging in the blick mould of the burrit o buts round thé wall-foundation.3 all above ground of said hectagonal wall having since been ruthlessiy utilised by parochial economists in making a road across the heath , and found amongst other spoil a little green bronze ring,-whieh 1 placed on the finger of our guest of the day, Mrs. Barclay of Bury Hill oddly enough it had six angles exactly like one of gold she wore as her wedding-guard. Again we had picked up some pieces of pottery decorated with human @ncger-tips,-just as, modern cooks do with pie-crust a son of mine said, perhaps we shall find a dog's foot on some tile,-and just as he said it, up came from the spàde precisely what he was guessing at, the large foot-print of dog or wolf stamped fifteen centuries ago on the unbaked clay. Again I was leaving for an hour a labourer in whose industry and honesty I had not the fullest faith. So in order to employ him in my absence, I set him to dig up an old thorn bush and told him to give me when I returned the piece of money he would find under it. AuTHORSHiP reaps honour in these latter days quite as much as it did in the classic times of Augustns with Virgil and Horace for his intimates, and of Petrarch crowned at the Capitol laureate of all Italy during thé vacancy of a popedom in the Vatican. Not but that, with or without any titular distinction, authorship is practically the most noticeable rank amongst us. Many will pass by a duke who would have stopped and waited to have looked at a Darwin when he was in this lower sphère and I am quite sure that the grand présence of Alfred Tennyson would attract more affectionate hom-age than that of any other ennobled magnate in the land. As to his title, I was glad that his good taste and wisdom elected to be called by his own honourable patronymic rather than haply Farringford or Hazlemere how can great names consent to be eclipsed in such obscure signatures as Wantage or Esher, Hindlip or Glossop, Dalling or Grhnsthorpo ? One geta quite at a loss to know who's who. My letter to the @Times@ of December 10, !883, headed Literary Honours, in praise of Tennyson's elevation to the House of Lords, and showing how in every age all nations except our own have given honours to authors, literally from China to Peru, elioited plenty both of approval and of censure from journal@ of many denominations. As a matter inévitable when Baron Tennyson was gazëtted, the less euphonious Tupper was stigmatised in the papers as desiring to be a Baron too, -at all events, the @Echo@ said so, and the @Globe@ good-humouredly observed that he deserved thé coronet. They little knew that in the summer of 1863 as para-graphs in my tenth volume of Archives are now before me to show the same derided scribe was seri-ously announced as about to be raised to thé peer-age ail over England and America see two available and respectable proofs in the @British Controversialist@ Hpulston Wright for July 1863, p. 79,-and Bry-ant's @Evening Post@ for September 17, 1863. I name these, as the reverse of comio papers,-and publishing what they supposed true, as in fact was told me by the editors when inquired of. Let this su@@moe as my@reply'to@some recent sneers and strictures. As for letters of the alphabet attached to one's name, almost any one nowadays may have any amount of them by paying fées or subsoriptions in partioular, America has given me many honorary diplomas. And for the matter'of gold medals, who can'covet them, when oven the creators of baking-powder and sewing-machines are surfeited therewith. My poor Prussian medal looks small in comparison. I claim to hâve diseovered the etymology 'of Punch, which Mark Antony Lower in his Patrony-mica says is a name the origin of which is in total obscurity. Now, I found it out thus,-when at Haver-fordwest in 1858 1 saw over.the maritel of the hosteiry, perhaps there still, a map of thé Roman earthwork called loeally Punch Castio and considering how that the neighbouring hills are named Preoelly Procella, storm as often drawing down the rain-clouds.-that Caer Léon is Oastrum Legionis, and that there is a Roman bridge over the little river thoro still styled Ultra Pontem-I decided at once that Pontii Oaste@Uum was thé true name for Punch Castle. Of course, Pontius Pilate and Judas appear in the modi@oval puppet-plays as Punch and Judy,-while Toby refers to Tobit's dog, in a happy confusion of names and dates. The Pontius of the Castle was Proetor of the Second Legion. 2. CHAPTER XXVII. F.R.S. As I have now been more than forty years a Fellow, 1 ought to be ashamed to confess that 1 never contri-buted a Paper to its learned Proceedings all of which as they corne to me 1 give appropriately enough to the famous Wotton Library, belonging to my excellent friend Evelyn, heir and successor to the celebrated John Evelyn of the Sylva, one of the Society's founders. That 1 have seldom even read them is also a pitiful truth for the mysterious nomenclature of modern chemistry, the incomprehensibility to my ignorance of the higher mathematics, the hopeless profundity of treatises on the tides, dynamics, electricity, and micro-scopic anatomicals, are, 1 am free to avow, worse to me than heathen Greek, nay for I @can@ in some sort tackle that , more difficult than the clay tablets of Assyria or a papyrus of Rameses II. So I must confess to being an idle drone among the working bees. Only thrice have I ventured to ask questions oC conséquence, scarcely yet answered by thé pundits. One regards Spectrum Analysis How can we be sure that the lines indicative of gases and other elements are not mainly due to the emanations from our own globe, swathed as it is by more than forty miles of an atmosphere imprognated by ita own salts and aoids in aerial solution? May we not be deducing false con-clusions as to the varying lights of stars and nobuloe, if all the while to our vision they are as it were olouded by our own smoke ? 1 Telescopes have to pierce so thick a stratum of earth's aura and ether that it is expootable they@ would show us only our own composites in those of other worlds. The spectra are varied, 1 know, but so may bo our wrappings of atmosphere from one night to another. Let this ignorant query su@@moo about Dr. Huggins' gréât discovery. Again, I certainly after some knowledge of strange facts could have wished that Mr. Crookes's philoso-phical spiritualism had met with a more patient hear-ing than Dr. Carpenter or Mr. Huxley offered at the time and that Faraday's clumsy mechanical refutation of table-turning had not been considered so conclusive. For there really are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, c., than even your omniscience is aware of and without pinning faith on Madame Blavatsky, or Mr. Hume, or any other wonder-worker from America or Thibet, there doubtless are petty miracles in what is called spiritualism possibly some form of electricity that demand more serutinythan our materialists will hâve the patience to vouchsafe I for one believe in human testimony even as to the miraculous. For a third and last inquiry justly indignant at the horrors of Continental vivisection, and especially in our own humane England at Dr. Ferrier's red-hot wires thrust into live monkeys' brains, I have ôften vainly asked @cui bono@ such terrible cruelty? 1 The highest authorities are at variance with each other as to the practioal utility in human therapeutice of experiments upon agonised brutes but all must be agreed that, so far as morals are concerned, vivisection only hardens the heart and sears the feelings and conscience of doc-tors who may surround thë dying- bod of our dearest, and very possibly make capital of peculiar symptoms in their patient, by experiments transferred from dogs and rabbita to himself 1 Single votes are useless against the annual list of seleoted candidates, or I for one would have at ail inconvenience testified both at Oxford. and in the Royal Society against the eleotion of a certain Professor whose glory lies in vivisection. CHAPTER XXVIII. PERSONATION. IT bas several times happened to me, as doubtless to others of my brethren, to find that 1 have been person-ated, certainly to my considerable discredit. Take these instances. When at Brighton, a fellow bad the effron-tery to collect money in my name, and I suppose he somewhat resembled me, as 1 heard more than once that I had been seen here and there, where 1 undoubtedly was not, and proved an @alibi@. At Bignor, where 1 went to see some Roman pavements on the property of a Sussex yeoman of my name very possibly a German cousin the owner reoeived me with more than suspicion when I said who 1 Was,-because thé true Martin Tupper had been his gùest for a week, and brought him a book he had written, and one of mine then was lying on the table t But 1 soon made it clear that he had been deceived, and that the real Simon Pure was now before him. Divers other cases might be mentioned however, perhaps the most ourious is this, and I extract the whole statement from ohe of my scrap-bopks now before me. It is headed An anecdote to account for certain slanders,@thé date being@August 1865!-1 I have heard it seriously asserted of me that I am a great pugilist 1 and very far in conduot and manners from what one might expeot, and so forth. Now it bas just come to my knowledge that a sporting publican and dog-fancier@ who called his publio-house in the Waterloo Road @Thé Groyhound@ my créât , and has my name over the lintel, has claimed to be the author, and is supposed to be myself 1 Mr. Payne my publisher told me about the @pugilist,' and said he had heard it in the clubs that 1 was a match for Sayera,-as I conclude my sporting namesake is. In America, too, 1 found that my double lived at Hardwick, Worcester Co., N.Y., and that another Martin hailed from Buffalo. So, like poor Edgar Poe, who had to suffer from the machinations of a profligate brother, who gave Edgar's name whenever he got into a scrape, 1 may have sometimes been credited with the sins of atrangers. No one is free from this sort of@calumny. We all have heard of Sheridan's wicked witticism, in that when taken up in Pall Mali for drunkenness, he gave his name Wilberforoo and it is said that he got drunk on purpose to say so 1 My venerable friend, Thomas Cooper, the pious and eloquent old Chartist, has been similarly confused with Robert Cooper, the atheist, lecturer not but that Thomas had once been an atheist too. Another sort of dishonest personation whereto we are a@U liable, whether authora or not, is the having imputed to us divers forged or garbled sentiments, even in the immutability of print, I have now before me a Boston copy of my first Proverbial published by one Joseph Dowe in 1840, which, though stated to be from the London edition, designedly omits all allusion to the Trinity, even my whole essay thereon, for Mr. Dowe as a Unitarian chose to make me one t AIso, 1 have seen my name attached to verses I never wrote, and have been claimed both by Swedenborgians and Freemasons as a brother, while Jesuitry bas otherwise traduced me. We are, and have been for générations, a very house-hive of'bees the whole front of two gables bas them under ita oak floors and panelled walls throughout,-and when guests sleep in certain rooms they have to be forewarned that the groans at midnight are not those of perturbed spirits, but the hum and buatle of multitudinous bées. We oannot drive them away, nor destroy them utterly.-as often has been attempted and if we did, the worry would be only wor-sened, as in that case hornets would corne and succeed to the sweet heritage of bee-dom. When the stuccoed @@on ! of our house was demolished, to show the oaken pattern but it had to be re-roughcast to keep out the weather , there were pailsful of honey carried off by the labourers, of course not without wounds and strife but in ordinary times it is a strange fact that our bées never sting their hosts be oarefui only to remain quiet, and there is no war between man and bee. Two years ago a great comb was built outside an eaveboard, pro-bably because there was no room for more comb inside. It is curious that it should hâve survived two hard winters. Long after all had gone to bed, we heard with trepidation stealthy stops crunching the snow round the house, and aoHM~MMjf that now and then touohod the ground-floor doors and windows, as if quietly trying to get in - at las@@@@t@ fumbled at the ancient hanging handle of the outside kitchen-door 1 Now was the time for Paterfamilias to show his pluck, in the universal scare so, armed @cap-a-pied@, with candies held in the rear by the terrified household, he valor-ously drew the bolts and flung open the heavy oaken door,-to greet-his childrén's donkey, escaped some-how from its stable, and trying to get indoors that cold night for warmth. Laugh as we might, and as you may, the test of courage was all thé same and if this donkey story is pounced upon by some critic or comic as a weak link in my chain of autobiography, I only. hope he will behavo as bravely if a real ruffian tries his doors and windows by night by no moans an. improbable hypothesis in 'these days of communistio radicatism. The old house itself may deserve a word. It came to me as a-shall 1 say 7-matrimony, from my mother if patrimony means from a father, why not matrimony from a mother, her@great-uncle, Anthony Devis, having bought it in 1780. He was a remarkable man in his way and before his age a good landscape painter. as Pilkington avouches , a collector of pictures and curio'-sities,-mostly sold by exeoutors at his death, aged eiglity-niiie, though a full gallery romains at Albury a. carver too, and a constructor of cabinets,@whereof two @Rue spécimens inlaid with brecoiated jaspers,.and made of ebony and cedar from his own turning-Iathe decorate our large drawing-room and the oldest folk in our village still remember the good old gentleman who always had gingerbread in his pockets for them as children, and who was known by them as the man mushroom, seeing he was the @nrst who ever had an umbrella in the place 1 There was, however, another and a better reason for this name, inasmuch as he built for himself an outer painting-room on a hilltop near which ho called Mushroom Hall, because it was just like one as a picture in our drawing-room testifies , being a circular turret surmounted by a @Bat broad dome, with overshadowing eaves all round. This strange summer-house has long vanished. Anthony came of a good old stock paternally, as the civic archives of Preston, in Lancashire, testify ,and his mother was Ann Blackburne, of Marrick Abbey, York-shire,@the title-deeds whereof, old slip parchments and maps from Henry II. to Henry VIII., 1 found in a chest at Albury, and years after transmitted them to Lord Beaumont, the present owner albeit, as a boy, I had been allowed to cut off thé seals and paste them in a oopy-book 1 A@U these deeds, and the history thereof, I had printed in Nichols's Antiquariana. AMERIOAN VISITS. the extreme drinking habits of one generation and the extreme temperance of another mainly due, amongst other causes, to the overflowing prosperities of the middle of this century and the comparative adversities of its declining years. Jeshurun once waxed fat, and kicked, -but since then he bas become one of the lean kine wines and spirits were formerly in abundance as well as bard.dollars, but hâve now been replaced by the cheaper water and discredited paper. Moreover, such shrewd and caustic writers as the Trollopes and Dixon and Charles Dickens have done great good service to their sensible and. sensitive American brothers,-who, far from resenting strictures which for the moment stung, took the best advantage of their utterance in self-improvement. My first visit was hospitably redolent of -all manner of seductive drinks,-wherein, however, 1 was as they thought too temperate my second was as hospitably plentiful so far as eating went, but iced water wherein I was temperate too appeared solitarily for the universal beverage though even in the most teetotal homes this English guest was always generously allowed his port or Madeira or even his whisky if he wished it. Oné of these was a grand dinner with the Maryland Historical Society at Baltimore, May i~, 1851, my late friend Mr. Kennedy in the chair as president, while Sir Henry Bulwer and myself supported him right and left, some hundreds of other guests also being présent. Some distinguished gentleman having proposed my health,@ This brought to his feet Mr. Tupper, who, having expressed his thanks in an appropriate manner, and acknowledged his superior gratitude to the Author of all good, alluded to that international loving-kindness whioh he aYowed to be one main errand of his life and he very happily brought in Horace's prophetical description of England and America in their relation of mother and child, @0 matre pulohrâ filia pulchrior.' He followed by relating some striking incidents of the good feeling which per-vades the old country in favour of her illustrious on-spring. One we cannot fail to give was that thé Royal Naval School at Greenwich had inserted his well-known' ballad 'To Brother Jonathan' in a collection published for the use of the Royal Navy. The speaker thën paid an eloquent compliment to the literature of Amerioa-her poets, statesmen, historians, and divines. Ho re-joiced that @Insular Amerioa and Continental England' were so intimately and inseparably intermingled in thé authorial productions of the hùman mind, as well as bound together by the strongest ties of nature and reli-gion, of lineage, laws, and language. Adverting tb thé wise piety of such associations as the one before him, he exhorted to keep together the records of the past, that they may sanctify the present and be an encourage-ment to good and a warning against evil for the future. He commented severely upon the vandal act of thé British troops under General Ross in burning thé national archives at Washington. In this connection he introduced the beautiful lines from Milton @@Lift not thy spear against the Muse's bower The great Emathian conqueror bid spare Thé house of Pindarus, when temple and tower Went to the ground.' In conclusion, Mr. Tupper related an interesting fact, which in his mind suggested what should be to Americaus a pleasing idea-possibly a discovery-as to the origin of the national flag. On making a pilgrimage just lately to Mount Vernon, he was forcibly struck by the circum-stance that the ancient family coat-of-arms of the illustrious Washington consisted of three stars in the upper portion of the shield, and three stripes below the crest represented an eagle's head, and the motto was singularly appropriate to American history, @Exitus aota probat.' Mr. Tuppor said he could not but con-sider this a most interesting coincidence. He thougbt the world might well oongratulate America upon being thé Geographical Apotheosis of that gréât unspotted character, who, while he yet lived, was proapectively her typical impersonation. One day when casually dipping into Addison's @Spectator@ at Albury, I made the following discovery which I recorded in the newspapers at the time, and give the extract now fully as thus @In thé a~ist No. of Addison's @~pec@@~o?', bearing date Thursday, December 6th, 1711, and as signed fi C. one of the letters of the mystié OEio , by the great Joseph Addison himself, oecurs the following remarkable anticipation of our presumably most modern diacoyery. Those who have access to the London edition of the @Spectator@ of i8~.f, published by J. J. Chidiey, 123 Aldersgate Street, can verify the verbatim faithfulness of thé following extract from page 274@@ Strada, in one of his Prolusions Lib. II. prol. 6 , gives an account of a chimerical correspondence between two friends by the help of a certain loadstone, which had such virtue in it, that if it touched. two several needles, when one of the needles so touched began to move, the other, though at never so great a distance, moved at the same time, and in the same manner. He tells us that the two friends, being each of them pos-sessed of one of those needles, made a kind of dial-platë, inscribing it with four-and-twenty letters, in the same manner as the hours of the day are marked upon the ordinary dial-plate. They then @nxed one of the needles on eaoh of these plates in such a manner that it could move round without impediment, so as to touch aay of the, four-and-twenty letters. fi Upon their separating from one another into distant countries, they agreed to withdraw themselves puno-tually into their closets at. a certain hour of the day, and to converse with one another by means of this their in-vention. Accordingly, whon they were some hundred miles asunder, each of them shut himself up in his closet at the time appointed, and immediately cast his eye upon his dial-plate. If he had a mind to write anything to his friend, he directed his needle to every letter that formed the words which he had occasion for, making a little pause at the end of every word or sentence, to avoid confusion. The friend in the meanwhile saw his own sym-pathetic needle moving of itself to every letter which that of his correspondent pointed at. By this means they talked together across a whole continent, and con-veyed their thoughts to one another in an instant over cities or mountains, seas or deserts. If Monsieur Scudery, or any other writer of romance, had introduoed a necromancer, who is generally in the train of a knight-errant, making a present to two lovera of a couple of these above-mentioned needles, the reader. would not have been a little pleased to have seon them corresponding with one another when they were guarded by spies and watchers, or. separated by castles and adventures. Il In the meanwhile, if ever this invention should be revived or put in praotioe, 1 would propose that upon the lovor's dial-plate there should be written not only the four-and-twenty letters, but several entire words which have aiwaya a place in passionate epistles, as @ûames, darts, die, language, absence, Oupid, heart, oyes, hang, drown, and the like. This would very much abridge the lover's pains in this way of writing a letter, as it would enable him to express the most usefai and significant words with a single touch of the needle.-C. Thus far Addison, a hundred and seventy years ago, and Strada whoever he may be, for ordinary bio-graphical dictionaries ignore him , perhaps fifty before him, and the two unknown experimentalists, perhapa twenty beyond that, making iu ail two hundred and forty or fifty years ago as the date of electrical in-vention whereof we Bée no further mention in the @Spectator@. But is it not aiso among the Century of the Marquis of Woreester'B Inventions ? -as is pos-sible the scarce volume is not near me for reference. Let the curious reader who can, turn to it and see. Meanwhile, how strangely Addison and Strada have anticipated the dial-plate, and thé needles, and the letters, and the short forma for common words, all so familiar to our telegraphists. Verily there is nothing new under the sun. Extract from my Archive-book, No. 8. Date October 15. @i~6.@@ was again an electric guest, this time at the Great Albion dinner Liverpool to Mr. Morse, whom 1 had met at Erith and in America. A day or two afterwards 1 sent him a letter of invitation to Albury, enclosing the sonnet below and not knowing his London address 1 posted it to my brother Charles in London for him to read and forward. So the moral is, don't try to do, twice what you've done well once. Interviewing is another sort of homage nowadays to popular authorship in America it is very rife,-and I never came to any city but, immediately on arriva!, two or three représentatives of opponent editors would call, and very courteousiy request to be allowed to turn me inside out, and then to report upon me 1 only remem-ber one or two cases which I will not specify wherein my inquisitor was not all 1 could hâve wished, or treated his patient victim more unkindly than perhaps a venial native humour might make necessary. As TO ÂDVERTISINCt. A word about advertisements, surely an authorial topic. The absurdly extravagant profusion in whioh thousands of pounda are now being continually flung away in advertising, is one which was nèver approved by me, and as long as' my books remained in print, at ~7 suggestion they all got sold without it. At present there are almost none in the market except Proverbial Philosophy, my Poems, Stephan Langton, and Dramas, and these still live and sell as before, after a silent life of many years. 1 suppose advertisiag must answer, or it would not be persisted in and oertainly thé news-papers that chiefly live thereby exhort all, to orowd their columns, if they,wish to win fortune but how the perpétuai and reiterated obtrusion of, auch single words as Oopack, or Syndicatea, or Beecham's Pills, or Argosy Braces, or Grateful and Ooinfortiag, c. 6., can prbve seductive baits, 1 do not see nor feel the shamoless amount of space they @611 in our newspapers, and especially the impertinent way in which thëy intrude upon us while reading, as interleaved into books and magazines, so entirely disgusts me that 1 have often de-claréd 1 would rather go without tea, coffee, tobacco, or snuff this is a phrase, for the two latter 1 abomi-nate than deign to patronise those persistent advertisers A, B, 0, D, or E. And yet 1 do know a splendid church at Eastbourne wholly built of pills, and Professer Holloway's ointment has produced a palatial institute, and another wholesale advertiser tells me he spends ~30,000 a year on notices and paragraphs, to gain there-by ~'50'ooo'ssd so one cannot but. acquiesce in Car-lyle's cynical dictum, so cruelly alluded to by Deau Stanley in his funeral sermon at .Westminster, that there are in our community 26,000,000, mostly fools, otherwise how can folks be weak enough to be forced to pay for goods, or bads, merely by dint of, réitération ? 1 There is, however, one form of advertisement which I have found to pay,-and that is not praise, but abuse. KINDNESS TO ANIMALS. As to tny several efforts in print to hinder cruelty to animaJs, bestdo and beyond what a reader may aiready find in my published books, let me chiefly mention thèse two @ny-leaves, widely circulated by the Humane Society in Jermyn Street to wit, Mercy to Animals, and my Four anti-Vivisection Sonnets. The latter 1 must preface with an interesting anecdote. Before Louis Napoleon was Emperor, 1 accompanied a depu-tation from Guernsey to Cherbourg, met him, had pleasant speech with him, and gave him a book, Proverbial Philqsophy , thus making his personal acquaintance which many years after 1 utilised as thus. The horrors of that infernal veterinary torture-house at Alfort, where disabled cavalry horsés were on system vivisected to death, had been known, to us by. letters in the @Times@, of course denounoing the crimi-nality 1 remember reading that one poor old horse survived more than threesoore opérations, and used to be led in daily strapped With bandages and plaistérs amid the cheors of the domdniaoal students 1-and this exoited me to make a strong personal effort to stop the outrages'at Alfort. Acoordingly, I wrote from Albury a letter to the Emperor if 1 kept and can find a oopy I will print it hère as from one gentleman to another fond of his horse and dog, exhortin'g him to interfère and hinder such horrors. 1 told him that I purposely did thia in a private way, and not through any news-paper or minister, beoause 1 wished him to cure,jM op~o ~o M, à crying evil whereof he was ignorant and there-fore innocent leaving the issue of my appeal to his own generous feeling and to Providence, but otherwise not expecting nor requesting any reply. 1 therefore got none but whether @post hoc@ or @pro .pter Aoc@ 1 do not know thé result was that vivisection at Alfort was suspended at once, though how long for is unknown to me. And hère may come a brief memory I wrote lately of Colonel Fred. Burnaby for an American editor. 1 am asked to give a short note of personal reminis-cence about my lately departed friend, Colonel @Fred. Burnaby@, with whom 1 was intimate for three years before his death. Every one bas read his popular life, and heard of his many exploits how alone in mid-air he navigated a balloon across the Ohannel how he aocomplished, in spite of State telegrams to'the oontrary, his adventurous and patriotio ride to Khiva in dead winter and defying perils of ail sorts how he stood six feet four in his stockings with another foot to be added to that magni@ncent specimen of manhood when in jack-boots and in his plumed helmet how he was strong enough to bind a kitchen poker round his neck, to crack cobnuts in his @nngers, and to carry a pair of Shetland ponies upstairs under his arms,-how alao the genial giant, quite the Arao of Tennyson's Princess, was the gentlest and kindest and least dangerous of knights-errant unless, indeed, his just wrath was aroused by anything mean or insolent, when doubtless he could be terrible , and how he was the idolised of men, eapeoially his own brother giants of the Royal Régiment of Blues, and naturally was also the. adored of women wherever he showed himself@ This Admirable Crichton had every social acoomplishment, but as he was also gifted with a knowledge of many tongues, even to Turkish and Arabie, beyond the more familiar French, German, Italian, and Spanish, of course he must dare all sorts of perilous travel, if only to provo that he was no oarpet-knight, no mère 'gold stick' at court, or silver-oasqued statue at, the Horse Guards. So he foarlessiy risked his life in a@U ways on every possible occasion which thé War O@@mco routine gave him on holiday. Khiva and Kars, and of late at last the fatal Mahdi war, had fascinations for him of danger which bis thirst for, active service too muoh refused to him as obliged officially to bo a stay-at-home had not power to resist and we all know how gallantly, if indeed too rashly, he fougbt and fell on what his Viking blood loved best as a deathbed, the field of battle. For he came of an old Teutonie family, and on his mother's side was also a direct descendant, as he told me himself, of our heroia and gigantio King Edward III., whom he is said greatly to have resembled, as the portrait at Windsor Oastle proves. We were talking about ancestry and the anec-dote came out naturally enough. In politics a strong Conservative, he, with charac-teristic antagonism, chose radical Birmingham for his coveted seat in Parliament, but alas@ he bas not lived to hazard the election. He. was a neat, fluent, and epigrammatic speaker, as potent with his tongue as with his sword and as for the pen albeit his hand-writing muât have puzzled compositors , the myriade of readers who hâve enjoyed his atirring books in print, can testify how brilliant and eloquent he was for the matter of authorship. A DiNINQ-OUT ANECDOTE. As@@ have before said, not having been much given to society, nor thereforè a professional parasite of Amphi-tryon though sometimes tempted to his side as a lion, but more often vainly, for 1 always refused if 1 could , 1 have an instructive anecdote to give about a celebrated conversationist, whom 1 will not name nor indieate even by initiais. One evening 1 found myself compelled to accompany him to a great man's banquet-@nota bene@, it was after 1 had well recovered speech-and so 1 found myself at his chambers perhaps ten minutes too soon. He called to me from his dressing-room, bidding me to amuse myself till he was ready. Now, on the study table were laid several books, open, with weights to keep them so and 1 glanced from one to another to while -away the time. Then up came his brougham, and off we went. At dinner my diner-out started a topic, whereof innocently enough 1 remembered instàntly a suitable epigram. Not long after another subject .gave me occasion to tell a witty story, which somehow came to me at the moment. My friend asked me with a keen glance where 1 had read it, and at once 1 recolleotëd those open books and understood the position, resolving mischievousiy to out-ûank the manoenverer. Accordingly, at each oppor-tunity, with seeming innocence, 1 wiped hia eye, as they say at a @battue@, and certainly reaped thé anecdotic AM ?os@ Mr. So-and-so had ounningly contrived and hoped to achieve for himself. Ï confess it was vicious of me, but who could help taking the benefit of suoh a chance ? Hosts should beware of wits who oram their jokes and anecdotes. Years after 1 met the same gentleman at another entertainer's table, where 1 found him in my présence not qùito thé livener-up they had expected, and he seemed a little shy of me probably he thought me an omniscient, for I never told the pobr man 1 had found him out. 1 fear ho bas departed to a world where genuine truthfulness is more accepted as a virtue than in this. A MORMON GUEST. Quito recently 1 have had a visit from a young American, who brought me a letter from a so-called cousin-at a@U events a namesake-in the Far West, asking me to tell her about her German ancestry. My visitor was good-looking, well-dressed, fair-spoken, and gentlemanly also well-bred and well-to-do. 1 will not indicate his name, but I may state that he is a n'ear relative of the eminent electrician who illuminates so magnificently the fountains at South Kensington. Of course, as pleased with his manners and deportment, I. kept him to luncheon and finding that he hailed from Utah, naturally asked if he knew Sait Lake City and. the Mormons there. Certainly he lived not a hundred miles from the city, and those were his own pëople as a Mormon himself from in@ noy, ho had nothing but good to say of them, and we in England had been very much mialed by Mrs. Stenhouse and other trayellers. As to plurality of wivës, not two per cent. of their whole 200,000 had more than one wife. His own father, a rich merchant and a church-hierarch, a stake of the tabernacle much as we should say a pillar , had but one-his own dear mother-and he scarcely knew any one with more. It was quite a European misjudg-ment tbat many followed Brigham Young's doctrine, whioh never had been Joseph Smith's.-and the present ohief, Taylor, had but one. He showed us many cabinet photographs of Sait Lake City, his own family, leading Mormons, and the like especially of the Old tabernacle, like a monstrous tortoise, and one from a flnished draw-ing. of the new, of even more tasteless architecture, being the most gigantic piece of perpendicular ever perpetrated, and full of unsightly windows. When asked about the golden book,-well ho had never seen it, but believed in it thoroughly because all the .twelve apostles had seen it and he trusted their testimony. Eleven of those apostles were now dead, one only sur-viving. Just as with our friends of Mr. Irving's sect at Albury, which arose in the same year as Mormonism. We had never set eyes on the originals of our own Scriptures-in tact, they did not exist-but believed the witnessing of others, as he did. Ho himself was not a missionary, but would go if he was sent by the Ghurch though he mightn't like it, he was bound to@ obey@ authority, c. c. 1 had plenty more talk with him, and found him intelligent, modest, and in every way a remarkably agreeable young fellow and I added to my mental Mpef~oM'6 of botter judgments that on Mormonism,-even as heretofore Mr. Sinnett has taught me not utterly to despise Buddhism, Dr. Wilkinson to revere Swedenborgianism, and a few othér people 1 might name who are true believers, to be charitable as to other sorts of strange isms once 1 met a very religioug olergyman who still held by Johanna Southcote and we hâve ail heard how Lady Hester@Stanhope had an Arab horse always rëady saddied for Messiah when He is to ride into Jerusalem and how some other person had a gold spoon and fork laid daily at his table for the sudden ooming of a Divine Guest 1 Car personal lesson is to be tolérant of all manner of innocent onthusiasms, to hear both sides and bear with all opinions,-s.ome-times finding to our astonishment that @Maok sheep may after all be whiter than they looked, and that unchari-table préjudice is but another name for ignorant folly. Before taking leave of my Mormon guest, 1 ought to report that he was teetotal, handsome, taciturn rather than talkative, a hunter among the Rockies, an author himself, and of course an old book-friend, so 1 made him happy with some autographic poetries. With reference to Joe Smith's own theological creed, there is a very neat and notable @@@~M'~M of it on p.-i~! of a bright little book 1 have lately read, titled Frank's Ranche, or my Holiday in the Rockies, easily accessible. That creed is so good that when 1 read it aloud to my homeflock they said, Why, we believe ail that 1 -and as to the evil matter of many wives, not only did the original Joseph repudiate that doctrine, but his namesake son, still a chief among the Mormons, does the same, and so far bas seceded from the Brigham heresy whioh a son of mine says is not bigamy, but Brighamy. A banknote expérience when a very small child I used to be taken to the Postford paper-mill at Albury by my nurse, who had a follower or a followed in the foreman there. While they talked together, 1 was deputed to amuse myself by making banknote paper, as thus a spoonful@of pulp put into a shallow tray of wire and shaken deftly made a small oblong of paper duly impressed with Britahnia and water-marked being then dried on a @nannel pad. Many years after, when .1 was preparing for Oxford under Mr. Holt at Postford House, there was discovered a secret oupboard in the wall of his drawing-room whieh was found to contain several forged plates for printing banknotes and this discovery ac-counted for the recent suicide of a Mr. H-@ a previous owner of the paper-mill, who evidently feared exposure and conviction. No one now is allowed to make bank-note paper, except the honourable firm of Messrs. Portal, which bas the monopoly thereof but when I was a child, any one might do it, and if there was a forger handy, fraud was possible to any extent. Our New-land's Corner on Merrow Downs is so called from Abraham Newland, whose name is printed on old bank-notes as F. May is on new ones, and who owned Postford Mill. Rence the word Sham-Abram for a forged note. 2. Let me a so give a brace of home sketches of Long-fellow. I have had two principal interviews with him in his beautiful home at Cambridge, Massachusetts, at the wide interval between those visita of twenty-five years. Of the first of these 1 record a few words from my American MS. journal in 1851, adding some un-written thoughts and recollections. On April i6th, then, in the year just named, Longfellow wrote to me cordially, and with much kindly appreciation, and soon after, calling on me at Boston, took me off in his carriage over the flooded lowlands to the ancient for America University of Cambridge, where the Queen Anne-like colleges are nestled in fine old elms. He treated me, of course, most hospitably, and had asked several @@iends to meet the traveller but one, a chief guest, was otherwise engaged, and so 1 missed Lowell, to my great disappointment. It is not my form to detail private conversation, nor to describe the Lares and Penates of sacred domesticity but 1 may reveal génerally that I spent several golden hours of intel-lectual communion with the Abbott 'Laurences, Ticknor, Fields, Preàcott, and Everett-illustrious names, which will sufficiently indicate the reception they gave me. At this time of day 1 cannot remember the thousand winged speeohes that @Bew about that genial board, and, as 1 failed, from conscientious motives, to record them in my journal, I will not invent, after thirty-four years have passod over my memory, with their crowds of other words and fanoies. Be this enough I reoolleot to have asked Longfellow why ho wrote Exoelsi@o@f, and not the more grammatical Bxce@@I@sMM, as the title to one of his most iamous pooms. The reason is a ourious one he wrote those stirring verses, by request, on thé motto 0 for the New York coat-of-arms, whieh is legended not quite accurately, Excelsi@or@. And when, in the samo line of thought, 1 inquired why he named a German story Hyperion, with no apparent reason @@om clas-sical associations, he pertinently enough answered me by pronouncing the name ~Mpe~-tOM~ going higher , the story being a tale of progress in human character. And now to leap over twenty-five years, at whioh interval I paid my second visit to America in 1876, when again 1 had the privilege of being Longfellow's guest in the same historic abode where Washington had once his headquarters. My kind-hearted host insisted on my occupying the same arm-chair I had before, and which since, he said, had been the throne of Dickens and Thackeray, and every book-celebr@hy that had visited Cambridge. Among invited guests unable to. corne was Oliver Wendell Holmes, but 1 soon after made up for this loss by having a long talk with that shrewd and amusing writer at Boston and once more, alas 1 no Lowell, whom 1 missed again, though 1 had waited for him that quarter of a century 1 Longfellow, out of compliment so he kindly said to his English guest, had specially provided pheasants and Stilton cheeae, among such more Transatlantic delicacies as wild venison from Tupper.Lake, in the Adirondac@s , and canvas-back ducks from Baltimore to say less of terrapin soup, whereof the unhatched eggs of tortoises are the OMMe-oMcAe After dinner he gaTe me an apple from Beaupré, Evangelino's farm, the pips whereof 1 sent to Albury for planting. Mr. Fields, on this festive occasion, reoited@some of Mark Twain's humour, and 1 had to give sundry of my American ballads, and the host himself bis exquisite Psalm of Life j my Venus, in reply to his Mars, having appeared, and been praised by him, somo years before. With @Charles Kingsley@, however seldom we met, I had strong sympathy in many ways, as a man of mon, to be loved and admired but chiefly we could feal for each other in the matter of stammering,@@ sort of a@@miction not sufficiently appreciated. In this connection 1 may give an anecdote to the point. Soon after my return from America in 1851 1 dined with my neighbour at AI-bury, Henry Druinmond, the humoursome M.P., always not a little good-naturediy misohievous. He knew that I had not approved of Lord Elgin's petulant removal of his viceroyal establishment from Montreal to Toronto, and cunningly resolved t6 draw me out before witnesses on the matter. Now I had taken in to dinner' an elderly Scotch lady unknown to me, and sat next to her of course. Soon my lively host somewhat unfairly asked me about my visit to Canada, and what 1 thought tif the then notorious flight of the Governor to far dis-tant Toronto,-forcing me to express my disapprova!, whioh naturally as an honest man 1 did, on which my left-hand neighbour, a lady of rank whom I knew, whis-pered Mind what you are saying, you took in his mothor. Accordingly, I had frankly to turn and say, And l'm sure Lady Elgin will ,agree with me, and you too, Mr. Drummond, for no captain should fly from his post because he's laughed at. This candid speech was fortunately applauded all round the table, and not least by the friendly Countess and the ba@@~ed mischief lover. For other of my politicals, take this common-sense essay from my pen, hitherto unpublished @@1S THE ONE-VOTE SYSTEM RIGHT OR WRONCt? a In a nation self-governed through its own representa-tives, it seems reasonable to admit that each citizen should have a vote each citizen, wo say, simply as such whether mâle or female, labourer, pauper, civil, niilitary, naval, or o@@mcial, every one not convicted of crime nor an atteated lunatic, of full age, of sufficient capacity evidenced by being able to read and write , cglibate or married, rich or poor,-every@persou in our commonwealth should equitably, it may well bo con-ceded, Lave his or her single vote in the government of the country. Poverty is no crime, therofore the Work-, house should not disfranchiso sex is no just disqualin-oation, thereforo the woman should have her vote as freely as the man, for surely marriage ought not to' suffèr derogation and disgrace by denial of the common right of citizenship as its penalty the soldier, sailor, policeman, government o@nicial, and any other class which may now be deprived of their birthright by law or custom, should certainly be admitted to thé poil like other patriotio citizens in. short, manhood su@nrage, it may be theoretically argued, is just and wise-manhood of course including womanhood, as suggested above for even a wife either sides with her husband or controls him in common cases and in the less usual instances where he rules, thére need be no more tyranny about poli-tical matters than about. domesticities, and so the home would scarcely. bé any the.worse even for partisan zeal. However,.whi!st admitting the theoretical propriety of a one vote for each citizen in the state, there remains to be coinsidéred the higher practical justice of@many having more than one. Numbers alone are not the strength of a people if of infe@nor quality they are rather its weakness. For the Parliament of England représentation is demanded of all the virtues, talents, and acqùirements, not cortainly of the vice, ignorance, poverty, and other evils mord rife amoug the lower rungs of the social ladder than to those above them. Thé single vote system so far as the franchise bas any influence at ail depresses and demoralises every class, as reducing all to one dead levé!. Thé ballot plan is now law and. cannot well be done away with but it is manifestly a h~miiiation fur intelligence to have to sign with his mark in order that ignorance may thus feel itself on an equality and for honest genia@Hty to be hushed into silent aocresy, that it may not put to shame the cunning fraud of a partizan who wishes to hide his real opinion. However, it is now too late to mend thé ballot-box let it be, aud let the single voter' use it if lie pleases. Another and a wiser scheme presents itself, practi-cally if possible even now to avert the national ruin wrought by the machinations of a rash and blind self-seeking spirit of party, often. seen hoist by its own petard, though too liable to destroy the foundations of society in the explosion. Shortly and simply, the scheme is this. Let every man, high or low, add to his one vote others as lie may and can. Be there a vote for the Victoria Cross, another for the Albert Medal, auother for long good-service in' the hous.ehold or thé farm, another for any such intellectual exploits among thé poor as .Samuel Smiles bas recorded all thèse being accessible to thé humblest, and so elevating them thus far. And now to asoend a few rungs, let additional votes be given to owners of a stated number of acres, to possessors of a certain amouut of money, to those who have been deemed worthy of public honours, and the like. A little further, let every mayor of a town have his o@@mcial vote, and the Presidents of the Royal Society and Royal Academy, and perhaps two or three other cbiefs of science and art and so forth. Thus, tbeu, we might get, by way of oounterpoise to the voting power of a bare and overwhelming prolé-tariat, the worthier aud far sweeter voices of those who have virtues aud excellences of@Yarioua kinds to recom-mend them,-so that if the lowest constituent côuMta for one, the highest may add up to six or eight. And thus, while no one of the mob is denied his one vote, those who rise above the crowd receive the more than one they hâve earned by good-doing or position, and plunip them all accordingly to the worthiest candidate., The method of ascertai@mag and ensuring such votes might be this. IN connection with the above, I will hère print for thé first time a paper written long ago on the now rife subject of a cure for Irish misery at all events partially. Ireland bas been with me a theme for many kinds of literature from that usual sort of authorship, letters in the @Times@, to journalising on occasion, balladising in or out of season, and now and then a political squib or graver article. I have known that hapless land well in old days irom Giant's Causeway to Cape Clear have been a guest in several noted homes,, as with geological Enniskillen and astronomical Crampton know the natives well, and how they hâve been taught by prieats and démagogues to hate the Sassenacb, and@ like most well-meaning men, who, after every kind effort, find tbemselves utterly misunderstood, am as a -merely private and quite unprejudiced@politician entirely at a loss .to know how to please that inipracticable people, or to mend their misérable condition. However, that in my authorial fashion I @@A tM tried, let the follôwing paper prove written and published nearly thirty years ago. Nations think and feel and act much as individuals do for, after all, the largest orowd of men is, only an aggre-gate of units. If contempt provokes a man to anger, and avowed negleot forces him into indolence and hope-lessnesa, we shall see the same result in masses as we do in single persons and the causes which may have generated hatred and despair will everywhere and everywhen find cures in their contraries, honour being accorded in the place of contempt, and kindly care instead of cold indifference. Thus, the far too common phrase, 'No Irish need apply,' bas doubtless wrought in@anité ill-feeling and the Levite's chilling rule of @passing by on the other side' evermore arouses indig-nation nationally no less than individually. Now, it cannot be denied in an ethnological sensé that the Celtic nature is peculiarly sensitive any more than it can be denied historically that its good feelings have been too often systematically crushéd, and its generous impulses seared. If the l'eutonio mind illus-trates in sterner traits the manhood of human intelli-gence, the Ceit shows its gayer youthfulness, if not indeed tha lighter phases of its rec@Hesa childhood and it bas been a second nature for the Saxon to hold mas,tery over the Celt, as a weaker race is everywhere subject to a strong one. Moreover, opposition in re-ligious creed bas had its evil influences, scarcely yet extinct, however caustically such a cure may in vain have been hitherto attempted. We must take nations as we find them thé Keltoi and the Sakai@ aiways at contrariety, do not seem to have altered in character from the earliest prehistorio reports,of old Herodotus even to our own times, more than three thousand years..Racial peculiarities are known to survive the actual transplantation to new lands see in especial the Irish of America as the Roman poet bas it, 'Those who cross the sea may change their sky, but not their mind.' Therefore it is that a far-seeing and philosophical statesmanship should ever deal spoci@neally-and as if individually-with national churacter for example,. if we would couvert the typical Irish mind from muât we say it ? hatred of England to the love of her, we must commence as we would in domestic life, by somehow managing to please our too sensitive sister, by showing her our sympathies, and by treating her with honour instead of contemp-tuoua indifference thus investing her with @thé gar-ment of praise for the spirit of heavinesa.@ It is a quarter of a century since the writer of this paper published in the course of a book of his, now somewhile out of print Thé Rides and Reveries of ~Eaop Smith , the following short chapter, on page 322, hère reproduced textually. Thé Celts are a folk of easentially loyal in-stincts but much as Americans often are heard to complain in their own behaJf they have, as an inde-pendent nation, no seen and known object for their loyalty. It is not easy to caloulate the advantages of such a social revolution as this and surely, in spite of many obvious objections, such an experimeut might be worth the trial. M? lamented son, Henry de Beauvoir, active and athletic, was killed in South Africa by the most un-likely accident of being jolted o@n the front seat in a rutty road and crushed to death under the wheel of an ox-waggon creeping at two miles an hour 1 This sad event occurred on May 31, i8~t and thé news-papers at thé time, both British and South African, fully recorded not only the accident but the heroism of thé brave youth, the kind but unavailing assiduities of friends, and the municipal honours accorded to him at his funeral, when the mayor and council, the volun-teers and chief inhabitants of King William's Town every window shuttered followed him to the grave, where Archdeacon Kitton read the solemn service and some months after, a marble headstone was placed over his rema@ms. His two, brothers have written some touching stanzas to his memory but they are private. I mention all this sadnesa now by way of publicly acknowledging the kindness of Archdeacon Kitton and, other friends at King William's Town, not fqrgetting a most friendly officer of the American navy, from whom we have received many excellent letters and présents from ail round the world, ever since he was among thé @Qrst to break to us the death o~ my son, now @Ëfteen-years ago 1 désire, then,' cordially to thank T. G. for these CHAPTER XLVI. kindnesses as also Mr. Robertson, of Brechin, N.B., whose son was Henry's African comrade, with him at the time of the catastrophe, and following him to the grave. Henry having been for good ancestral reasons chris-tened de Beauvoir, remiuds me of a memorable matter of our family history which, as it is on record, 1 will, here relate. In the days of King James I. to quote with pedantic omissions from a pedigree , one Peter de Beau-voir, descended from a younger branch of the ducal house of Rutland, had an eldest son, James, whose daughter Rachel married Pierre Martin my spiritual sponsor after Martin Luther , and her daughter married a Carey of Guernsey, whose descendant married my grandfather. Peter's second son, Richard, married a Priaulx, also related to us, and her daughter married a Benyon, in Charles II.'s time, whose descendant is now the mil-lionaire, Sir Richard Benyon de Beauvoir of Reading, o. o. Now, this is thé strange fact which bas always puzzled me as well as others. The old De Beauvoir was a very thrifty miser, and died two hundred years ago possessed of great wealth, which bas increased enor-mousiy up to our day, seeing he bad landed property in the north of London,. now including De Beauvoir l'own. In the second generation, bis grand-daughters Rachel Martin of the elder branch and Marie Priaulx of the younger, contended at law for the inheritance after some intestacy and a terrible lawsuit raged in Ohancery for 150 years, between thé Tuppers and thé Benyons,-and was carried even to the House of Lords, being finally decided in my memory for the Benyons. 1 remember my unole saying he would not take thirty thousand pounds for his individual ohanoet'-but my lésa sanguine father carod not to join in the lawsuit,-saying he wo@ùM not throw good money after bad. For my own judgment, and I can speak as an old conveyancing barrister though without business or expérience of nearly fifty years' standing, our side as the elder had the best right, though the two sisters might well and wisely@have shared in a compromise. But@somehow@it came to be decided that the younger claimant of that vast property must bave @all@,-and the elder be atrangely left out in the cold. After the conclusion of the Lords, further litigation was hopeless so those whom I now represent as almost the last of the Abruzzi must acquiesce in getting nothing, while the opponent side bas the good luck to possess, as Dr. Johnson has it, wealth beyond the dreams of avarice. Such is life,-and law the most obstinate and the riohest win the less pertina-cious and the poorer are allowed to fail it is a process of Darwin's survival of the fittest. Ail this is now too late to mend but 1 do hope that if ever 1 go to Engelfield Castle, Sir Richard will be kindly and genial to his far-off cousin, who but for some legal qui@bMe unknown might have dispossessed him. My father numbered among bis patients the Duke of Rutland, and 1 have heard him say that they half-humorously called each other cousins. A LOST CHANCE IN BBMBAVIA. LUTHER. 1 GAVE a second lecture, one on Luther, at the same place, and on the like solicitation of Mr. Le Fevre, Président of the Balloon Sooiety the date being November 9, 1883. Of this lecture, not to be tedious, 1 will here give only the peroration. And now, in conclusion, let us answer thèse reason-able questions What has Martin Luther done and su@nered tbat we at this distant interval of four centuries should reverence his memory with gratitude and ad-miration ? What was the lifewôrk he was raised up to do, and bow did ho do it ? and what influence have his labours of old on thé times in which we live?-We must remember that in the sixteenth century priest-craf~ bad culminated to its rankest height of fraud, cruelty, vice, and superstition the lay-folk everywhere were its serfs and victims, not to mention also numbers of the worthier clerios who hated but could, not break their bonds.
